The climate change process is exogenous (to the country) and the onset of the abrupt catastrophic event is uncertain. An adaptation policy entails investing in a particular sort of capital that will reduce the damage inflicted by the calamity when it occurs. This investment consumes resources and entails real costs but yields benefits only after the catastrophe occurs. The policy design problem involves the investment and buildup of the adaptation capital in light of the delicate tradeoffs between the (certain) investment costs prior to occurrence and the benefits after (the uncertain) occurrence. The damage inflicted by a catastrophic climate change can assume different forms, shapes and scales, depending on the nature of the catastrophe (rise in seawater, disease outburst, extended drought) and on the afflicted location (see the taxonomy of events-damages in de Zeeuw and Zemel 2012). Following Karp and Tsur (2011), we assume that the event reduces income by a certain share from the occurrence date onwards. The innovation here is to make this reduction a function of the stock of the adaptation capital at the occurrence date. The flow of investment benefits can then be associated with the reduction in the expected income loss vis-à-vis the expected loss that would have been realized without the investment (or under different investment policies). We characterize the optimal investment policy and show how it depends on preferences (time discounting and aversion to intergenerational inequality), the (exogenous) catastrophic hazard, the marginal productivity of preventive capital, and the scale and severity of the damage. We find that for stationary economies (without technical change), investment in adaptation capital may not always be warranted, depending on time preferences, risk aversion, the catastrophic hazard (occurrence risk) and the severity of the ensuing damage. When undertaking adaptation measures is warranted, which is always the case for truly catastrophic damages, the optimal adaptation capital process converges monotonically to a unique steady state. In contrast, growing economies should always engage in adaptation and eventually build the corresponding capital stock to the point beyond which it is no longer effective. The intuitive explanation is rather simple. A larger economy stands more to lose in case the event strikes and, at the same time, can more easily afford to relinquish the resources needed to invest in adaptation capital. For stationary economies growth is (at best) transitional, whereas a growing economy gets larger and larger as time goes by. A similar effect of economic growth on climate policies was found in the context of mitigation policies (abatement of GHG emission), namely, for a stationary economy optimal emission reaches a steady state, whereas for a growing economy emission should eventually be diminished to achieve a zero hazard (see Tsur and Zemel 2009). The present work complements this line of study and provides a basis for extensions that will investigate the effect of economic growth on mitigation–adaptation tradeoffs.Footnote 3
 The next section lays out the model’s components and specifies the policy problem. Sections 3 and 4 characterize the optimal policy for stationary and growing economies, respectively, and provide insights into some salient properties. Section 5 concludes and the Appendix contains technical derivations.

Title: Monetary policy with linear information costs
Intro: This paper develops a monetary model where information is treated as a scarce resource in the transactions technology and is intimately related to the strategic monetary model of Dubey and Geanakoplos (1992, 2000). In their model, the nominal interest rate can be seen as a standard transaction cost, hence the outcomes are typically non-Walrasian. Money emerges as an institutional phenomenon and its quantity in circulation fully specifies how much trade can take place. The same approach is adopted here, however emphasis is given to a specific transaction cost, namely the cost of information, e.g. the cost of search, data gathering and processing of market information. The basic monetary model we encounter in strategic market games incorporates outside money that it is introduced by the imposition of a cash-in-advance constraint. This sort of money emphasises on its transactions role whereas the store of value function has been neglected due to the static character of the game. Hence, it enables us to scrutinize the role of transaction costs and their disturbing role in forming policy decisions. In specific, we argue that the monetary policy affects the overall cost of traders not only by the variations to the quantity of money but also by the associated information cost. The argument is simple. As long as the price expectations of traders are affected by the quantity of money, any change will incur additional expenses to the traders for the market price revelation. Originally, the basic market mechanism is extended so as to incorporate, first inside money via credit provided by an outside Bank, and second information costs. The provision of credit by a Bank was first introduced by Shubik and Wilson (1977), and later used by Shubik and Tsomocos (1992) and Dubey and Geanakoplos (1992, 2000).Therefore, the role of the Bank is twofold; first the Bank has the exclusive authority to issue fiat money and second, it is responsible to provide credit to traders. Furthermore, the presence of the Bank has a prominent role for the existence of the monetary equilibrium, since it guarantees positive value for the fiat money. Regarding to the information cost, no attempt has been made to be modeled in detail, and for the ease of exposition it is imposed in a linear form. With some laborious manipulations we could let the information cost be convex. In addition, the model provides some useful insights for the effect of monetary policy on the transactions technology which is specifically associated to the information of traders. By comparative statics, we examine how the monetary policy affects the structural knowledge of traders (Kurz 1994a, b) when the traders have rational expectations and their beliefs are formed in a monotonic way. Both assumptions are demanding in the ability of traders to gather and process market information. On top of that it is not provided the process of learning by which the Rational Expectations equilibrium is attained. Kurz (1994a) suggested as alternative concept the rational belief equilibrium that may accommodate a non stationary element in the formation of beliefs, stemming from the forecast error of traders. This approach is less demanding in information and provides the dynamics where beliefs formation affects the equilibrium outcome. The emphasis on the market inefficiencies stemming from the market information makes rational beliefs, as in this model, consistent with an active role for the monetary policy. The paper is organised as follows. Section 2 provides some basic preliminary notation and definitions. Section 3 depicts the onetary model whereas Sect. 4 unfolds the information effect of monetary policy. Finally, Sect. 5 concludes.

Title: Can growth-enhanced monetary policy improve welfare when people seek social status?
Vertically related markets, tariffs, and technology adoption
Intro: Local companies in developing countries often use imported intermediate inputs in manufacturing the final output. These intermediate inputs are crucial in a sense that the production of final product is not possible without them. At the same time, the local companies could invest into the development of new technology that will allow the production of crucial intermediate inputs domestically. This paper explores how the governments of developing countries might use trade policy in order to stimulate new technology adoption in their countries. The vertically integrated markets were modelled by Spencer and Jones (1991, 1992) and Wang et al. (2011) among others. The typical setup is that vertically integrated foreign company supplies both intermediate and final goods to the home country. A tariff on final good imposed by home country induces foreign firm to supply intermediate good. Tariff on intermediate good causes the price of intermediate good to increase, according to Wang et al. (2011). According to Spencer and Jones (1992), the increase in the tariff imposed on final good causes the decrease in the price of intermediate good, when the foreign firm is integrated. Though the effect of increase in the tariff on final good is opposite in the case the foreign firm is not integrated. In modelling technology adoption, I follow Crowley (2006), which is based on Reinganum (1981) and Fudenberg and Tirole (1985). Crowley (2006) demonstrated that antidumping duty on imports of firms from country with positive technological shock leads to earlier technology adoption by both import-competing and exporting firms relative to the free trade case. At the same time, the safeguard tariff that is applied to both country with positive technological shock and country without that shock, accelerates the technology adoption by import competing firms in country imposing the tariff. While it slows down the technology adoption by exporting firms against which the tariff was introduced. Further, Mukunoki (2010) studied the effect of formation of PTA on the technology adoption in the setup of three countries among which one country has old technology. The main finding is that the formation of FTA between the country with old technology and the developed one speeds up the technology adoption and the realization of multilateral free trade. At the same time, the formation of CU between these countries delays the technology adoption and the realization of multilateral free trade. This paper combines the modeling of vertically integrated markets in line with Spencer and Jones (1991) with the technology adoption, which is done similar to Crowley (2006). The contribution of this paper is to analyze the factors influencing the timing of technology adoption in vertically integrated markets. The domestic firm is dependent on a foreign vertically integrated firm for supplies of a intermediate good before the technology adoption and can produce the intermediate good after the technology adoption. Tariff regulation influences the timing of technology adoption that, in turn, affects the country’s welfare. Initially, when the cost of technology adoption is significant, the optimal tariffs are the ones maximizing country’s instantaneous welfare. With the decline in the cost of technology adoption over time, the government should start to stimulate the technology adoption by the domestic firm. It is done through a lower tariff on imports of final good, which decreases the protection of domestic firm from foreign competitor. Also, the higher tariff on imports of intermediate good decreases the profit of domestic company and provides additional incentives for earlier technology adoption. The remainder of this paper includes: Sect. 2, which develops the model, and explores the properties of the equilibria before and after technology adoption; Sect. 3, which provides results on the timing of technology adoption and describes the underlying mechanisms behind stated results, and Sect. 4, which provides conclusions.

Title: Consumption taxes in monopolistic competition: a comment
Intro: Consumption taxes in the form of unit taxes or ad valorem taxes are frequently used means to produce revenue. In the sense that an ad valorem tax produces lower prices compared to an equal-revenue unit tax, this tax is the better choice of the two. Suits and Musgrave (1953) show this, in general, for the case of monopoly. Subsequently, Delipalla and Keen (1992) demonstrate the result in oligopoly. However, under perfect competition, there is no reason to prefer one of the two kinds of consumer taxes. With the exception of Schröder (2004), the two taxes have not been compared on an equal yield basis in monopolistic competition. It is of obvious interest, in theory and maybe even more practically, whether one can establish, under reasonable assumptions, that ad valorem taxes are better than unit taxes in monopolistic competition. On the other hand, when the superiority of ad valorem taxes can be traced back to one, or a few, crucial assumptions, these assumptions must surely be realistic.Footnote 1 Otherwise the implications will be met with some scepticism. I want to argue that this applies to Schröder’s result on taxes in monopolistic competition by showing how some key assumptions generate the results. Monopolistic competition has been discussed formally by Spence (1976) and Dixit and Stiglitz (1977). A common thread in these analyses is that consumers have a preference for product variety. In this regard, there is a set of products that are close but yet imperfect substitutes. Limited substitutability gives each firm some monopoly power but entry and exit drive profit to zero. Schröder applies the Dixit–Stiglitz model, but in a variant with two decisive characteristics. First, taxes will not affect the way income is distributed upon different sectors. Second, demand per variety has constant price elasticity, in turn resulting in mark-up pricing with a constant mark-up. As we explain, together with the zero profit restriction, this fully explains why ad valorem taxes are the better choice. We show that the price under ad valorem taxation is lower than the price under an equal-revenue unit tax whenever (1) firms use mark-up pricing with a constant mark-up, (2) firms pay a fixed cost independent of actual production, (3) entry and exit drive per-firm profit to zero, and (4) consumers spend some fixed proportion of income on taxed goods. Moreover, the result can be strengthened, allowing for positive non-decreasing marginal production costs. Our proposition on the superiority of ad valorem taxes encompasses in addition to standard Dixit–Stiglitz model of monopolistic completion also oligopoly. In this meaning Schröder’s results are not specific to monopolistic competition and they might not be robust in other types of monopolistic competition models.Footnote 2

Title: Agénor, Pierre-Richard: Public capital, growth and welfare. Analytical foundations for public policy
Selected Books Received
Intergenerational redistribution and risk sharing with changing longevity
Intro:
A significant upward trend in the age composition of the population (ageing) is a global phenomenon driven both by falling fertility and increasing longevity. It is widely known that these changes will have large consequences for public finances. It has become standard to assess the financial consequences in terms of fiscal sustainability (see e.g. European Commission 2009). Fiscal sustainability indicatorsFootnote 1 are based on projections for public expenditures and revenues, and thus the budget balance, given demographic projections, and yield the permanent change in the budget balance (in % of GDP) ensuring that the intertemporal budget constraint of the public sector is met. Since the demographic trend usually causes a downward trend in the budget balance, such calculations imply that fiscal sustainability is ensured by establishing sufficiently large budget surpluses for an initial period to finance deficits arising later.Footnote 2 This is sometimes denoted a consolidation or pre-savings strategy (see e.g. IMF 2004; European Commission 2006, 2009) since it implies that public finances are sufficiently consolidated to manage budget deteriorations in the future due to the changing demographic structure of the population. Such analyses build on the premise that welfare schemes are not strict PAYG-schemes. Differences between expenditures and revenues in a given period of time are possible as long as the intertemporal budget constraint is met. Via the budget balance (and therefore the debt level), there is effectively a transfer of resources over time and thus generations (see e.g. Gordon and Varian 1988). This raises important normative questions concerning the appropriate way of addressing changing demographics. This applies not least to changes in longevity, which implies that different cohorts have different circumstances and thus utility options.Footnote 3
 Computations of fiscal sustainability are often associated with normative statements on the needed policy changes. However, the sustainability indicator is a positive metric of the orders of magnitude based entirely on the intertemporal budget constraint, and therefore it does not have any immediate normative interpretation (see e.g. Andersen 2012). Often the consolidation strategy is motivated in terms of tax smoothing (Barro 1979). The argument being that tax distortions are minimized by keeping distorting tax rates constant letting variations in expenditures and revenues be absorbed via the budget balance. Applying this reasoning to the ageing problem requires a once and for all change in policy which immediately improves the budget and therefore implies pre-funding of demographic trends. While the tax smoothing argument per se is important, it does not follow that consolidation of trends driven by e.g. increasing longevity should be pre-funded. Having marginal tax rates constant across time and generations does not imply anything about the (net) tax burden which should rest on given generations. This paper takes a first step in addressing the normative question on intergenerational redistribution and risk sharing across cohorts with different options in terms of longevity. In a seminal paper Calvo and Obstfeld (1988) addressed intergenerational redistribution in an OLG model with an age dependent survival rate under a utilitarian criterion. They found that the optimal allocation entails consumption smoothing across generations; i.e. the same consumption level for all agents across age and time.Footnote 4 If there is heterogeneity in the population concerning survival rates, the utilitarian optimum implies redistribution from groups with high mortality (low longevity) to groups with low mortality (high longevity), cf. Sheshinski (2006). A similar mechanism is at stake when different generations have different longevity (Auerbach and Hassett 2002, 2007). In the empirically relevant case of a trend increase in longevity (see Christensen et al. 2009 and Oeppen and Vaupel 2002), this line of reasoning supports pre-saving or consolidation to ensure consumption smoothing across generations. This implies redistribution from current generations with short longevity to future generations with longer longevity. However, in the above mentioned work retirement is not endogenized. It is a restrictive (implicit) assumption to take the retirement age to be exogenous when longevity changes. In modelling retirement this paper builds on a tradition based on Crawford and Lilien (1981). Retirement is modelled as a labour supply decision on the extensive margin involving a trade-off between the consumption possibilities generated by postponing retirement and the utility gain from more leisure upon retirement. In a setting where longevity is allowed to change, the assumptions made about the age dependent disutility from work are crucial. A key issue is whether increases in longevity are adding more healthy years to life (see e.g. OECD 2006) as there is support for.Footnote 5 Healthy ageing makes it possible to retire later without necessarily incurring higher disutility from work, and a specification in accordance with healthy ageing is adopted in this paper. Addressing the problem of distribution and risk sharing across generations with different longevity raises a difficult modelling problem. A comparison of (steady-state) allocations under different longevity (survival functions) assumptions is not capturing the problem that there is redistribution across different cohorts with different longevity. Analysing this problem easily becomes rather complicated. This paper presents a simple workhorse model to analyse this problem.Footnote 6 The model is a simple extension of the basic two-period OLG model allowing for varying longevity across generations and endogenous retirement. It is shown that retirement plays a crucial role when longevity is increasing. It is well known from the literature that a utilitarian planner aims at consumption smoothing based on the marginal utility of consumption. A trend increase in longevity implies a larger consumption need tending to increase the marginal utility of consumption. However, it also affects the scope for working, and under a notion of healthy ageing it is shown that the social optimum also has work smoothing in the sense that the relative retirement age is constant (the deterministic case) across generations. This is crucial for the extent of redistribution taking place since cohorts with longer longevity have larger consumption needs, they are also going to work longer, and therefore in part contributing to the financing of this larger consumption need. However, it is shown that a constant relative retirement age is not sufficient to imply that intergenerational redistribution remains unaffected by trend changes in longevity. In the case of a trend increase in longevity, a utilitarian planner will front-load some financing (pre-saving) to be capable of achieving the desired consumption and work smoothing. Stochastic cohort-specific longevity raises the issue of intergenerational risk sharing, which in general goes in the same direction as life annuities; that is, cohorts turning out to have a high longevity are compensated at the expense of cohorts turning out to have a relatively short longevity. It is shown that it is possible to separate intergenerational redistribution and risk sharing by making the cohort-specific retirement age dependent on expected longevity. This paper focuses on longevity, savings, retirement and social security. Therefore, a number of simplifying assumptions are made to highlight the role of longevity. This includes exogenous changes in longevity,Footnote 7 a constant marginal product of labour (deterministic) and a small open economy assumption implying an exogenous interest rate (making it possible to disregard feedbacks to rates of return and the capital stock). The paper is organized as follows: Sect. 2 sets up the overlapping generations model with different and stochastic life expectancy for different generations and endogenous retirement. The social optimal allocation across generations is considered in Sect. 3. Issues of intergenerational distribution and risk sharing are addressed in Sects. 4 and 5, respectively. Section 6 offers a few conclusions.

Title: Optimal size of the government: the role of the elasticity of substitution
Intro: In his seminal work Barro 1990 introduced the flow of government expenditure, which is financed by a distortionary income tax, as a productive input to private production. Thus, public policy has two opposite effects on growth which, under Cobb–Douglas technology, offset each other if the tax rate on income is equal to the elasticity of public spending in production. Furthermore, this growth-maximizing tax rate also maximizes intertemporal utility in a second-best sense. The empirical literature, however, provides evidence against the unitary elasticity of substitution implicit in the Cobb–Douglas specification, and in favor of a more general constant-elasticity-of-substitution (CES) specification (e.g., Klump et al. 2007; León-Ledesma et al. 2010). The departure from the assumption of a unitary elasticity of substitution has important consequences on many issues in growth theory as, among others, the level of macroeconomic variables and the growth rate (Klump and De La Grandville 2000; Irmen and Klump 2009; Xue and Yip 2012), the existence of endogenous growth (Palivos and Karagiannis 2010), the effect of biased technical change (Blanchard 1997), multiple equilibria (Azariadis 1996), (in)determinacy of equilibria (Guo and Lansing 2009; Wong and Yip 2010), the speed of convergence (Turnovsky 2002), or the dynamics of the saving rate (Gómez 2008a). This paper adds to this literature by analyzing the implications on the optimal fiscal policy of assuming a non-unitary elasticity of substitution in the (Barro 1990) model of endogenous growth with productive public services. As Barro and Sala-i-Martin (1992) argue, almost all public services are subject to some degree of congestion, so that the pure public good should be viewed as only a benchmark. Hence, following Turnovsky (1996, 1997), we allow for different degrees of congestion in public services (see also, e.g., Eicher and Turnovsky 2000; Gómez 2008b). First, we analyze the equilibrium dynamics of the decentralized economy. Next, we characterize the first-best outcome that a benevolent central planner would implement. Then, we study the tax rate on income that maximizes long-run growth and the one that maximizes the representative agent’s utility—i.e., the second-best solution—in the market economy, and compare them with the first-best solution. Our main result is that the interplay of assuming a non-unitary elasticity of substitution and allowing for different degrees of congestion has significant consequences on the optimal fiscal policy. The standard (Barro 1990) result on the equality between the growth-maximizing, welfare-maximizing and first-best income taxes holds if and only if production is Cobb–Douglas or there is proportional congestion. If congestion is non-proportional—or in the absence of congestion—the first-best income tax is lower (greater) than the second-best welfare-maximizing and the growth-maximizing income taxes if the elasticity of substitution is below (above) unity. Furthermore, if the elasticity of substitution is below unity we show that the welfare-maximizing income tax is lower than the growth-maximizing tax rate. This relation is reversed, under mild conditions—e.g., in the absence of congestion—if the elasticity of substitution is above unity. The first-best solution can be decentralized as a market equilibrium only in the presence of proportional congestion, when the second-best outcome coincides with the first-best solution. Otherwise, the first-best solution cannot be decentralized, and the first-best long-run growth rate is greater than the maximum long-run growth rate attainable in the decentralized economy. Intuitively, income taxation has two opposite effects on growth. On the one hand, it lowers growth because it reduces the private marginal return to capital which discourages private investment. On the other hand, the public services provided stimulate growth. The individual agent ignores the externality caused by congestion which would lead to over-accumulation of capital. If congestion is proportional the negative effect of the income tax exactly offsets the effect of the externality and, therefore, the growth-maximizing income tax is equal to the first-best income tax. However, with a lower degree of congestion—or without congestion—the negative growth effect of the income tax dominates, and the first-best income tax is no longer optimal for growth-maximizing in the market economy. If capital and public services are substitutes, reducing public services will result in individual agents increasing the stock of capital. Hence, the individual agent can partly avoid the negative net effect of taxation by substituting away from public services. Thus, the growth-maximizing government size would be lesser than the first-best one. If capital and public services are complements, an increase in public services may lead to more capital accumulation. Hence, the growth-maximizing government size would be greater than the first-best one. In the borderline Cobb–Douglas case, the growth-maximizing and the first-best income tax rates coincide. Given that the second-best welfare-maximizing income tax has to balance the effect on the long-run growth rate and the effect on initial consumption, it will generally lie between the first-best and the growth-maximizing tax rates. Related work has been made by Devarajan et al. (1996) and Ghosh and Gregoriou (2008), but they have only analyzed the welfare-maximizing solution. Recently, Misch et al. (2012) studied the relationship between the welfare- and growth-maximizing solutions in a variety of models with productive services.Footnote 1 However, they do not obtain general analytical results for the CES specification and must rely instead on numerical simulations. In addition, all of these works consider the simplest case in which public services are subject to proportional relative congestion and, as we show, allowing for different degrees of congestion has crucial implications. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents the model. Section 3 studies the first-best solution attainable by a social planner. Section 4 analyzes the growth- and welfare-maximizing income tax and compares them with the first-best solution. Section 5 concludes.

Title: Coalitional fairness in interim differential information economies
Intro: The problem of a fair distribution of resources among agents has been widely investigated and many notions of fair allocation have been adopted to evaluate equity. Since Foley (1967), one of the most extensively studied concept has been the one according to which an allocation is fair if it is envy-free and efficient. Under an analysis conducted on the individualistic level, an allocation is said to be envy-free if each individual prefers to keep his bundle rather than to receive the bundle of another agent. It is known that in a pure exchange economy, fair allocations always exist (see Theorem 2.3 in Varian 1974). This is so, simply because any competitive allocation, resulting from an equal sharing of the total initial endowment, is fair. This result has been generalized in Svensson (1983). On the other hand, when production is allowed, envy-freeness may be incompatible with efficiency and therefore the set of fair allocations may be empty. The same problem arises when agents are asymmetrically informed at the time of contracting. Recent papers by de Clippel (2008), Gajdos and Tallon (2002), exhibit the tension between the concepts of envy-freeness and efficiency in models that explicitly encompass uncertainty. The incompatibility may occur if the allocation is judged before or after the realization of uncertainty, as well as according to an interim stage evaluation. Stronger notions of equity require that bundle comparisons are allowed between groups of agents according to a coalitional envy concept. This approach is introduced by Varian (1974), (see also Vind 1971) and, on a slightly different base, by Gabszewicz (1975). An allocation is coalitional fair (briefly c-fair), if no coalition envies the aggregate bundle, and this is Varian’s definition, or, and this is Gabszewicz’s approach, the net trade of another coalition. In both cases, differently from individual fairness, the efficiency is implicitly satisfied and the existence is guaranteed under standard assumptions. Moreover, despite of differences due to technical requirements about the measures of potentially envious coalitions, c-fair allocations introduced in both papers provide a complete characterization of competitive market equilibria (see also Yannelis 1985; Zhou 1992, for analogous results). The aim of this paper is to identify Gabszewicz’s coalitional fairness notion as a suitable criterion to evaluate allocations on an equitable basis when agents are asymmetrically informed. As in Wilson (1978), we assume that the true state of nature is commonly known at the time of implementing the contracts, focusing on interim fairness notions. The straightforward extension to differential information economies of the c-fairness criterion introduced by Varian cannot serve the same purpose since, when uncertainty is involved and agents are asymmetrically informed, a fair allocation (and, a fortiori, a c-fair one) may not exist, as shown by de Clippel (2008). Therefore, we extend to our context the coalitional fairness notion introduced by Gabszewicz (1975), so that an allocation is qualified c-fair if it is not possible to find an alternative allocation such that in each state of nature a coalition of agents can redistribute among its members the net trade of a disjoint coalition and each of them, using his own private information, is better off. Our main result shows that this set of c-fair allocations is non-empty. We do it by proving that c-fair allocations of a differential information economy correspond to c-fair allocations of an auxiliary Arrow-Debreu exchange economy with uncertainty and symmetric information. Agents of the auxiliary economy are defined by adapting the idea used by Harsanyi (1967–1968) to define Bayesian games. A type-agent is a couple \((t, E)\), where \(t\) is an agent and \(E\) is an event of his information partition. The future state of the fictitious economy is uncertain, but each type-agent has no private information. Moreover, since contracts are contingent on the future state of the economy, standard Arrow-Debreu equilibrium notions can be applied. We adapt this representation in the framework of mixed markets and prove that there is a natural correspondence between the original and the auxiliary economy, which preserves c-fair allocations and constrained market equilibria. This allows us to conclude that the set of c-fair allocations is non-empty, since it contains the set of constrained market equilibria. In general, this inclusion may be strict, and it becomes an equivalence under additional assumptions. The paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2 we present the model, describe main ideas and state our results. Proofs are collected in the final section.

Title: Voting in small committees
Geisst, Charles R.: Beggar thy neighbor. A history of usury and debt
Bokros, Lajos: Accidental occidental. Economics and culture of transition in Mitteleuropa, the Baltic and the Balkan Area
Regulating a manager whose empire-building preferences are private information
Informal incentive labour contracts and product market competition
On the value of partial commitment for cooperative investment in buyer–supplier relationship
Intro:
A growing range of production activities is now subcontracted. Firms split their production process and outsource activities, from product design to assembly. This split expands vertical inter-firm relationships and trade in customized parts. In such vertical relationships, the “hold-up problem” appears to be crucial (Klein et al. 1978). The canonical example goes as follows. A buyer commissions a supplier to produce a tailor-made input. Either the supplier or both the buyer and the supplier make ex ante non-contractible and relationship-specific investments to transact. At the (re)negotiation stage, investors are locked into the relationship and risk not receiving ex post the overall return of their autonomous investments. Two potential economic inefficiencies result from the hold-up problem. The investors may under-invest in specific assets (Grossman and Hart 1986) and/or waste resources to protect her investment returns. Following the classification introduced in Che and Hausch (1999), autonomous specific investments can be either ‘selfish’, when they generate a direct benefit only for the investor, ‘purely cooperative’, when the direct benefit only goes to the partner of the investor, or ‘hybrid’, when it offers direct benefits to both parties. A first stream of the literature concentrates on selfish investments and shows that simple renegotiable fixed-price contracts can solve the hold-up problem (Chung 1991; Aghion et al. 1994; Edlin and Reichelstein 1995, 1996; Nöldeke 1995).Footnote 1
Che and Hausch (1999) concentrate on purely cooperative and hybrid investments. They show that with purely cooperative investments contracting has value only if the parties can commit not to renegotiate, while renegotiable contracts offer no advantage over a simple ex post negotiation. They also show that renegotiable contracts can be valuable when investments are hybrid. In all the literature we have referred to investments are autonomous, i.e., each party decides independently from the other and one party’s investment has effect even if the other decides not to invest. In this paper we study the value of partial commitment to solve the hold-up problem for joint investments. Joint investments require an explicit cooperation between the parties: one party investment generates benefits only if the other party also invests, so that investments are complementary. In that setting, we show that with joint investments renegotiable contracts are always potentially valuable, but never able to restore first best incentives for both parties. This result echoes the hybrid case of Che and Hausch where a simple contract is also potentially valuable without restoring first best incentives. However, the setting is different. They coined as purely cooperative or partly cooperative (i.e., hybrid) investments that are autonomous.Footnote 2 Thus, a restriction of the Che and Hausch’s investments lies in their lack of joint work. In our setting, firms cooperate in the sense that their investments are complementary. Considering joint investments may help to understand how cooperation emerges in Japanese procurement practices. Our framework roughly fits some stylized facts about the Japanese buyer–supplier relationships. First, parties trade in customized parts, which require autonomous and joint relationship-specific investments [see among others Asanuma (1985a, b), Asanuma (1989); Aoki (1988), Nishiguchi (1994), Qiu and Spencer (2002) and Spencer and Qiu (2001)]. As an example of joint investments, Japanese car manufacturers cooperate with suppliers to design parts of the final product.Footnote 3 They coordinate tasks, share information and meet each other. This cooperation is typically linked to joint investments, which are the source of productivity improvements over time. Second, Japanese practices tend to differ from American ones in key areas such as quality control and price determination. However, characterizing Japanese arrangements as informal and cooperative and Western arrangements as formal and antagonistic is a coarse generalization. In fact, the difference is blurred, as Western firms have adopted many Japanese practices [see e.g Cusumano and Takeishi (1991)], while Japanese firms contract with their partners (Asanuma 1985a, b, Nishiguchi 1994). Based on a survey of automobile manufacturers, Cusumano and Takeishi (1991) provide evidence of the contractual nature of the Japanese buyer–supplier relationships. They find that, for each new model of car, parties sign a new contract. “The most common contract (62 % of the sample) is 4 years, corresponding to the average model life-cycle” (Cusumano and Takeishi 1991). Given that the average total duration of a Japanese buyer–supplier relationship is about ten years, this means that parties sign up to three different contracts by relationship. Third, these contractual arrangements provide room for renegotiation. Parties write basic renegotiable contracts establishing basic rules covering a range of items including price determination, payment, delivery, property rights, the supply of materials and quality issues (Nishiguchi 1994). Finally, these contractual arrangements also promote cooperation. The typical contract sets a target price for each input produced. Buyers then cooperate and help suppliers to reach their targets (Cusumano and Takeishi 1991; see also Nishiguchi 1994). Therefore, overall Japanese firms seem to rely on partial commitment to their relationships and ex post bargaining to promote cooperation and joint investments. Our result also echoes the literature on the value of partial commitment devices in other strategic and decision-theoretic environments. For instance, Colombo and Merzoni (2006, 2008) stress the value of partial commitment to a relationship in terms of the duration of contracts, while Amador et al. (2006) show the value of commitment devices that partially limit the freedom of choice with time-inconsistent preferences. Our contribution is also related to McLaren (1999), who distinguishes joint from autonomous investments. However, the latter are assumed to be not relationship specific. This implies parties can pay an additional fee to adapt the tailor-made input to an alternative buyer. Under this assumption, a non-renegotiable fixed-price contract gives optimal incentives for autonomous investments, but not for joint work. Ex post bargaining is thus required to foster cooperation, as the supplier can always get the buyer to share the costs ex post. We assume instead that autonomous investments are relationship-specific and we find that a fixed-price contract is valuable to promote cooperation.Footnote 4 However, this result is not necessarily in conflict with McLaren (1999). In fact, in both settings, the possibility of bargaining ex post fosters cooperation: although the present setting underlines the value of contracting as partial commitment, contract incompleteness leaves room for renegotiation.Footnote 5
 The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In the next section, we present the model, a simple two-stage game between a buyer and a supplier. In Sect. 3, we establish two benchmark outcomes to compare our results: the first-best and the ex post bargaining (without an initial contract). In Sect. 4, we show how a formal fixed-price contract arrangement may foster cooperation. Finally, in Sect. 5, we conclude.

Title: Insider trading with product differentiation
Tangian, Andranik: Mathematical theory of democracy. Studies in social choice and welfare
Manski, Charles: Public policy in an uncertain world
Partial ownership and cross-border mergers
Intro:
This paper explains partial ownership by information asymmetries. The model applies to both vertical and horizontal cross-border mergers: A foreign firm considering an acquisition of a local firm does not know the productivity of the potential target, because it is private information of the target firm. The productivity of the target determines the scope of merger gains. If the foreign firm specified only the acquisition price, it would suffer from the lemons problem: unless the acquisition price is very high, only the low productivities will accept, but the high productivities will reject. Hence, the firm would discriminate against high productivities if foreign ownership has to be complete. Alternatively, the merger proposal could be made dependent on the future performance of the target, like future output. However, takeover contracts based on future performance are rare, and the reason is the limited liability of the previous owner. Since the future profitability of a target may be uncertain, it is sensible to assume that a previous owner cannot be held responsible for after merger losses so foreign firms cannot claim a part of the acquisition price back if their expectations are not met. But if performance-related contracts cannot be written, the foreign firm may still use partial ownership as a screening device. A productive target can be expected to accept a high share of after merger profits as a compensation for accepting partial ownership of the foreign firm even if the sales price for foreign partial ownership is not large. Conversely, a less productive target will not accept this offer, as it correctly anticipates that after merger profits will be small. Hence, leaving a part of the future after merger profit to the target may qualify for a proper screening scheme. The background of this paper is that cross-border mergers have become a hotly debated issue since countries have experienced several merger waves. The World Investment Report estimates a value of US$ 297 billion of cross-border mergers and acquisitions in 2003, compared to US$ 151 billion in 1990 (see UNCTAD 2004). It is not only this substantial figure but also the size of individual mergers which makes this foreign direct investment (FDI) mode important. For example, the largest single FDI inflow to Germany was by far the takeover of Mannesmann Mobilfunk, a local cellphone company, by British Vodaphone in 2000.Footnote 1 The substantial share of cross-border mergers in FDI demonstrates that combining assets across countries has been expected to lead to large expected merger gains.Footnote 2 However, not all mergers are success stories, and even substantial merger losses do happen from time to time,Footnote 3 demonstrating that a foreign firm does not always know the size of after merger gains when specifying the merger proposal. The obvious reason is asymmetric information between a foreign firm and a local target, and this is the first starting-point of this analysis. The second starting-point is the observation that mergers do not necessarily imply a complete takeover by the foreign firm. For example, Asiedu and Esfahani (2001) show that the degree of foreign equity participation rises with foreign assets. Partial ownership is a universal feature of FDI in general and mergers in particular, meaning that mergers are not equivalent to complete takeovers. Furthermore, information asymmetries are found to be most important when it comes to cross-border merger activities and if these activities affect private instead of publicly listed targets. Several empirical papers like Martynova and Renneborg (2006) have demonstrated that partial ownership is universal in mergers. López Duarte and García-Canal (2004) and Garcia et al. (2002) demonstrate the importance of partial acquisition strategies for Spanish multinational firms as a response to information asymmetries. Shen and Reuer (2005) demonstrate that, ceteris paribus, private targets are less preferred compared to public firms because they offer less information on assets. Desai et al. (2004) investigate the determinants of partial ownership of foreign affiliates of U.S. firms. Henceforth, our analysis is primarily geared towards the case of a foreign firm which wants to merge with a private target whose shares are concentrated in the hands of a few or a single owner and are not diversified.Footnote 4
 In summary, our model discusses how partial ownership as a screening device may solve the problem.Footnote 5 The innovation of the paper is that a share agreement is scrutinized in a principal-agent framework which may allow the principal (i.e. the foreign firm) to capture the whole surplus. If the principal cannot capture the whole surplus, we arrive at the interesting result that partial ownership leads to discrimination against intermediate productivities, if at all. In both cases, ownership is endogenous, and the endogenous ownership share is always different from zero and one.Footnote 6 After having discussed the implications of the basic model, we will demonstrate how our model extends to the case that the foreign firm negotiates simultaneously with all potential target firms. This is not the first paper dealing with cross-border mergers. The international economics literature has mainly dealt with the impact of mergers on international trade patterns. Barros and Cabral (1994) and Horn and Levinsohn (2001) discuss the impact of trade policies on mergers. Neary (2007) discusses the role of mergers as a result of comparative advantages in a general equilibrium setting. Horn and Persson (2001) determine the equilibrium ownership of firms by a cooperative approach of coalition formation. Qiu and Zhou (2006) discuss the effects of information sharing and/or output coordination on the performance of an international merger. Other papers have dealt with mergers as a certain mode of foreign direct investment and compare the merger incentive with greenfield investment or the incentive to form a joint venture (see Bjorvatn 2004; Chowdhury and Chowdhury 2001; Das 1999; Raff et al. 2012). Kabiraj and Chaudhuri (1999) compare the welfare effects of domestic and cross-border mergers under different assumptions on market structures. There is also an extensive literature on cross-border joint ventures, pronouncing that shared ownership in joint ventures is important if the joint venture is subject to moral hazard and adverse selection (Balakrishnan and Koza 1993; Chi 1996), if agency costs increase in the foreign share of a joint venture (Nakamura and Yeung 1994) or if foreign intangible assets are substantial (Nakamura and Xie 1998).Footnote 7 The difference from this paper is that those papers do not consider different degrees of partial ownership whereas this paper will endogenize the degree of partial ownership.Footnote 8 Konrad and Lommerud (2001) and Fuest (2005) have endogenized ownership as a means of a multinational firm to alleviate a hold-up problem and to reduce the burden of corporate taxation, respectively.Footnote 9
 Mergers have also received a lot of attention in the finance literature. One strand of this literature has dealt with the division of merger gains after a profitable target has been identified by an investor.Footnote 10 Another strand of this literature has dealt with the optimal behavior of potential investors before a merger might be found profitable.Footnote 11 This literature thus emphasizes the strategic effects of partial ownership during and before merger negotiations take place. Furthermore, numerous papers have emphasized the crucial role information asymmetries play for the method of payment in a merger deal.Footnote 12 These papers either deal with the case of an uninformed seller not exactly knowing the value of an equity offer or with the case of two-sided information asymmetries. They focus on the type of payment (cash versus equity). Partial ownership is not considered as endogenous, and is not a strategic variable in merger negotiations as this paper will show.Footnote 13
 Our model has some features in common with share contracts (see Bhattacharyya and Lafontaine 1995; Canjels et al. 2001; Dai 2004, and for a general treatment of wealth-constrained agents, see Lewis and Sappington 2000a). The difference is that share contracts assume a binding wealth constraint for the partner who is (still) carrying out future actions, whereas our model considers a target whose owner will not take any independent future action once the merger deal is done. The basic model is closest to Hviid and Prendergast (1993) who also consider a target with private information and a merger proposal as a take it or leave it offer. The difference is that both firms are already rivals in a market, so the market performance can be given by a Bayesian equilibrium. A rejected proposal signals a high profitability of the target and increases the target’s profit and decreases bidder’s profit. In our model, the foreign firm is a newcomer to the local market, and to our knowledge only one paper has dealt with partial ownership as a screening device in a share model of adverse selection. Raff et al. (2009) discuss why multinational firms often share ownership of a foreign affiliate with a local partner. Their model predicts that the multinational’s ownership share is increasing in its productivity, and they show that their results are consistent with data on the ownership choices of Japanese multinationals. Their analysis assumes the existence of a separating equilibrium whereas this paper will scrutinize the existence and characteristics of both pooling and separating equilibria. This paper thus focusses on the role of incomplete information as the only market imperfection. Other imperfections like financial constraints, incomplete contracts and capital market imperfections could also give rise to partial ownership, as could governmental restrictions. We see our approach complementary to these possible explanations but it seems that asymmetric information could play a more important role in particular for cross-border mergers. The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the model, and Sect. 3 determines the equilibrium offer of the foreign firm. It also demonstrates that the results are similar if the foreign firm negotiates with all potential target firms simultaneously. Section 4 presents two examples for a horizontal merger in a Cournot market, and Sect. 5 concludes the paper. For convenience, technical details and proofs have been relegated to the appendix.

Title: Complementing Cournot’s analysis of complements: unidirectional complementarity and mergers
Intro: Mergers and acquisitions in the information technology (IT) industry often attract media attention. For example, it was reported Footnote 1 on February 24, 2012, that Apple acquired Chomp, a company that produced a search engine (application software or an “app”) compatible with Apple’s iPhone (a brand name for Apple’s smartphone). According to Cournot’s (1838) analysis, a merger of two companies that produce complementary goods coordinates (or “internalizes”) pricing decisions that are otherwise made independently, resulting in a lower price of the composite good [see e.g., Varian (2010), Chapter 35]. A merger makes all players happier: the lower price unambiguously enhances consumer welfare, and the merged firm’s profits are higher than the sum of the two firms’ profits. An important point that is missing in Cournot’s (1838) analysis is that, in the example above, the two products are “unidirectional” complements rather than strict complements. In the cases of strict complements (such as CPUs and OSs, printers and toner cartridges, etc.), each product is indispensable: one product is useless without another. However, Chomp’s search engine is useless unless it is used together with an iPhone, not vice versa. In fact, product complements often have unidirectional relationships. Other examples outside of the IT industry include cars and GPS car navigation systems, cable TVs and accompanying optional channels, and so on. It is not straightforward to obtain the same implication as Cournot’s (1838) when evaluating mergers of firms of unidirectional complements. The aim of this paper is thus to study Cournot’s (1838) old question in the cases of unidirectional complements. In considering unidirectional complements, it is important to take into account explicitly that not all consumers choose to consume a composite good or nothing. This is because if all consumers do so, the situation is no different from the demand of a composite good of strict complements in Cournot’s (1838) analysis. Thus, in studying unidirectional complements in a model à la Cournot (1838), one needs to introduce consumers who are satisfied with the use of iPhones only. In this paper, we study the effects of a merger of two monopolists of unidirectional complements: one firm producing a base good, and another firm producing an optional good. We assume two monopolies to contrast our analysis with Cournot’s (1838).Footnote 2 Following the necessity described above, we assume that there are two types of consumers: (i) those who consume one unit of the base good only (having zero valuation of the optional good), and (ii) those who consume one unit of the composite. It is shown that a merger of the two firms raises the price of the base good, resulting in lower consumer surplus for the group of those who purchase a base good only, if and only if the average willingness to pay of the group of consumers purchasing a composite good (or nothing) is sufficiently low. This result is in sharp contrast to Cournot’s (1838) classical implication that a merger of firms producing strict complements makes all consumers strictly better off. The paper is organized as follows. After reviewing the related literature in the next section, we present the model in Sect. 3. Section 4 then studies the price and welfare effects of the merger of firms producing unidirectional complements. Finally, Sect. 5 concludes.

Title: Outsourcing versus technology transfer: Hotelling meets Stackelberg
Intro: In this era of globalization it has become increasingly common for firms to outsource their required inputs rather than produce them in-house. While many factors influence a firm’s decision to outsource, it can be argued that outsourcing is primarily driven by cost considerations.Footnote 1 A firm will choose to outsource if the input supplier can offer a price that is lower than the firm’s in-house cost. This will be the case if the supplier has a cost advantage in one or more factors of production. Such advantages can be interpreted broadly as the supplier having a superior production technology. For example, the supplier may be able to hire skilled labor at a relatively low wage or it may possess advanced machineries. It is therefore plausible that as a mode of production, transfer of technology across firms could be an alternative to outsourcing. In fact, like outsourcing, technology transfers have also grown substantially in recent years.Footnote 2 As outsourcing and technology transfer serve the same purpose of enabling one firm to use the cost-efficient production process of another firm, a natural question is, what would make firms choose one of these contracts over another? A closely related question is, what are the relative effects of these contracts on the consumers? This paper seeks to address these questions in the context of imperfectly competitive markets. There could be different possible reasons for firms to prefer outsourcing over technology transfer. For instance, the superior technology may be labor intensive and difficult to transfer due to imperfect mobility of labor. Additionally, transfer of technology may involve other barriers such as intellectual property rights laws or large initial investments that firms may want to avoid. On the other hand, technology transfer enables a firm to produce its inputs in-house using the superior technology which gives it complete control over its production. So a firm may prefer technology transfer to maintain a higher quality standard or to avoid the risk of relying on an external supplier for its inputs. Apart from these reasons, strategic considerations play an important role in determining the nature of input production decisions of firms. Such considerations are particularly dominant when an input-seeking firm competes with its supplier in the final good market. Exploring the differences in the strategic aspects of outsourcing and technology transfer contracts in duopolies, this paper characterizes situations where firms would adopt one of these contracts over the other. We also study the consequences of these contract choices on consumers. We carry out our analysis in a Hotelling duopoly model with two firms \(A\) and \(B\) who are locatedFootnote 3 at two different end points of the unit interval in the final good market \(\varphi .\) Consumers are uniformly distributed in this interval and incur linear transportation costs for traveling to the end points. Any consumer buys at most one unit of \(\varphi \) from either \(A\) or \(B.\) We consider a production process where an intermediate good \(\eta \) is required to manufacture \(\varphi .\) Each firm can convert one unit of good \(\eta \) into one unit of good \(\varphi \) at zero cost. Both \(A\) and \(B\) can produce \(\eta ,\) but firm \(B\) has a lower cost due to a superior technology. Outsourcing (firm \(A\) orders \(\eta \) from firm \(B\)) and technology transfer (firm \(B\) transfers its technology to firm \(A\)) are two contracts that naturally arise in this situation. We study these contracts by considering unit-based pricing policies for both cases, where the unit price is determined through negotiations between firms \(A\) and \(B.\) Under an outsourcing contract, firm \(A\) can place any order with firm \(B\) at the agreed upon price. Under a technology transfer contract, firm \(A\) uses the superior technology of firm \(B\) by paying a price for each unit of production, i.e., the technology transfer contract is based on a unit royalty.Footnote 4 We denote \(\omega \) to be the effective unit cost of firm \(A\) in any contract and compare these contracts by fixing \(\omega .\) We show that these two contracts generate different strategic interactions between firms and consequently result in different prices in the final good market. Specifically we show that compared to the case of no contracts, prices in the final good market never rise under outsourcing (Proposition 2) while this is not necessarily the case under technology transfer. There are always weakly Pareto improving outsourcing contracts that make both firms better off and no consumers worse off compared to the situation of no contracts. Moreover if the cost difference of firms is sufficiently large (i.e., firm \(B\)’s technology is sufficiently superior), there are strictly Pareto improving outsourcing contracts that make both firms as well as all consumers better off compared to the case of no contracts (Proposition 3). On the other hand, there are no Pareto improving technology transfer contracts: whenever both firms prefer technology transfer over no contracts, there are always some consumers who pay a price in the final good market that is higher than what they paid in the absence of either contracts (Proposition 4). Comparing outsourcing and technology transfer contracts by fixing \(\omega \) (the effective unit cost of \(\eta \) for firm \(A\)), it is shown that there is a conflict between the incentives of firms and the interest of consumers. For any \(\omega ,\) (i) if both firms prefer outsourcing over technology transfer, there are always some consumers who prefer technology transfer over outsourcing and (ii) if both firms prefer technology transfer over outsourcing, there are always some consumers who prefer outsourcing over technology transfer (Proposition 5). It is also shown that if the supplier firm \(B\) has a relatively large bargaining power in negotiating the terms of a contract, then both firms prefer technology transfer while all consumers prefer outsourcing (Proposition 6). An outsourcing order from \(A\) to \(B\) is equivalent to an endogenous capacity building by \(A\) prior to competition in the final good market. As firm \(A\)’s capacity is in effect built by its rival firm \(B,\) the volume of this endogenous capacity plays an interesting role of information transmission. It credibly informs \(B\) that \(A\) is committed to maintain a specific market share, which establishes \(A\) as the Stackelberg leader in the final good market.Footnote 5 This is where Hotelling meets Stackelberg. The Stackelberg leadership effect generated by the outsourcing contract is the novel feature of our model. Wauthy (1996) and Boccard and Wauthy (2005) also study the role of capacities in the Hotelling location model, but they consider exogenous capacities. Capacity is endogenous in the well-known model of Kreps and Scheinkman (1983) [KS]. However, firms choose their capacities independently in KS, so unlike our model there is no prior information transmission. As capacities are either exogenous or independently chosen by firms, the Stackelberg leadership effect is absent in these papers. To see the impact of Stackelberg leadership, observe that when the contracted unit price \(\omega \) of the intermediate good \(\eta \) is small, the Stackelberg leader’s market share is larger than \(A\)’s market share under no contracts. This large share is sustained in equilibrium by a lower price of firm \(A\) in the final good market \(\varphi .\) Given that \(A\)’s commitment of Stackelberg market share is credible, \(B\)’s equilibrium price is also set lower and prices of both firms fall. This results in lower profit in the market \(\varphi \) for firm \(B.\) So \(B\) would accept such an outsourcing contract only if it can obtain a large supplier profit from \(\eta \) to compensate for its losses in the market \(\varphi .\) This happens when firm \(B\) is sufficiently more efficient compared to firm \(A.\) The upshot is that when the cost difference of two firms is sufficiently large, there are strictly Pareto improving outsourcing contracts: both firms prefer outsourcing over no contracts and both set a lower price for \(\varphi \) that makes all consumers better off [Proposition 3(I)(a)]. Under technology transfer, firm \(A\) acquires \(B\)’s superior technology and produces \(\eta \) itself using this technology. As a result, firm \(B\) knows the quantity of \(\eta \) produced by \(A\) only when it receives its payments for technology transfer. As these payments are received after profits are realized in the final good market, the informational aspect in outsourcing is completely absent under technology transfer. Moreover since firm \(B\)’s payments from the transfer depends on the demand of \(A,\) it has an incentive to ensure that \(A\)’s demand is not too small. This creates a distortion that raises the effective cost of \(B\) which in turn adversely affects prices in the market \(\varphi .\) Due to this distortion, technology transfer contracts that are preferred by both firms necessarily make some consumers worse off. Consequently, unlike the case of outsourcing, there are no Pareto improving technology transfer contracts in relation to the situation of no contracts [Proposition 4(III)(c)]. It should be mentioned that the distortive effect of royalty contracts is well known in the literature. Our analysis is closely related to Matsumura et al. (2010) who also consider technology transfer among firms in a Hotelling model. However, they focus on optimal contracts from the viewpoint of the efficient firm, while our objective is to characterize the market outcomes for all values of \(\omega \) and compare these with the corresponding outcomes under outsourcing. To sum up, the difference between outsourcing and technology transfer in our model is driven by two factors: first, the information transmission and the subsequent Stackelberg leadership effect that leads to lower prices under outsourcing is absent under technology transfer, and second, outsourcing orders are obtained upfront before firms set their prices, so outsourcing has no distortive effect. The paper is organized as follows. The related literature is discussed in Sect. 2. We present the model in Sect. 3. Three contractual settings—no contracts, outsourcing and technology transfer, are studied in Sect. 4. Comparison of outsourcing and technology transfer contracts is carried out in Sect. 5. We conclude in Sect. 6. For the proofs of most of the results, we refer the reader to the Appendix of the working paper version of the paper Pierce and Sen (2012).

Title: Licensing under convex costs
Gesell, Silvio: Establishing a natural economic order through free-land and free money
Clark, Gordon L., Dixon, Adam D. and Monk, Ashby H.B.: Sovereign wealth funds. Legitimacy, governance, and global power
Selected Books Received
Second chance offers in auctions
Intro: In a recent article in The New Yorker about art dealer Jeffrey Deitch it was noted that, “When two buyers compete for a picture, bidding the price up and up, Deitch may have access to a similar work that he can offer to the underbidder” (Tomkins 2007). In practice, Deitch is not alone in adopting the strategy of using information previously revealed by bidders when attempting to sell a subsequent item, as more and more sellers are using such “second chance offers” when selling multiple units. In addition, sellers can also use second chance offers when a winning bidder defaults, thereby saving time and resources by not holding an entirely new auction. Whether because multiple units are available or because of bidder default, this mechanism has become such a popular option that eBay has altered its rules to formally allow for “second chance offers.” Our paper develops an IPV model where the seller is able to credibly commit to a second chance offer rule where a take-it-or-leave-it offer is made to the highest losing bidder at a price equal to their bid.Footnote 1 Our model can accommodate both the multi-unit and defaultinterpretations and shows that not only does bidder behavior in both second price and English auctions differ from the standard “bid your value” dominant strategy,Footnote 2 but that bidding in the two types of auctions is no longer strategically equivalent. The main reason that a second chance offer alters bidding behavior is that neither the second price nor English auction is isomorphic to the Vickrey (1961, 1962) auction when there is a possibility of a second chance offer and thus it is not dominant for a bidder to simply bid his value in these auctions. Ultimately, because information contained by bids in each auction can subsequently be used to set the second chance offer price and because each auction releases information differently, bidding behavior differs as well. While our paper is the first to analyze this specific form of second chance offer, other types of second chance offers have been examined. Salmon and Wilson (2008) compare using an auction and second chance offer to sell two goods to simply using a sequence of two second price auctions. Their model is similar to ours in that the seller makes a take-it-or-leave-it offer to the second highest bidder from the auction. However, their model differs qualitatively in that the seller does not pre-commit to the form of the second chance offer. Thus, equilibrium bids in their model must involve mixed strategies since bidders realize that their values could be directly inferred from a pure strategy bid (through inversion of the bid function) in which case the seller would simply extract all of their surplus through the second chance offer. Mixing does not surface in our model as the seller is able to pre-commit to the take-it-or-leave-it pricing rule before the auction and thus bidders can build the second chance offer price into their strictly increasing bid functions. Joshi et al. (2005) also examine the impact of augmenting an auction with a second chance offer. They focus on determining the degree to which bidders would be better off if it were possible to prevent the seller from observing their individual identities, their exact bids, or both in an initial auction for a single item (after which \(k\) identical items are offered to the \(k\) highest losing bidders at the price at which each bidder chose to drop out of the bidding process). Bidders in their model know with certainty that \(k\) second chance offers will be made, whereas in our model there is uncertainty regarding the possibility of receiving a second chance offer (represented by an exogenous probability \(p\)). In a related paper, Sun and Vora (2009) consider second chance offers in first price auctions. In that model, the second chance offer is a randomization between a fixed-price and the bidder’s bid at the initial auction. Once again, unlike our model, Sun and Vora (2009) assume that the seller will be making the second chance offer with certainty. Our assumption of uncertainty about whether or not the second chance offer will be made reflects a number of real world settings. The applicability of our model concerns whether real-world sellers can credibly commit to the take-it-or-leave format of the second chance offer modeled here and whether or not that offer can be fully anticipated. Clearly eBay provides one such example because winning bidders do not always default, but also because sellers sometimes have multiple units to sell. However, application of our model is not limited to eBay. For example, several state procurement procedures require that, should a winning bidder default on a contract, the contract be awarded to the second highest bidder, at a price equal to their bid, without reopening the bidding process. The credibility and uncertainty behind our second chance offers lead to vastly different conclusions than the papers cited above. Our results however, are closely related to those of Jeitschko (1999) where, although second chance offers are not considered, there is uncertainty regarding the possible auction of a second unit. Focusing on second price auctions, Jeitschko shows that when there is a possibility that a second unit will be auctioned later, bids in the first auction are shaded below what they would be if there were no possibility of a second unit being auctioned, but higher than what they would be if it were known for certain that a second unit would be sold. Our model produces a similar result when there is a possibility that a second chance offer will be made (rather than a second auction being conducted) although equilibrium bidding in our model differs drastically from that in Jeitschko (1999). Our paper begins with a formal statement of the model in Sect. 2. Section 3 defines the bidder’s maximization problems for first price, second price, and English auctions when a second chance offer may follow the auction. Bayes-Nash equilibrium bid functions are derived for each auction. Section 4 follows with a detailed analysis of how bidder behavior differs in second price and English auctions (when a second chance offer will be made with an exogenous probability \(p\)) and then shifts focus to the expected revenue generated by each auction for a seller who faces risk averse bidders.Footnote 3 We compare the revenue generating properties of the three auctions studied in Sect. 3 with a fourth: the multi-unit (Vickrey 1962) auction. This allows us to couch our revenue results in terms of the well established literature on revenues in standard single unit IPV auctions with risk averse bidders. The famed Revenue Equivalence Theorem implies that all standard IPV single unit auctions deliver equal levels of expected revenue when bidders are risk neutral. However, it is well known that revenue equivalence ceases when bidders are risk averse. Holt (1980) was the first to explain why, showing that (1) risk averse bidders bid more aggressively in standard first price auctions than do risk neutral bidders and (2) the dominant strategy of bidding one’s value in second price and English auctions is impervious to bidder risk aversion since these auctions are isomorphic to the Vickrey (1961) auction in the single unit IPV model. As Klemperer (1999) sums up, “\(\ldots \) since the standard auctions were revenue equivalent with risk neutral bidders, a risk-neutral seller faced by risk averse bidders prefers the first-price auction to second-price sealed bid or ascending auctions.” (see Klemperer 2004 or Krishna 2010 for a detailed discussions on auctions with risk averse bidders). With second chance offers, the revenue equivalence theorem continues to apply under risk neutrality, in which case expected seller revenue is equal in all of the auctions that we consider. However, if bidders are risk averse (with CRRA preferences), bids and thus expected revenues in first price, second price, and English auctions increase with the degree of bidder risk aversion. Thus, our results for second price and English auctions differ from those in the standard single unit IPV model where bids are unaltered by the level of bidder risk aversion. The lack of dominance in our model stems from the fact that second price and English auctions are no longer isomorphic to the Vickrey auction. Specifically, because the second chance offer is made to the second highest bidder at their bid, a “first-price” component is added to these auctions and dominance is lost. In essence, by using a second chance offer, the auctioneer entices risk averse bidders to bid more aggressively (than if they were risk neutral) and is thus able to capture some of the revenue enhancing properties of standard first price auctions, even when using second price and English auctions. The second chance offer variant of the Vickrey auction allocates the first unit to the highest bidder for a price equal to the second highest bid if there is no second chance offer made. If a second chance offer is made, then the two highest bidders are allocated units and both pay the third highest bid. By design, this produces a dominant strategy of bidding one’s value that is impervious to the degree of bidder risk aversion. Therefore, the Vickrey auction is revenue dominated by the other three auctions considered, all of which engender more aggressive bids than when bidders are risk neutral. Further, the precise impact of risk aversion on bidding is more substantial in second price auctions than in English auctions and thus second price auctions outperform English auctions in terms of expected revenue when there is a possibility of a second chance offer. Finally, we point out that first price, second price, and English auctions each set the second chance offer price equal to the second highest bidder’s bid. But, only the first price auction sets the auction price equal to the auction winner’s bid. This leads us to speculate that when bidders are risk averse the first price auction will generate higher expected revenue than either a second price or English auction. Unfortunately, the first price equilibrium bid function is vastly different from the second price and English bid functions, and each bid function is relatively complex. As a result, no general conclusions can be made about the revenue ranking of the first price auction to these other two auction formats. While we are able to provide several numerical computations that support our speculation regarding the revenue dominance of the first price auction, in the end the only general conclusion that we can make about the first price auction with the possibility of a second chance offer is that it revenue dominates the Vickrey auction.

Title: Imperfect evaluation in project screening
Intro:
We study a game of two-sided incomplete information in which an agent considers proposing a project of unknown quality to an evaluator, who has the choice of whether or not to accept it. Prior to taking their actions, each player performs an assessment of the project that yields a private signal of quality. The agent’s payoff upon submission is determined by the evaluator’s decision; the evaluator’s payoff is determined by the quality of the projects that he accepts. Making the proposal incurs a cost on the agent in the form of a submission fee.Footnote 1
 The situations that are captured by the above setting are abundant and diverse. A possible example is that of a firm interested in undertaking a project, such as the development of an economic activity in an environmentally sensitive area, that requires filing a costly application with a regulatory agency. In this case, the firm is concerned with the agency’s decision of whether to approve the proposal, while the regulatory agency is usually concerned with the social welfare implications of that activity. Other examples are the introduction of a new product with potential undesirable effects, a merger, a patent application, or the submission of an article to an academic journal. The main objective of this paper is to study the effect of the submission fee, in its role of instrument of control of the level of self-screening exerted by the agent, on the expected quality of projects implemented by the evaluator.
