Several recent papers, starting with Leslie (2005), investigate the optimal submission fee problem in the context of the submission of articles for review to academic journals, and show that these optimal fees are strictly positiveFootnote 2 because they reduce the burden on the journal editors and referees by discouraging long-shot submissions.Footnote 3 In these earlier papers, the evaluator can perfectly learn the quality of an article upon submission, and the optimal fee is chosen so as to balance a trade-off between the cost of evaluation and the need to accept a certain minimum number of articles. In a variety of real-world applications of project-screening, though, the evaluation of a project is imperfect at the time when the decision on whether or not to be accepted is made, and the project’s quality is revealed only after it is implemented. In this paper we examine a model of two-sided incomplete information where not only the agent’s, but also the evaluator’s assessment of the project is imperfect. In this case, while a higher submission fee increases the quality of projects that the agent submits, it also lowers the evaluator’s standards of acceptance. Since under this specification, the expected quality of projects that are implemented is determined by the screening of both the agent and the evaluator, this raises the question of whether and when a higher submission fee is beneficial. We show that a higher submission fee increases the expected quality of projects that are implemented if and only if the elasticity of the likelihood of a high-quality project as inferred from the evaluator’s minimum quality standard is higher than the elasticity of the likelihood of a high-quality project as inferred from the fact that the evaluator accepted a project. Intuitively, the effect of the increase in the submission fee on the expected quality of projects that are implemented is determined by the corresponding effect on the likelihoods of a high quality project as inferred from the facts that (i) the agent submitted a project, and (ii) the evaluator accepted it. A higher submission fee increases the former likelihood, but decreases the latter. The effect on the former likelihood can be elicited from the evaluator’s decision problem, as a function of the elasticity of the likelihood of a high quality project as inferred from the evaluator’s minimum quality standard. This is because this minimum standard is determined in the evaluator’s problem precisely by the expected quality of projects that are submitted, and thus can act as a sufficient statistic for the agent’s information structure in a neighbourhood of the agent’s equilibrium strategy. Thus, the effect that we investigate can be elicited locally from the evaluator’s information structure. The necessary condition for a higher submission fee to increase the quality of projects that are implemented is not always satisfied for generic information structures. Thus, while a higher submission fee does increase the expected quality of projects that are submitted, it may decrease the expected quality of projects that are implemented. In particular, this occurs if for the given project-screening mechanism, the evaluator’s effect on the quality of the projects that are implemented (i.e., the elasticity of the likelihood of a high-quality project as inferred from the fact that the evaluator accepted a project) is highly responsive to the change in the quality of projects submitted for review. From a policy perspective, this implies that in those situations where evaluation is imperfect and where there is reason to believe that the evaluator may infer information from the agent’s decision, then when studying the optimal submission fee problem, one has to account for that fact that an increase in the perceived quality of projects submitted for review may come at the expense of the evaluator’s own judgment of the project. For instance, this suggests that if a regulatory agency’s rulings are susceptible to be highly influenced by a firm’s decision to proceed with an application for permit of an economic activity, then higher application costs may have a negative impact on the quality of projects that are implemented. From a formal point of view, the closest paper to ours is Taylor and Yildirim (2011), which studies a model in which an agent chooses the amount of effort to exert in generating a project, and investigates the moral hazard effects of the potentially available public information. We consider the effort level as sunk, and the agent’s decision to be whether to submit a project as a function of the available public and private information. Miquel-Florensa (2010) examines an optimal allocation problem in a signaling game where a budget constrained applicant can employ the amount of resources expended on the application to signal the quality of his proposal. The principal does not posses any information about the quality of the project, but can use several instruments to influence the applicant’s decision so as to solve a trade-off between better project screening and loss of resources spent on the application process. Ottaviani and Wickelgren (2009) analyze the trade-off between ex-ante and ex-post approval of an activity when the evaluator may reconsider his approval at the time when the quality of the project is revealed. Boleslavsky and Cotton (2011) study a model in which an evaluator has to select one of several competing proposals, and investigate the effect of the limited capacity on the incentives of the proposers to produce information. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2 we introduce the model. In Sect. 3 we solve for the equilibrium of the game. Section 4 contains the main results of the paper, while Sect. 5 concludes. Most proofs are presented in the Appendix.

Title: Exclusive contracts when the incumbent can establish a direct retailer
Optimal manipulation rules in a mixed oligopoly
Inferior factor in Cournot oligopoly revisited
De Grauwe, Paul: Lectures on behavioral macroeconomics
Scheubel, Beatrice: Bismarck’s Institutions. A historical perspective on the social security hypothesis
Some thoughts on the Sutton approach
Intro: The endogenous market structure (EMS) approach analyzes strategic interactions between an endogenous number of competitors. Simple models of quantity or price competition with endogenous entry show that increasing the size of a market the number of firms tends to increase but in a less than proportional way.Footnote 1 This is due to the fact that larger markets attract more firms and strengthen competition, which reduces markups: this limits the entry opportunities on one side, and requires an expansion of individual production on the other side. Such a relation between market size and market structure has found a certain empirical support (see Bresnahan and Reiss 1987; Campbell and Hopenhayn 2005, and Etro 2009) and has relevant implications: for instance, entry tends to be procyclical while markups are countercyclical, which has an impact on the business cycle in a dynamic context, and opening up to trade induces business destruction at the local level while inducing gains from competition.Footnote 2 The consequences may be even more radical in markets where firms endogenously invest in fixed costs of R&D and advertising, because larger markets may induce larger investments and reduce entry rather than increase it. This possibility has been forcefully pointed out by Sutton (1991, 1998), claiming on empirical grounds, that many sectors characterized by intensive R&D and advertising activity may face an upper bound on the number of firms and exhibit even a decreasing number of competitors when the market size is large enough. However, while the upper bound emerges in a variety of theoretical models, the inverse-U relation between market size and number of firms does not emerge naturally in basic models available in the literature. In this note I provide a simple theoretical foundation for such an inverse-U relation, within a model where firms invest in R&D and (simultaneously or sequentially) choose their market strategies. It is an example based on Cournot competition, homogenous goods, linear demand and a quadratic cost-reducing technology: what emerges is that an increase of the market size induces the inverse-U pattern conjectured by Sutton for the number of firms, but reduces always the price and increases R&D investment and production of each firm. The first theoretical analysis of EMSs with endogenous sunk costs has been provided by Dasgupta and Stiglitz (1980). They considered Cournot competition between firms producing a homogenous good and choosing how much to invest in R&D to reduce the marginal costs of production. Their example with isoelastic demand and cost functions shows that a larger market size is associated with a proportionally larger investment in cost reduction, so that the endogenous number of firms remains invariant. Nevertheless, since the marginal cost is endogenous and decreasing in the investment, the equilibrium price is always decreasing in the size of the market. These outcomes justify the same focus of the EMS approach (also without endogenous sunk costs) on markets with a small number of competitors (even when the size of the market is global), and they are consistent with two traditional insights: larger markets generate lower prices and higher production (and R&D investment) per firm. Tandon (1984) has replicated the analysis of Dasgupta and Stiglitz (1980) considering a very specific example of linear Cournot model with endogenous entry and sunk costs to confirm that the number of firms is independent from the size of the market. Sutton (1991) has obtained a similar results on the basis of a model in which firms compete in quantities and invest in quality. Only recently, Vives (2008) has been able to extend the analysis of endogenous sunk costs to general profit functions under quantity and price competition. He has shown that an increase in the size of the market increases always individual investment and production, but has ambiguous effects on the number of firms, which suggests that the earlier examples were rather peculiar. For instance, in the case of CES utility with price competition, Vives (2008) has derived an equilibrium number of firms, which is increasing in the relative market size, as in standard models without endogenous sunk costs. However, examples of the opposite case, that is fewer firms in bigger markets, or of non-monotone patterns have not emerged in the theoretical literature, leaving the Sutton hypothesis as a mere theoretical possibility. The idea that there is a maximum number of firms for different sectors independent from their size has found additional support in the celebrated result by Sutton (1991): under rather general modeling assumptions, he has shown that there is a lower positive bound to market concentration in the presence of endogenous sunk investments.Footnote 3 These investments are essential for the result because the number of firms remains constant only when the endogenous sunk costs increase proportionally with the size of the market. Sutton (1991) has also emphasized the possibility of a non-monotone relation between size and entry, but has obtained such a relation only through a shift of regime from a traditional one with zero endogenous investment for all firms (where a larger size increases the number of firms) to an “escalation” phase in which market expansion leads to higher investments and higher concentration (a larger size reduces the number of firms). A wide empirical literature, has also verified the Sutton hypothesis of an inverted-U relation between market size and number of firms for markets with endogenous sunk costs. The initial reference is (Sutton 1991, 1998), whose empirical analysis is entirely aimed at showing the existence of a lower bound on concentration in a number of global markets (such as those for automobiles, aircrafts, electronic computing equipment, semiconductors, organic fibres, drugs, cereals and so on). Recently, Ellickson (2007) has looked at the supermarket industry in the U.S. and shown that “the minimum level of concentration is highest in the smallest markets, decreases for a range, and then hits a lower limit beyond which it does not fall and might even increase” (p. 52). In this note, I provide the simplest theoretical foundation for an inverse-U relation between market size and number of firms in a textbook Cournot model with homogenous goods, linear demand and standard functions of R&D activity. In particular, I generalize the example introduced by Tandon (1984) in many directions and show that, as long as the exogenous fixed costs are positive, the EMS is naturally characterized by an inverted-U relation between market size and number of firms, in line with the hypothesis of Sutton (1991). To understand the rationale for this non-monotone relation we should examine how the equilibrium strategies change in markets of different sizes (notice that there is no dynamic in our model, therefore our comparisons should be seen as cross sectional results). First of all, we obtain that R&D investment increases more than proportionally with the size of the market because its marginal profitability increases. In small markets with few firms and low investment, the mark ups are high enough that an increase in demand is able to expand production and profits as much as needed to attract a larger number of firms. However, in larger markets with many firms, high investments and low mark ups, an increase in demand cannot expand production enough to increase profits and attract more firms. For a given high number of firms, an expansion of the market is going to increase the entry costs more than the gross profits, which in equilibrium requires a smaller number of active firms. Once again the price is decreasing in the size of the market and the production of each firm is increasing in it, as in all the earlier models. This work is related to the recent revival of the literature on EMS, which has analyzed implication of markets with endogenous strategies and entry decisions in different partial and general equilibrium fields, both with exogenous and endogenous sunk costs. Relevant contributions considering preliminary investments or commitments by firms in markets with endogenous entry include Vives (2008), Erkal and Piccinin (2010), (Etro 2006, 2011a), Ino and Matsumura (2012), Žigić (2012), Anderson et al. (2012) and Cato and Matsumura (2013). Applications to general equilibrium issues with related discussions of the impact of market size on the structure of the markets, on the number of firms and on the markups include (Peretto 1999, 2003) and Etro and Colciago (2010). The linear Cournot model with quadratic investments in cost reductions is analyzed also in Etro and Cella (2013) for the case of uncertainty and asymmetric information on the productivity of the managers engaged in the cost reducing activity. The next Sect. 2 reviews the past results of the literature, Sect. 3 presents our example, derives its implications and extends it to a more general cost reduction technology. Section 4 extends the model to sequential decisions on R&D investment and production, and Sect. 5 concludes.

Title: New technology adoption in a Cournot oligopoly with spillovers
A generalized framework for endogenous timing in duopoly games and an application to price-quantity competition
Low price signals high capacity
Radial and directional measures of the rate of technical change
Intro:
The rate of technical change provides a local measure of the shift in the production frontier between two periods. In the single-output case, the rate of technical change as defined by Solow (1957) measures the rate at which output can increase as time elapses holding inputs constant. This proportional change is indeed equal to the partial logarithmic derivative of the production function with respect to time. Caves et al. (1981) generalized Solow (1957) measure to the case of multi-output technologies where two alternatives can be considered. First, the output-based measure, which is defined as the common rate that technological improvements allow all outputs to increase over time holding inputs constant and second, the input-based measure, defined as the common rate at which all inputs can decrease over time holding outputs constant. Since a common rate of change in either outputs or inputs is assumed in the above definitions, the aforementioned measures of the rate of technical change are referred to as radial or proportional. 
Caves et al. (1981) shown in addition that the radial output- and input-based measures of the rate of technical change are related one another through the scale elasticity. In particular, the output-based measure is less (greater) than the input-based measure under decreasing (increasing) returns to scale while they are equal under constant returns to scale.Footnote 1 Even though Caves et al. (1981) employed a transformation function to derive this result, it can be shown that holds for all other function representations of multi-output, multi-input technologies, such as the Shephard-type input and output distance functions.Footnote 2 On the other hand, the primal (i.e., input- and output-based) measures can also be linked with the dual (i.e., cost-, revenue- and profit-based) measures of the rate of technical change.Footnote 3 It has been shown in particular that the cost- and the input-based measures are equal to each other (Caves et al. 1981; Atkinson and Cornwell 1998) as are the revenue- and the output-based measures (Fulginiti 2010). Moreover, the input- and the output-based measures are related to the profit-based measure by means of the scale elasticity (Bernstein 1994; Karagiannis and Mergos 2000), which has also a pivotal role in linking the alternative dual (i.e., cost-, revenue- and profit-based) measures of technical change (Karagiannis and Xepapadeas 2009). The main objective of this paper is to develop measures of the rate of technical change for the class of directional distance functions. We not only consider output- and input-based measures as was done for the other function representations of the technology, but we develop both radial (proportional) and directional measures of the rate of technical change. The former are analogous to the conventional measures considering radial changes in inputs and/or outputs such that their proportions remain unchanged while the latter deal with non-proportional changes in either inputs, outputs or both along the direction of the reference vector. We show that the proposed three primal directional measures of the rate of technical change are related one another through the translation elasticity.Footnote 4 We also derive relations between the primal and the dual directional measures of the rate of technical change and we show that are also linked to each other with the translation elasticity. Finally, we relate radial and directional measures by means of the normalized (by the value of the direction vector) dual functions. Even though the choice between directional and radial measures is by and large an empirical matter closely related to the study under consideration, there are several cases where the radial measures do not suffice to provide plausible estimates of the rate of technical change. For example, in the presence of undesirable outputs, such as pollution or non-performing loans, the output-based radial measure provides implausible estimates of the rate of technical change as it fails to credit expansion of good outputs and to debit bad outputs production. Instead it measures the proportional increase of both good and bad outputs that is made possible by technical change from a given input bundle. In contrast, the output-based directional measure provides more reasonable estimates of the rate of technical change as allows for simultaneous increases in good outputs and decreases in bad output. Another example refers to the case of specialized and diversified firms: e.g., some power plants may produce only electricity, others produce only heating and some may produce both. For the specialized firms, the radial measure due to its proportional nature could only account for the expansion of the currently produced outputs neglecting the possibility that technical change may favor the development of more diversified production plans. However, the directional measure due to its additive nature can accommodate that option.

Title: Mansuri, Ghazala and Rao, Vijayendra: Localizing development. Does participation work?
Price competition and quality differentiation with multiproduct firms
Endogenous direct advertising and price competition
Innovation or imitation? The effect of spillovers and competitive pressure on firms’ R&D strategy choice
Effects of capacity constraints on mixed duopoly
Slanina, František: Essentials of econophysics modelling.
Selected Books Received
Infrastructure, women’s time allocation, and economic development
Intro:
The role of infrastructure in the process of economic development has received renewed attention in the ongoing debate on how to promote growth in low-income countries. In addition to the conventional positive effects on factor productivity and private investment, more recent evidence suggests that access to infrastructure may have a significant impact on health and education outcomes.Footnote 1 Moreover, this impact tends to be magnified through interactions between health and education themselves. Better health has been shown to have a large impact on the ability to learn and study; conversely, more educated parents tend to take better care of themselves and their children. Since the seminal contribution of Boserup (1970), the role of women in promoting growth and development has also occupied centre stage in policy debates. For instance, Coulombe and Tremblay (2006) found that investment in women’s human capital has been more important for growth in today’s industrialized countries than investment in men’s human capital. At the same time, however, it has been well documented that women trail men in a number of dimensions—formal labor force participation, access to credit and infrastructure, entrepreneurship rates, and income levels. In today’s low- and middle-income countries for instance, the labor force participation rate for women is only 57 women workers earn about three-quarters of what men earn. Gender differences in education, work experience, and job characteristics explain some fraction of that gap; in Sub-Saharan Africa, 54 of girls do not complete even a primary school education (Herz and Sperling 2004). In a related literature, it has been found that illiterate women have more children and that mothers’ education has a positive effect on child survival, education and nutritional status. Indeed, because of better nutritional knowledge, more educated mothers tend to adopt safer health and hygiene practices, which improve their children’s health and survival (see Glewwe 1999; Morrison et al. 2007). In Africa, children of mothers who receive five years of primary education are 40 age five, and educated mothers are about 50 immunize their children than uneducated mothers. As documented by Blackden et al. (2006), gender inequality (particularly with respect to education and access to formal sector employment) remains a significant constraint to growth in Sub-Saharan Africa.Footnote 2
 The key issue that this paper addresses is at the intersection of these two agendas: it focuses on how improved access to infrastructure affects women’s time allocation decisions and how, in turn, changes in these decisions affect the process of growth and economic development. The impact of infrastructure on women’s time allocation has been documented in a number of empirical studies, including Ilahi (2000), Riverson et al. (2006), and Blackden and Wodon (2006). On average, women in rural Sub-Saharan Africa spend between 0.9 and 2.2 h per day on collecting water and firewood. Better access to infrastructure may enable women to devote more time to market activity, thereby promoting growth; at the same time, it may lead to improved learning monitoring (in the case of electricity, for instance) as well as improved child care practices (including breast feeding), which may strengthen the health status of children and their ability to learn.Footnote 3 Put differently, there are opportunity costs to market activity, and these should be taken into account when assessing growth effects. Accordingly, this paper develops a three-period, gender-based overlapping generations (OLG) model with public capital to explore the implications of infrastructure on women’s time allocation and growth. Gender-based OLG models are relatively few in the literature; among the notable exceptions are Ehrlich and Lui (1991), Galor and Weil (1996, 2000), Zhang et al. (1999), Lagerlöf (2003), Greenwood et al. (2005), Greenwood and Seshadri (2005), and De la Croix and Vander Donckt (2010). None of these contributions, however, addresses the kind of issues that we consider here. Greenwood et al. (2005) and Greenwood and Seshadri (2005), for instance, focus on technological progress in the market, and technological progress in the home, as determinants of fertility and female labor force participation.Footnote 4 Our focus here is on the specific impact of access to public infrastructure services (whose supply can be directly influenced by policy decisions) on female time allocation choices, and its interactions with women’s health, education outcomes, and economic growth. Our model differs from the existing literature in several other ways as well. First, women’s time in the model is endogenously allocated not only to market work, but also to home production, child rearing, and own health care. In existing contributions, rearing time is typically considered exogenous, whereas time devoted to own health care is generally ignored—even in OLG models where interactions between health and growth take center stage, as for instance in Chakraborty (2004), Hashimoto and Tabata (2005), Finlay (2006), Bhattacharya and Qiao (2007), Tang and Zhang (2007), and Chakraborty et al. (2010). Endogenizing mothers’ rearing time is important because in the model such time is productive—it helps to shape education and health outcomes. Second, the model accounts not only for the productivity effect of public infrastructure (as in many other contributions) but also for its effects on home production and human capital accumulation.Footnote 5 As documented by the World Bank (2008) for instance, greater access to electricity can decrease significantly the amount of time that women spend on household production activities such as cooking, collecting firewood, and fetching water. Thus, in contrast to existing studies, but in line with the evidence alluded to earlier, we are able to highlight the key role that infrastructure may play in human development, both directly and indirectly. To the extent that access to infrastructure affects the time devoted by mothers to home production and caring for themselves and their children, it will also exert indirect effects on long-run growth. Third, health outcomes exhibit serial dependence, in the sense that health status (and productivity) in adulthood depends to a significant extent on health outcomes in childhood. This is consistent with a number of empirical studies, such as Case et al. (2005), World Health Organization (2005), Schady and Paxson (2007), Smith (2009), and Verropoulou and Joshi (2009).Footnote 6 Such dependence gives a crucial role to mothers’ time allocation in shaping the future of their children.Footnote 7
 Our key results can be summarized as follows. The effect of government provision of infrastructure on growth depends not only on conventional productivity effects on marketed output, but also crucially on its impact on women’s time allocation, human capital accumulation, and the strength of congestion effects. Improved access to infrastructure induces women to reallocate their time away from home production activities and toward productive uses—which include not only market work but also time spent caring for themselves and their children. This may help trigger a process through which a poor country may escape from a low-growth trap. However, if women substitute time away from child care, persistence in health outcomes may lead to lower productivity in adulthood. In addition, if health improvements lead to higher life expectancy and savings, and thus a faster rate of private capital accumulation, the benefits from increased access to public capital may be mitigated by congestion effects—which in turn may affect women’s time allocation.Footnote 8 In the absence of complementary (possibly microeconomic) measures, a “ Big Push” policy involving a reallocation of public spending toward infrastructure investment may not succeed in triggering a shift to a high-growth path and sustained improvements in health and productivity. The remainder of the paper is organized as follows.Footnote 9 Section 2 presents the model. Section 3 derives the steady-state growth rate and examines the properties of the model. In particular, we examine how access to infrastructure affects fertility and women’s time allocated to home production and market activity. Section 4 examines the possibility of multiple development regimes resulting from threshold effects associated with life expectancy and health outcomes, which may themselves result from how access to infrastructure affects the home production technology. Section 5 discusses whether an increase in public spending on health, education, or infrastructure may allow a country to escape from a low-growth equilibrium. The last section provides some concluding remarks.

Title: Exponential discounting bias
Lender deception as a response to moral hazard
Intro:
The topics of fraud or breach of contract in the literature on asymmetric information and principal–agent relationships have long been posed as actions possibly taken by the agent (in both ex post and interim manners), since it is the agent that is in possession of the relevant information and more disposed to commit fraud or deception with regard to this information. The prevention of fraudulent agency is therefore a primary concern in the literature, and the response commonly ascribed to principals in this situation is generally ‘monitoring and enforcement’ of contracts and/or the construction of optimal contracts in such circumstances.Footnote 1 Very little consideration has been given to the possibility that the principal employ fraud or breach of contract for improving the outcome for themselves in response to the agent’s advantage. Leading up to the failure of the US mortgage market in 2007–2008, studies of ‘abusive lending practices’ and ‘predatory lending’ became more frequent, especially in legal scholarship.Footnote 2 Economic analyses of the subprime mortgage market and payday lending existed, but the foundational theoretical work on credit markets with asymmetric information lent little to understanding why lenders might defraud borrowers.Footnote 3
Engel and McCoy (2005) suggest that models, such as Stiglitz and Weiss (1981) or Bester (1985), lost relevance due to changes in home lending markets that reoriented the asymmetry of information, from one of borrower privilege to one of lender privilege. For example, the problem of ‘reduced documentation’ in the sub-prime lending market did not make sense according to the standard models of asymmetric information in lending: the lender can only benefit from additional information, not less information. In the unfolding housing crisis, Golding et al. (2008) characterize lender deception as motivated by the “extraction of rent” but do not provide a formal demonstration of this point, nor do they provide references to the theoretical foundation for this idea. Durkin and Elliehausen (2011) spend considerable time reviewing the economics of information literature to provide justification for the Truth in Lending Act of 1968, but they never point to the disconnect in asymmetric information models and policy crafted to address opportunistic lending practices. An exception, Bond et al. (2005), provide a model of ‘predatory lending’ in the context of an asymmetric information between a borrower and lender, in both competitive and non-competitive markets. They contrast their work with a body of literature on ‘competition for imperfectly informed consumers,’ which does not easily fit the lending market and translates to borrowers as being irrational.Footnote 4 Instead, they propose that borrowers are rational, but they lack “the private information regarding their future incomes residing with their current lenders.” Our paper presents a similar relationship of borrowers to information: lenders create an information asymmetry with regard to the terms of the loan contract. This is consistent with reports about questionable lending practices and circumstances surrounding US mortgage markets leading up to 2008 (see Anderson 2004; Carr and Kolluri 2001; Lacko and Pappalardo 2007). We consider the possibility that a principal may misrepresent some element of the prospective contract in response to the agent’s privileged information. We are expanding the credit market model of Bowles (2003), which is used to demonstrate the possibility of inefficient allocations of credit in the presence of wealth inequality among borrowers with different quality investment projects. The model can be altered for the hidden-state situation rather easily, but the hidden-action model is retained here for sake of continuity and expansion of the ideas in Bowles (2003). Principal–agent relationships have an inherent conflict of interest, and the possibility of a breach of contract foreseen by either party precludes the possibility of a contract; but the existence of third-party enforcement can restore this possibility. Let us consider a middle-ground. Can the possibility of breach exist in the midst of third-party enforcement? There are several routes one can take in entertaining this possibility: we can imagine that both parties are aware of the presence of a legal system, but that one party can ‘purchase’ the lack of enforcement. In other words, imagine that a borrower does not anticipate a breach of contract due to the existence of third-party enforcement and the lender can sustain the borrower’s naivety at a cost. Call this costly activity paid for by the lender, lender deception: it is a costly way of producing (indiscreetly) an asymmetry of information with regard to the existence of a breach of contract under the guise of an already existing legal system. We will consider the possibility that the principal (lender) has at their disposal some mechanism by which the distribution of economic rents due to the information asymmetry can be adjusted for their advantage. Typically, to achieve such alterations, the principal’s mechanism is an alternate contract, whereby they appropriate either a larger share of rent or increase the rent and appropriate a share of greater absolute size. We will propose a situation where the potential economic rent is fixed and the principal commits ‘undetectable fraud’ in order to extract a share of the agent’s economic rent. Thus, instead of costly monitoring or costly auditing, we propose a model where the principal ‘produces ignorance’ in the agent in response to their information advantage. Section 2 outlines the lending model with collateral, as well as the structure of the borrower-lender interaction assumed for it. Section 2.2 considers the outcomes of two extreme market conditions, the monopoly and competitive market cases. Section 2.3 formalizes the theory of deception for the determination of the amount of deception chosen by a lender in both market conditions. Section 3 considers the welfare effects of deception and the distribution of rents under different market conditions and across different borrower characteristics. The section ends with comments and recommendations for further possible research.

Title: Regulating harmless activity to fight crime
Intro: There is a consensus in the field of public economics that governments should intervene in private decision-making in some areas, since market outcomes would otherwise prove unsatisfactory. For example, when firms’ activities imply environmental pollution, the use of policy instruments (such as environmental taxes aimed at the internalization of the corresponding external effects) can be welfare-enhancing (Pigou 1920). Similarly, the public-good nature of national defense justifies government involvement (Samuelson 1954). However, with regard to criteria of efficiency, it is commonly agreed that decisions regarding goods or activities with purely private repercussions should be left to the market’s ‘invisible hand’. This paper establishes that government regulation of individual decisions may be welfare-enhancing even when the direct repercussions of the goods or activities in question are purely private. In our framework, the rationale for such regulation lies in the interdependence between the activity with purely private direct consequences and criminal involvement, where the latter imposes external costs on society. In other words, we consider goods or activities that have only private direct effects (i.e., impose no expected external harm) but, if combined with criminal undertakings, influence the offender’s crime engagement.Footnote 1 The interdependence may be such that the two activities are either substitutes or complements, when evaluated from the individual’s point of view. Regulation of the private good or activity offers the policy maker an instrument that can indirectly address crime. In seeking to increase the level of deterrence, the policy maker can either choose to fight crime directly (by increasing the probability of detection and/or the sanction level) or indirectly (by making substitutes for criminal involvement more desirable and complements less attractive). The direct approach is associated with high costs; however, the indirect approach entails costs as well. Specifically, the costs associated with the indirect approach are related to the distortion of the decisions made by law-abiding citizens; clearly, the lower the utility obtained from the harmless and law-abiding use of the activity in question, the lower the indirect costs. In other words, if a good is bought or an activity is undertaken primarily because of the effect it is expected to have on an individual’s involvement in crime, then the societal costs of regulation will be tolerable in most circumstances. As a result, whether or not governments seek to regulate individual decisions with purely private direct consequences in order to influence criminal involvement will depend on the relative size of the respective crime-fighting costs and the costs resulting from the crime itself.Footnote 2 There is reason to believe that the costs of the direct approach to crime have reached levels that warrant (at least partial) utilization of alternative approaches.Footnote 3 For instance, (Kleiman (2009), p.2) reports that the United States spends about $200 billion per year on detecting and punishing criminals. Furthermore, there are indications that the effects of spending more on traditional methods of law enforcement will be limited due to strictly diminishing returns (Kennedy 2010). In the real world, governments indeed intervene in decisions that at first glance seem to have purely private consequences. This is particularly true in areas in which the relationship between the decision and criminal undertaking is obvious. For instance, the private use of police radios is a violation of the German telecommunications law (TKG). It seems intuitive that this activity would offer advantages to non-law-abiding individuals, although it is likely that the majority of interested radio operators only seek entertainment. Another example is individual participation in certain kinds of organizations. As a consequence of the terrorist attacks of 9/11, several jurisdictions have sought to hamper the expansion of certain organizations, almost to the extent of outlawing membership in them (Cole 2008). However, many modern (Western) societies support other kinds of organizations, in particular religious organizations, in one way or another.Footnote 4 The support of the state can be explained by church programs that serve the community (such as day-care centers) and, significantly, by the possibility that religious involvement might influence moral norms (by reinforcing commandments such as “thou shalt not steal” and “thou shalt not kill”, for instance). In addition to church membership, other activities can also potentially influence morality, including education and child-rearing.Footnote 5 Moral norms influence individual behavior by imposing an intrinsic punishment for engaging in amoral behavior, even when there is no one else present to observe or punish the offender (see, e.g., Elster 1989). As a result, engaging in an activity that is likely to enforce morality is generally associated with a reduction in the net benefits obtained from crime, all else equal (see, for example, Shavell 2002 and Kaplow and Shavell 2007). On a different note, it could be argued (in particular, for adolescent offenders) that crime is at least in some instances undertaken because it is exciting and requires a show of courage. By subsidizing amusement parks, climbing parks, go-kart tracks, and the like, the government may be able to offer affordable alternative ways to experience risk-taking and prove one’s mettle to others. Whereas the previous two examples make reference to purportedly substitutionary relationships between the extent of the activity in question and benefits from crime, copyright-infringing technology may be considered to be an example of complementary interdependence. Technologies such as file-sharing engines, DVD writers, and photocopiers have many harmless uses, but are also employed to appropriate intellectual property in one way or another. Finally, it can be argued that one reason for the regulation of drug use is the association between drug (ab)use and crime, given that the external effects of (certain) drugs are disputable (MacDonald 2004). If we presume, for example, that intoxicated offenders incur lower psychological costs when breaking the law, then permitting drug use may increase the prevalence of crime. Similar arguments that apply to alcohol regulation have been proposed in the literature (see, e.g., Carpenter and Dobkin 2011). In considering these various examples of regulations regarding activities and goods, it is noteworthy that the interventions are subject to significant cross-country variation. For example, the ownership of guns and large knives is highly restricted in Germany, but regulation in the US is much looser (although this varies from state to state). It seems that the valuation of the cost imposed on law-abiding citizens versus the effect on crime deterrence has resulted in different outcomes across countries. There are also certain activities that are associated with a high incidence of crime, but that governments have nevertheless refrained from strictly regulating. For instance, Rees and Schnepel (2009) establish that the host communities of college football games experience sharp increases in a variety of crime categories. In light of the variety and inconsistency of application, we seek to provide a simple framework for the analysis of cost-benefit considerations related to the regulation of harmless activity. Our set-up is quite straightforward. Individuals obtain utility from two goods and, in order to finance consumption, decide how much time to allocate to crime and lawful employment. The individuals differ in their moral scruples or psychological costs related to law-breaking; consequently, there are always some law-abiding citizens. The interdependence between the activity with purely private direct consequences and crime is integrated by allowing the harmless activity of consuming one of the goods to influence the expected payoffs from crime (in addition to a possible interaction via the time constraint of the individual). Should the government decide to regulate this activity, the decisions taken by both law-abiding and non-law-abiding individuals will be influenced. Since the government is unable to distinguish between law-abiding and non-law-abiding individuals (except when the crimes of the latter group are detected), this information asymmetry permits only a uniform ex-ante intervention with respect to the harmless activity under consideration. In terms of how the policy maker will influence the extent to which individuals engage in the harmless activity, we restrict our discussion to the case in which the relative price is changed by a tax or subsidy, relegating the possibility of introducing regulatory standards for future research. However, it is likely that the imperfect information of regulatory agencies and the preference for a light intervention (due to the consumption of the good by many non-criminals) will often work in favor of the price instruments studied here. Given its focus, this paper is related to several different branches of the literature. The policy maker in our study considers intervening in decisions regarding a harmless activity because it is interrelated with crime, i.e., an activity that creates negative external effects for others. As a result, the present paper contributes to the vast literature on achieving the internalization of external effects by means of economic policy. A central feature of the present study is that the harmless activity is not necessarily associated with crime, and thus changing its price also has repercussions on lawful and harmless activity. This distinguishes our treatment from the analysis of the utilization of polluting inputs by firms and corresponding regulations in contributions to the field of environmental economics, for example. Table 1 provides a more comprehensive taxonomy of activities in order to clearly distinguish the goods/activities considered in the present analysis from those treated in other contributions to the literature. In particular, the paper contributes to the literature on optimal law enforcement, a field that has recently been surveyed by Polinsky and Shavell (2007). In this body of work, it has been considered that offenders may invest in avoidance activities that influence the probability of detection (Innes 2001; Langlais 2008; Malik 1990; Nussim and Tabbach 2008, 2009; Tabbach 2010). Avoidance activities are generally complementary to criminal activity, because more crime increases the marginal benefit of avoidance. As explained in Table 1, avoidance activities have neither a direct utility effect nor do they directly impose (expected) external harm; in addition, they only arise in combination with criminal activities. Our approach is related to this branch of the literature, in that the harmless activity we consider may also impact the detection probability; however, a critical difference in our approach is that the activity itself provides utility (see Table 1). This implies that a decrease in the extent to which individuals engage in the harmless activity connotes direct welfare losses. In contrast, pure avoidance only serves the purpose of lowering the expected sanction for the perpetrator; thus, attempts to restrict its utilization bear no direct negative repercussions for society. Furthermore, the consequences of avoidance are usually restricted to the detection probability or the level of the sanction, whereas we additionally consider the influence of the harmless activity on the benefits from crime.Footnote 6 Our discussion also differs from contributions on safety regulation because the activity we consider in addition to crime does not impose expected harm on others (except for its interdependence with crime), whereas regulated activities generally have direct repercussions on others (see, e.g., Shavell 2004). For instance, regulations governing the use of hazardous substances and workplace design have obvious consequences for others. Similarly, our approach is distinct from analyses of gun ownership, since such studies usually assume that guns are purchased only to commit criminal offenses or for the purpose of defense against crime (Mialon and Wiseman 2005; Bac 2010). In contrast, we are interested in the case in which the consumption of a good or activity promotes well-being in its own right (i.e., without any relation to criminal contexts). This is also applicable to gun ownership, since many people enjoy collecting weapons or shooting as a sport. Finally, the goods/activities considered here can be distinguished from private goods/activities without any interaction with crime. For example, eating in a restaurant instead of cooking at home (where both activities imply a rather similar use of time) may be regarded as a purely private activity that lacks any interrelation to crime. Because we consider the allocation of time between legal and illegal opportunities, this paper is also related to Ehrlich (1973); the first study to examine this aspect, and subsequent extensions of the concept. Another body of literature related to our study addresses the topic of taxing complements to leisure and subsidizing substitutes to leisure as elements of optimal taxation (Atkinson and Stiglitz 1976; Corlett and Hague 1953, and, more recently, Kaplow 2010). This research is also related to the informational aspects of our analysis, with information asymmetry about an individual’s type being present. The policy maker may prefer to distort individuals’ decisions with respect to observables (in our case, consumption) in order to affect unobservable decisions. To the best of our knowledge, the question of whether harmless activities should be regulated as means of optimizing law enforcement has not been addressed elsewhere in the literature. The balance of the article is as follows: In Sect. 2, we examine decentralized individual decision-making and explain the comparative statics of the private optimum. Section 3 elaborates on the policy maker’s problem with respect to private decision-making, and Sect. 4 concludes.

Title: Granville, Brigitte: Remembering inflation
Taxation and the quality of entrepreneurship
Comparison between specific taxation and volume quotas in a free entry Cournot oligopoly
Intro: We revisit the classic discussion of the comparison between tax and quota policies, but in a free-entry Cournot oligopoly. We investigate a quantity ceiling regulation as a quota policy. We find that the tax policy dominates the quota policy in free entry markets. Taxation and quotas are major alternative policies for regulators in many situations such as international trade, environmental damages and resources control, and industry policies. Many studies compare the two policies in various contexts and some of them investigate this problem in the context of oligopoly.Footnote 1 In this paper, we consider a Cournot oligopoly model with free entry.Footnote 2 We compare specific taxation policy and quota policy that restricts the upper limit of output of each firm. First, we present results of short-run analysis as a benchmark. We investigate an oligopoly market in which the number of firms is given exogenously. We show the equivalence of two policies with respect to the equilibrium aggregate quantity and welfare. Next, we present results of long-run analysis. We show the equivalence of two policies with respect to the equilibrium aggregate quantity. We find, however, that specific taxation dominates volume quotas from the welfare viewpoint. This is because quotas increases the number of entering firms and increases the welfare loss caused by excessive entries pointed by Mankiw and Whinston (1986) and Suzumura and Kiyono (1987).Footnote 3 Note that, in our model, a welfare function (or a government preference function) is defined as a weighted sum of consumers’ and producers’ surpluses, the governmental tax revenue, and externality. Thus, a variety of preferences of government can be represented by the function. Our main result holds for any preference of government that can be represented by the function. In the literature, many works have already pointed out that welfare implications of public policies in free entry markets are in sharp contrast with those in non-entry markets.Footnote 4 Our result suggests that this is true in the context of tax-quota policies, too. The quota policy is more harmful than the tax policy in free entry markets.

Title: Comparing Cournot and Bertrand equilibria in an asymmetric duopoly with product R&D
The cost effect in third-degree price discrimination
Intro:
One of the best known results in the Industrial Organization literature is that an output expansion is a necessary condition for welfare to increase with third-degree price discrimination. The study of the welfare implications of price discrimination may be traced back to Robinson (1933), and Schmalensee (1981), assuming that firms operate with constant marginal costs. The contributions in this strand of the literature discuss the existence of an output effect, of uncertain sign, and a misallocation effect, which is always negative. The former effect depends on whether total output varies with discrimination, and the latter effect arises because of the fact that discrimination induces the monopolist to transfer output from the market with greater marginal valuation to the market where marginal valuation is lower. Schmalensee (1981) concludes that the net welfare effect will be positive only if total output expands, although this does not constitute a sufficient condition for welfare to improve. Later, Varian (1985) generalizes this result to interdependent markets and increasing marginal costs and Schwartz  (1990) proves this result for decreasing marginal costs. More recent contributions have studied particular aspects of the effect of price discrimination on welfare. For instance, Aguirre et al.  (2010), assuming constant marginal costs, present sufficient conditions for price discrimination to have a positive effect on welfare. Assuming a risk-averse monopolist operating in markets with demands that are subject to uncertainty and possibly correlated, Anam and Chiang (2006) find that it is possible to observe a decrease in output together with an increase in welfare. A similar result was obtained in Eckel and Smith (1992), studying the problem of a multiproduct monopoly facing random, correlated demands. Our contribution is to stress the fact that non-constant marginal costs, together with demand uncertainty may reverse the established relationship between output and welfare. Specifically, we will show that introducing a small level of uncertainty in just one of the markets may lead to a decrease of expected output with price discrimination while expected welfare increases. Central to our analysis is the interplay between non-constant costs and demand uncertainty. Assuming increasing marginal costs, demand uncertainty leads to an increase in the monopolist’s expected cost. Thus, a new effect appears in the analysis, which we will refer to as a cost effect. In order for this cost effect to appear, two conditions are necessary: non-constant marginal costs, and the monopolist choosing prices before demand is realized. In this setting, price discrimination provides the firm with an additional degree of freedom, which it may use to reduce costs, given that marginal costs are non-constant. The relevant question is whether this cost effect may more than offset the sum of the negative output and misallocation effects. In this article, we present an example in which this is the case. Hence, our result applies to markets in which the monopolist is unable to adjust prices facing demand fluctuations within a given market, but may price discriminate across markets. In the presence of increasing marginal costs, the monopolist may be able to reduce expected costs under price discrimination by reducing total expected output. We will see by means of an example that this cost reduction may more than offset the negative output and misallocation effects of price discrimination. In this paper, we depart from the usual assumption of constant marginal costs. While it is reasonable to assume constant marginal costs for some given range of production, variations in demand may introduce a wide dispersion in the range of production, which makes the assumption of constant marginal costs less plausible. Additionally, uncertainty itself may be a factor making other relevant costs, such as marketing, organizational costs, or stocking costs grow more than proportionally with output. For instance, analyzing the particular case of inventory costs, Chopra and Sodhi (2004) argue that using inventory to cover a high level of demand risk costs much more than covering a low level of demand risk. Thus, an industry that has a constant marginal cost structure may become one with an increasing marginal cost structure due to the necessity of accumulating and keeping stocks facing demand uncertainty. In fact, non-constant marginal cost are common in industries such as electric power generation. In this particular industry, producers have large plants, such as nuclear plants, capable of servicing a significant proportion of total demand. However, if demand increases above a certain level, then producers may make use of smaller gas or coal plants so as to service this additional demand. The marginal cost of these plants is much higher than that of nuclear plants. Furthermore, storing electricity is still technically difficult, inefficient and costly.Footnote 1
 On the demand side, producers of electricity usually have two kind of customers: on the one hand, industrial companies that buy large amounts of electricity, and on the other, households or small firms whose consumption levels are lower. In this market, price discrimination is key for the electricity producer to maximize profits. Furthermore, demand is highly uncertain, especially household demand, since it depends on factors such as the weather and other factors that cannot be foreseen by the producer. Additionally, there is an important seasonal component of demand, although this demand variability is not of uncertain nature. Many other markets include submarkets with demands that have different degrees of uncertainty. Consider, for example, the market for water. Usually, water prices for households, industry and agriculture differ, given that the latter is highly dependent on the amount of rainfall. Another example is that of an ice-cream producer. There are regions with relatively stable weather, and thus, relatively stable demands, and other regions in which the demand of ice-cream depends on more uncertain weather. Moreover, hotels, airlines, or rental car companies try to charge different prices for different types of customers. In this industry, demand from occasional customers is more uncertain at least during non-vacation periods. Thus, there are many examples of industries where firms face different demand functions in different submarkets and with different degrees of uncertainty. Finally, we would like to emphasize that our results also apply to settings in which demand variations are not caused by uncertainty. In particular, our analysis would also apply to demand subject to seasonal fluctuations. As long as demand fluctuates, and marginal costs are increasing with output, the cost effect appears. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the concept of the cost effect. Section 3 presents an example where this effect is responsible for an increase in expected welfare under price discrimination even though expected output decreases. Finally, Sect. 4 concludes the article.

Title: A pre-emption model of mergers
Intro:
The literature on mergers and acquisitions (M&A) indicates that a not insignificant proportion of merging firms, or at least the acquirers of these firms, do not benefit from acquisitions, regardless of whether the value of these M&A’s are measured according to short-run or long-run event windows employing stock price data or according to accounting-based measures.Footnote 1 For instance, Andrade et al. (2001) find that in 17.5 % of all M&As, the acquiring firms reported a less than \(-5~\%\) announcement return. Similar results are shown in the numerous M&A event studies found in the literature. Studies have shown that, for up to five years following mergers, acquiring firms (that is, the combined acquirer and target firm) earn a statistically significant, abnormal, negative return. This is the post-merger underperformance puzzle widely known in the literature. On the other hand, a positive abnormal return on shares is often observed for the target company, known as the “acquisition premium”. Such value destroying M&As are also documented by the popular media. For example, the Economist reports: “ ...there is the old, nagging question about whether mergers make business sense. Much navel-gazing followed the great merger frenzy of the 1990s, as the board of directors–their own mergers in ruins–solemnly dusted down old studies showing that mergers usually destroy value. Only this week, the Boston Consulting Group put out research showing that, of 277 big M&A deals in America between 1985 and 2000, 64  % destroyed value for the acquirers’ shareholders.” (The Economist 2006, July 12, Vol. 368, The Return of the Deal) 
Stigler (1950) first realized that it might be advantageous for firms to stay outside a merger since outside rival firms can free-ride on the lessened competition due to merger. Salant and Reynolds (1983) formally modeled this free-riding effect in a Cournot setting which is known in the theoretical literature as the “merger paradox”.Footnote 2
 In the current paper, a sequential bargaining model where a target firm makes a proposition to each potential acquirers is used to interpret the value destroying M&As when the possibility of pre-empting rivals is of primary concern. When the target firm sequentially presents propositions to the two acquirers, the first potential acquirer may end up overpaying the target firm (value-destroying M&A) since it does not know the rival acquirer’s synergy which is the rival’s private information. When the first potential acquirer turns down this take-or-leave-it offer, the second candidate acquirer always makes nonnegative gains from the bargaining process. When the first acquirer accepts the offer, the rival firm may gain or lose. In the current paper, it is also shown that overpaying does exist and that it serves as the main source of value destroying in a merger. In particular, in this paper, we show that the winner’s curse like overpaying never occurs in a simultaneous competitive bidding process but that it may arise in the target firm initiated sequential negotiations; and if the merger is successful, then it is never value destroying for the combined firm. Thus the acquirer’s overpayment is not the ‘winner’s curse’ that resulted from the post-announcement competitive bidding but rather is due to the strengthened bargaining power the target gains from the sequential negotiation process. In contrast, most existing studies on the merger paradox attempt to disprove the value-destroying nature of mergers. There is however another strand of literature that accepts the paradox and offers interpretations as to why value-destroying mergers take place. These include various interpretations in management, finance and economics literature.Footnote 3 One explanation for such puzzles is firms’ pre-emptive motives, for example in studies by Molnár (2007), Akdogu (2011), Fishman (1988), Toxvaerd (2008) and Fridolfsson and Stennek (2005). If a merger confers strong negative externalities to firms outside the merger, then it is better to become an “insider” than an “outsider”. This pre-emption theory says that the pre-emption can be optimal even if the acquiring firm has to overpay relative to the increase in the combined profits of the merged firm. This is because by pre-empting an outside rival firm’s bid, the acquiring firm avoids a larger (hypothetical) loss that would result from this rival merger. Such overpayment results obtained in Molnár (2007), are based on the assumption that synergiesFootnote 4 are public information and pairwise symmetric. In realistic situations, however, synergies may be private information and asymmetric, meaning the synergy gained from a merger can be firm specific. Furthermore, such overpaying is vulnerable to collusion among the bidders in the competitive bidding setup. In Akdogu (2011), the synergy is private information but a negative externality is assumed exogenously, hence overpaying is a natural consequence. However, a merger does not necessarily only result in a negative externality, i.e., the positive externality may outweigh the negative one depending on the degree and nature of the synergies. On the other hand, the literature on pre-emption perceived that being an outsider may be disadvantageous to a merger (Akdogu 2011; Brito 2003; Molnár 2007). Akdogu points out that there “must be an intuition that losing a target to a competitor is costly.” Nevertheless, empirical studies confirm that overpaying (through competitive bidding) is the main source of the post-merger underperformance puzzle.Footnote 5 The fact that overpaying persists,Footnote 6 together with the theoretical result of the nonexistence of overpaying in the competitive bidding models lead us to rethink the setup of the M&A models. In the current paper, we consider that the target firm approaches potential acquirers sequentially, negotiating on a one-on-one basis. More rigorously, we show that overpaying occurs in the sequential setup, but never arises in the traditional simultaneous competitive bidding setup, when synergies are private information. And the result is invariant to the auction forms because of revenue equivalence theorem. The finance literature on these cumulative abnormal returns on the acquirers and targets has mainly focused on the post-public announcement period of the takeover process. A recent study by Boone and Mulherin (2007) reveals that the process during the pre-public announcement takeover period is much more competitive and sophisticated than previously thought. In particular, they find that half of the target firms privately contacted multiple potential buyers prior to the public announcement (21 bidders on average). That the target firms initiated the sequential negotiations in corporate takeovers is nothing new.Footnote 7 A large proportion of corporate takeovers begin with target firms negotiating with bidders on a one-on-one basis. If the negotiation succeeds, target shareholders should benefit in the form of higher abnormal returns. Notice that, in fact, most M&As are friendly. The Economist
Footnote 8 reports that only 4 % of deals struck in the year 2000 were deemed hostile or unsolicited, and even during the hostile days it was still below 20 %. Furthermore, studies show that target firms’ management often manipulates the takeovers to benefit themselves for example, by negotiating large cash payments, special bonuses, or golden parachutes (see e.g. Hartzell et al. 2004, among others). Several theoretical studies show that the method a firm’s sale has some impact on the expected wealth changes for target shareholders (e.g., Hirshleifer and Png 1989; Bulow and Klemperer 1996; Ye 2008). Bulow and Klemperer (1996) prove that the single bidder negotiations may outperform simultaneous bidding when bidders’ signals are not independent. Povel and Singh (2006) show that targets can profit from a sequential one-on-one negotiation mechanism when bidders have asymmetric valuation. They consider a timing similar to ours in which the target firm sequentially solicits bids from potential buyers. The key difference is that their framework is in a common value environment, while ours resembles a private value setting. Our results, therefore, complement those of Povel and Singh (2006) and Bulow and Klemperer (1996). In summary, this paper complements the existing literature on pre-emptive M&As in the following ways. First, we show that, in the presence of private information on synergies, a competitive bidding process does not lead to overpaying the target firm. Second, the current model uses a sequential-bargaining model to interpret value destroying M&As. In some cases, the sequential bargaining setting results in overpaying. But in the current paper, the intuition differs significantly in that overpaying does not occur ex ante to an acquirer, whereas in existing preemptive models overpaying systematically persists. Third, in some papers mergers are triggered by changes in industrywide market conditions, such as demand shocks, where in our model mergers occur in equilibrium in the absence of exogenous triggers. Related to the current paper, Zhao (2009a) argues that transaction costs and/or an empty core may explain why some profitable mergers do not take place. Zhao (2004) shows that, in a Bertrand setting that mergers that attain sufficiently large cost savings will reduce the outsiders’ profits. We show that in a Cournot setting, such synergies can also reduce an outsider’s profit, and thus, mergers tend to be pre-emptive. Zhao (2009b) considers the optimal number of firms in the presence of scale economies, which has implications on an antitrust authority’s position over merger applications, regardless of whether a particular merger is profitable or not. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the model. Section 3 gives the nonexistence results of a simultaneous bidding environment. Section 4 extends the basic model to multiple bidders and production differentiation. Section 5 concludes.

Title: Kaplow, Louis: Competition policy and price fixing
Precautionary saving under many risks
Sequential procurement auctions with risk-averse suppliers
Intro:
Governments delegate the provision of a wide range of public infrastructure to the private sector. Such infrastructure consists of physical facilities (e.g., railways, schools, hospitals) and public services (e.g., transportation, education, medical services). An essential aspect of infrastructure provision is that it is a multi-stage process. A public facility is designed, built, and operated over a long period of time as it delivers services to the public. Inevitably, an infrastructure project involves many kinds of uncertainty. Risk sharing between public authorities and private contractors is thus a key factor for a successful project. The government must find an efficient procedure for procurement. The purpose of this paper is to compare the performance of two procurement mechanisms, bundling and unbundling, and to investigate the choice problem of a mechanism. In many construction projects, a public authority has the option of choosing between a bundling method called “design-build” and an unbundling method called “design-bid-build.” Under the design-build method, a private party called a design-builder, which may be organized by a group of companies, is responsible for performing tasks of both design and construction.Footnote 1 Similarly, contractual arrangements called “public-private partnerships (PPPs)” are characterized by bundled tasks. Under the design-bid-build method, the two tasks are separated. Architects draw the initial design, and then bidders are invited to submit bids for the construction. While unbundling methods have been employed traditionally in public procurement, there is a recent trend towards bundling methods. There is an ongoing debate about the two methods. It is often said that the bundling method transfers risks from public authorities to private parties so that the private parties are motivated to invest more. However, the risk transfer may become excessive and, as a result, the public authority must pay a higher risk premium in exchange for shifting the burden of risk to private parties. See Gibson et al. (2007) and Iossa et al. (2007) for more about these methods and detailed arguments in the debate. It remains an open question, theoretically and practically, which of the bundling and unbundling methods is most desirable for a public authority and for society. We analyze the procurement problem in a two-stage auction model with risks. A risk-neutral buyer procures a public infrastructure project from risk-averse suppliers. The investment stage is followed by the production stage. In a bundling mechanism, the buyer holds a single auction. In an unbundling mechanism, the buyer holds two sequential auctions. Each auction adopts a first-price format. A distinctive feature of our model is that it has two categories of production risks. The first category is an aggregate risk. The risk is common to all suppliers. The second one is an idiosyncratic risk. The risk is specific to each supplier. Each supplier’s production cost is affected by the two risk factors as well as by the cost-reducing investment. After the cost-reducing investment is made, the realized value of the aggregate risk is commonly known to all suppliers, and each supplier privately knows the realized value of the idiosyncratic risk to him. 
Yescombe (2007) provides many examples of aggregate risk and idiosyncratic risk in construction projects. He classifies risks into several categories related to sites, construction, and completion. Site risks including ground conditions are typical examples of aggregate risk. If the geology of a site turns out not to be as expected, then piling is required for foundations. Design risks in the category of completion are other examples of aggregate risk. If there is a flaw in the design drawings, then all builders are damaged. Market uncertainty such as fluctuations in material prices, political uncertainty, and climate conditions are other examples of aggregate risk. Many uncertain elements in economic, financial, labor and organizational conditions of construction companies constitute idiosyncratic risk to them. For instance, a construction company may be uncertain of the technical ability of its hired subcontractors. If the subcontractors are not able to do the construction work properly, then the constructor must bear additional costs. The main result of this paper is as follows. The bundling mechanism is optimal for the buyer and also socially desirable if the aggregate risk is below certain thresholds. The result may not hold true for the idiosyncratic risk. Key factors leading to the result are the differences in risk sharing, information rents, and investment incentives between the bundling and unbundling mechanisms. In the bundling mechanism, all the risks are assumed by a single supplier, the winner of the auction. The buyer has to pay a high risk premium to the winner, while the mechanism implements the efficient investment. In contrast, the unbundling mechanism provides little incentive for the investment due to a moral hazard problem. The buyer must pay risk premia for the idiosyncratic risk indirectly through the payment of information rents. The buyer pays no risk premium for the aggregate risk because the risk is transferred from the suppliers to the buyer through the second-stage auction. Therefore, a decrease in the aggregate risk is beneficial to the buyer and society only in the bundling mechanism, unlike the idiosyncratic risk. A decrease in the idiosyncratic risk reduces the information rents in the unbundling mechanism if the idiosyncratic risk is exponentially distributed. Based on the result above, we can provide the following policy recommendation on the choice of procurement mechanisms: A public authority should not lump all possible risks together, but classify them into aggregate risks and idiosyncratic risks. A low aggregate risk for a project is a strong reason to choose a bundling method from the viewpoints of both the public authority and society. On the contrary, when a project’s idiosyncratic risk is low, it may be recommended for the authority to choose an unbundling method rather than a bundling method. 
Kay (2009) reports a real case of a construction project that is relevant for our result. During 1996–2004, a new metro system called Tren Urbano was constructed in Puerto Rico. The 10.7-mile metro line connects the cities of San Juan, Guaynabo, and Bayamón. The Puerto Rico Highway and Transit Authority (PRHTA) split the civil work into seven sections, and employed design-build methods (i.e., bundling) in all sections. Prior to requesting proposals for the design-build contract, the PRHTA investigated geotechnical conditions significantly. The research outcome was shared by prospective bidders, and it reduced aggregate risks to them. This paper is related to several previous studies in the literature which also considered the choice problem of bundling and unbundling mechanisms. Hart (2003) presents an incomplete contract model and shows that a bundling mechanism gives a supplier strong incentives for socially productive and unproductive investments. His result is supported experimentally by Hoppe et al. (2013). Li and Yu (2011) present an auction model similar to ours, and examine how the optimality of a bundling mechanism is affected by the competition among suppliers. Martimort and Pouyet (2008) show that the buyer’s optimal choice is a bundling mechanism if a quality-enhancing effort in the first stage reduces production costs. In a second-price auction model, Grimm (2007) shows that the buyer always prefers a bundling mechanism with subcontracting to an unbundling mechanism in the case of risk-neutral suppliers. Unlike all works mentioned above, this paper focuses on risk sharing between the buyer and suppliers in the choice of a procurement mechanism, and shows that aggregate risk and idiosyncratic risk have different effects on the choice of mechanism. Finally, our result is closely related to the “yardstick competition effect” studied by Auriol and Laffont (1992). As in their regulation model, the unbundling mechanism in our model has the yardstick competition effect in the sense that information on aggregate risk is revealed to the buyer through the second-stage auction. Owing to the information revelation, the unbundling mechanism becomes beneficial to the buyer. This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents a two-stage auction model. Sections 3 and 4 characterize an equilibrium of the model under each mechanism. Section 5 gives the main results. Section 6 discusses an extension of the model. Section 7 is the conclusion. All proofs are given in the Appendix.

Title: Equal, proportional, and mixed sharing of cooperative production under the threat of sabotage
Intro:
Modern compensation schemes frequently depend to a large extent on either individual (if observable) or relative (in comparison to others) performance measures, i.e. a significant part of salaries is usually provided as variable compensation. This dependence of the individual salary on the respective performance is in general justified by incentive motivations, for instance, to reduce free-riding behavior; see Prendergast (1999).
