The peculiarity of our growth model lies in the way technological progress occurs: a new intermediate variety is the outcome of a successful process of search and matching between entrepreneurs (or innovators), who come up with new ideas and capitalists (or financiers), who select what they believe are the most promising ideas and help launch them in the market. In particular, entrepreneurs and financiers meet pairwise and, once a successful matching has occurred, they bargain over the distribution of the monopoly rents associated with the “discovery” of the new intermediate good variety. The model studies the occupational choice of economic agents. Agents have to decide whether to work in the final good sector or in the “industry of ideas”. In this last case, they can choose to devote their time to come up with a new idea, and hence to become entrepreneurs. Alternatively, they may opt for screening and selecting the most valuable ideas deserving financial funds, in which case they become capitalists. We find the employment allocation across the three occupational possibilities of this economy along the balanced growth path: manufacturing, entrepreneurial and capitalistic activities. This allocation is found by imposing that, at equilibrium, the expected returns from each of these activities be identical. We show that the financial market for innovation is characterized by a complementary relationship between entrepreneurs and financiers, in that the number of entrepreneurs is increasing in the number of financiers, and viceversa. The intuition for this result is straightforward: a higher number of financiers simply raises the entrepreneur’s chance of having her own project being selected and financed, and thus it raises the incentive to become entrepreneur, and viceversa. Because of this thick market externality, we cannot exclude the possibility that the economy admits multiple stationary equilibria. The equilibrium employment allocation is then compared to the optimal allocation obtained through the welfare analysis. The amount of total labor resources that the market allocates to entrepreneurial innovation is sub-optimal and, moreover, it is inefficiently distributed between entrepreneurs and capitalists. In particular, in addition to the usual externalities associated with the class of horizontal innovation models à la (Romer 1990), our model allows us to evaluate the welfare effects of the search frictions in the market for innovation. As we will clarifly in Sect. 5, the occupational choice of each economic agent affects the payoff and the choice of all other agents. In particular, the entry of an entrepreneur stimulates the entry of capitalists (“easy matching effect”) and discourages the entry of additional entrepreneurs (“stepping on toes effect”), and a symmetric reasoning applies to the entry of a capitalist. Moroever, the fact that the allocation of the monopoly rents is made according to a Nash bargaining process between entrepreneurs and financiers introduces an additional source of frictions: the bargaining power of each agent does not necessarily reflect their marginal productivity in the innovation process. The overall effect on the market of innovation, which is not internalized by either entrepreneurs or capitalists when making their choices, may be positive or negative. As a result, total market-driven innovative efforts may be higher or lower than optimal. The existence of these external effects is an additional reason for the policy maker to intervene in the innovation sector. The modeling strategy that we follow in this paper is meant to capture some salient features of the financial market for innovation. In the words of (Phelps 2009, p. 50), “the classical supply-and-demand apparatus does not apply to the core market of capitalist economies—the capital market, particularly the market for capital going to entrepreneurs’ innovative projects”. It takes time and resources for an entrepreneur to find and convince a financier about the profitability of her business venture. At the same time, it takes time and resources for a financier to find the innovative project that she believes is worth financing. The financial market for innovation is then, probably, better represented as a decentralized market where heterogeneous entrepreneurs and financiers meet bilaterally according to a matching technology. Again in the words of (Phelps 2009, p. 52), “the capital market is a sort of matching process that matches a financier to an entrepreneur who the former sees as having a model compatible with his own model”. The search and matching process is a modeling tool that allows us to represent succintly all frictions characterizing the process of financing innovation—such as information imperfections, or the entrepreneurs’ and capitalists’ heterogeneities in skills, location, beliefs etc.Footnote 2
 This representation of the financing relationship is also especially apt to describe the practical functioning of the modern venture capital (VC) industry, where a financed entreprenerial project is the result of a meeting between an entrepreneur submitting her business plan, and a VC fund that is expected to bring managerial and/or technical expertise together with financial investments (see for instance Gompers and Lerner (1999)). Venture capital is a relatively novel model of innovation financing, and it complements the more traditional, corporate R&D model. A debate is open as to whether entrepreneurial finance is going to replace corporate R&D as the new standard of financing innovation. On the one hand, the former still represents a tiny fraction of the latter (Lerner 2010). On the other hand, evidence suggests that entrepreneurial investments are growing faster and are more productive than R&D investments.Footnote 3 Moreover, they are disproportianately concentrated in the most innovative industries (ICT, biotechnology and, more recently, energy and environment). Our model can be interpreted as a first attempt to introduce, into an endogenous growth model, a role for the venture capital sector as the engine of economic growth. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 further discusses the related literature. Section 3 describes the model, while Sect. 4 characterizes the balanced growth path(s) of the economy and carries out the comparative statics analysis. Section 5 carries out the welfare analysis and discusses the policy implications. Section 6 concludes with a few remarks.

Title: The stochastic Mitra–Wan forestry model: risk neutral and risk averse cases
Rossi, Peter E.: Bayesian non- and semi-parametric methods and applications
Competition, innovation, and the effect of R&D knowledge
Intro:
Innovation is an instrument for competitive advantage and often seen as one or even the engine for growth. Therefore, it is crucial to understand its determinants. Competition and innovation are intimately connected. This relation is twofold. On the one hand incentives to innovate are driven by the competitive situation. On the other hand successful innovations affect and thus change the market structure. The link between product market competition and innovation has been studied for a long time. The classic contributions of Schumpeter and Arrow shaped the corresponding polar positions of competition hindering innovation (often attributed to Schumpeter) on the one hand and competition spurring innovation (often attributed to Arrow) on the other hand.Footnote 1 Research on this issue deals with the fundamental question whether higher intensity of competition leads to higher or lower innovative efforts by each firm. In addition to the question whether incentives to innovate are increasing or decreasing with more intense market competition the question on the endogenous evolution of the market is to be addressed. Leaving aside changes in the number of firms (due to entry, exit or mergers and acquisitions), this reduces to the question on the evolution of differences between incumbent firms. Is one firm becoming more and more efficient leaving other firms behind or do we see neck-and-neck competition? Casual observations and empirical evidence suggest a process of action-reaction in markets, i.e., market leadership is constantly changing hands. In theoretical analyses different modeling strategies lead to widely differing conclusions.Footnote 2
 However, most of this literature seems to leave out some important aspects. It neglects that past experience in R&D usually has an impact on current success. Considering only one innovation project or several projects separately omits the fact that a level of technological competence may be valuable for following projects. On the one hand, the success in preceding projects helps in securing income. Beyond that, the pure experience of these projects improves performance in other projects. This is due to experience, learning-by-doing, users’ feedback etc. Our approach tries to identify the effect of experience in R&D in a stylized model designed to capture the essentials of the problem. We develop a dynamic model with history dependency. History affects market opportunities, i.e., previous actions and outcomes determine the range of available actions and outcomes. This is modeled in a way that a firm’s investment in R&D does not only increase the chance of making a discovery, but additionally increases the R&D knowledge stock.Footnote 3 This knowledge stock is a measure of firm’s past R&D effort and allows modeling learning, i.e., firm’s past experiences add to its current capabilities, and organizational forgetting in R&D.Footnote 4 Learning-by-doing has been observed in many empirical works.Footnote 5 In practice learning may occur when the innovation activities of a firm are adjusted due to past experiences or when innovation projects are cumulative, i.e., sequential and building on each other. An example would be an investment in laboratory equipment which could be used for other than the current project or gained experience of the researchers. Organizational forgetting in R&D on the other hand is a phenomenon that has been shown in more recent studies and is also crucial for R&D.Footnote 6 Sticking to the idea of knowledge capturing the experience of the workers, organizational forgetting would be the result of turnover and layoffs. When there is organizational forgetting, a firm’s accumulated knowledge depreciates over time. As described, firms’ continuous investment in R&D creates the permanent possibility of a successful innovation. These innovations come in successive steps, i.e., a step has to be completed to proceed. Due to the “step-by-step” innovations a technological laggard must first catch up with the leading-edge technology before battling for technological leadership in the future. This in turn implies that if we do not see a process of increasing dominance then every once in a while competition will be neck-and-neck and therefore the escape competition effect will be strongest.Footnote 7 With respect to the product market, we assume the industry to be characterized by a duopoly where firms are competing in prices. The incumbent firms simultaneously engage in R&D in order to decrease their relative costs. The main research focus of the model where history and dynamics are essential is the effect of experience on the firms’ incentives to invest in innovation activities. How does this effect influence the evolution of market structure over time? What are the effects of competition in innovation on market structure? Does one firm become increasingly dominant by being more successful in R&D, i.e., do we see a process of increasing dominance, or is there a process of action reaction, in which market leadership is constantly changing hands? Above all we wish to discover when competition in innovation is most intense. Starting with the benchmark case without learning we show that relaxing the usual assumption of imposing imitation adds strategic effects. Usually it is assumed that the follower at least catches up with the frontier technology with one successful innovation. Without this exogenous possibility of immediate imitation the leader’s R&D effort is increasing with the lead while the laggard’s effort is decreasing. The industry’s leader is trying to avoid competition in the future while the reduced prospect of moving ahead diminishes incentives for the follower. Nevertheless, leaders always invest less and hence a process of action reaction results. Allowing for knowledge accumulation via learning-by-doing adds another effect. If one firm has accumulated enough knowledge, its chances to successfully innovate are increased and therefore further R&D effort is less rewarding. The leading firm can afford to rest on its laurels and hence, in steady state the firm invests less the higher the technological lead. The knowledge effect outweighs the increased incentive for the leader to innovate in order to avoid competition. This may induce the follower to catch up. With respect to product market competition our findings are in line with Arrow’s position of competition spurring innovation. In our framework we clearly find that due to the effect of knowledge accumulation the incentives to perform R&D are increasing with the intensity of competition. As mentioned earlier, the relation between competition and innovation has been studied for decades and hence literature on this issue is very extensive. However, neither theoretical nor empirical research has led to a clear result on this link. In empirical literature some support for the theory that predictions are highly specific to characteristics of innovations and the mechanism to protect the value created by new technologies can be found. One reason why empirical studies have not generated clear conclusions about the relationship might be a failure of many of these studies to account for different market and technological conditions (see for example Cohen and Levin 1989 and Gilbert 2006, for surveys). We will discuss this issue in the lights of the results of our model in the respective sections. Regarding economic theory, in addition to Sutton’s work on industrial market structure (Sutton 1991, 1998, 2007), the voluminous literature dealing with static models (see for example Vives 2008; Belleflamme and Vergari 2011 and Bondt and Vandekerckhove 2012 for important recent advances), this paper is especially related to the literature on dynamic evolution of oligopoly.Footnote 8
Budd et al. (1993) present a work that analyzes whether the gap between two firms in a model of dynamic competition tends to increase or decrease. While modeling the gap in terms of an abstract (bounded) state of competition parameter without modeling the product market explicitly they find that the gap tends to evolve into the direction where joint payoffs are greater. This most often results in a process of increasing dominance. Cabral and Riordan (1994) provide further indications of increasing dominance. Segal and Whinston (2007) study the effects of antitrust in a dynamic R&D model based on “winner-take-all” competition. Denicolò and Zanchettin (2012) develop a model of leapfrogging where an incumbent competes against potential entrants in a sequence of patent races. Due to the replacement effect the leaders’ share in total R&D as well as the size of their lead decreases within each leadership cycle. Articles analyzing industry evolution when there is learning-by-doing like Dasgupta and Stiglitz (1988) and Cabral and Riordan (1994, 1997) usually simply model cost reduction as a function of output decisions.Footnote 9 Basically, firms learn by producing not by researching and developing. That means it becomes less costly for the leader to gain higher profits as the lead widens. With this way of modeling R&D is complementary with production. Besides, organizational forgetting cannot be modeled in these frameworks. Our work is also related to the literature on patent races (see Reinganum 1989, for an early summary). Due to the endpoint that players are aiming for, usually the property of increasing dominance results. This characteristic remains in multistage race models, where several stages are introduced into a patent race, as there is still a definite end.Footnote 10 To the best of our knowledge Doraszelski (2003) was the first to introducing knowledge accumulation into patent races. However, his model builds on a patent race à la Reinganum (1989) where the firm that makes the innovation first is awarded a patent of positive value and the game ends. Hence, product market competition is not modeled and questions concerning the relation of competition and innovation cannot be addressed. Additionally, the game cannot be solved analytically. In contrast, we model step-by-step innovation and product market competition. Thus, there is no endpoint firms are aiming for and a successful innovation always enhances the firms’ market position such that innovation incentives are driven by the way that firms’ profits rise and fall as competition evolves. The aim of this analysis is to gain insights into the forces at work in the general case where profits vary with the state of competition. Regarding dynamic step-by-step innovation, our work is most closely related to and extends the works of Aghion et al. (2001) and Acemoglu and Akcigit (2012). Although our model builds on these papers, it also differs from them in significant ways. Most importantly, our main research regards the effect of experience in R&D. Therefore, we extend the model to learning-by-doing and organizational forgetting. Besides, we do not imply the strong assumptions on imitation as Aghion et al. (2001) and Acemoglu and Akcigit (2012). These authors assume the follower at least catches up with the frontier technology with one successful innovation.Footnote 11 Thus, in contrast to our model strategic incentives to perform R&D are absent. Acemoglu and Akcigit (2012) show numerically, based on the model of Aghion et al. (2001), that optimal intellectual property rights policy provides more protection to firms that are technologically more advanced as this policy strengthens the escape competition effect. Obviously, R&D by firms that are sufficiently ahead is encouraged just as well as effort by companies with a limited lead because of their prospect of reaching levels of gaps associated with higher protection. That is to say, the effect of avoiding competition that is absent in the basic model is introduced by means of intellectual property rights policy. Based on the work of Aghion et al. (2001), (2005) analyze the relationship between product market competition and innovation. However, they only allow for two possible states (one step behind and neck-to-neck). In a related work Hörner (2004) develops a model allowing a firm to be an arbitrary number of steps ahead or behind. His contribution and the effect of a firm being sufficiently far ahead suggests that an analysis à la Aghion et al. (2005) with only two possible states leaves out some aspects. Unfortunately, Hörner does not model product market competition. Our work differs from all of the above papers as we consider the effects of learning-by-doing and organizational forgetting in R&D with firms competing on the product market. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents the basic model. Section 3 provides an analysis of optimal R&D when accumulation of knowledge is not possible. In this section we also compare our result to the one of the related framework of Aghion et al. (2001). Section 4 analyzes the equilibrium R&D investment when the effect of knowledge accumulation is at place and compares it with the benchmark case without knowledge. Section 5 concludes while the appendix contains the proofs of the results stated in the text.

Title: Competing R&D joint ventures in Cournot oligopoly with spillovers
Intro:
R&D cooperation has become increasingly important in the last 30 years, and is now a common means for organizing R&D in industries like IT, telecommunications, electronics, biotechnology, software, and chemicals (Hagerdoon 1996; Hagerdoon et al. 2000; Caloghirou et al. 2003). Underlying the vast literature on non cooperative vs. cooperative R&D is the claim that R&D cooperation may be beneficial for society for at least three reasons. First, it requires the integration of otherwise overlapping activities and hence encourages R&D efficiency at the industry level. In addition, it takes into account the direct (that is to say, non pecuniary) effects of individual research on the aggregate profit of the venture, which is positive under technological externalities. Finally, it may create synergies and hence provide firms with a superior R&D technology. A widely accepted and robust result is that for technological externalities above a threshold, R&D cooperation results in a larger level of R&D investment and a lower price in the product market than R&D competition. This point has been illustrated at length, but almost exclusively for the case in which R&D cooperation is represented by a unique, industry-wide R&D cartel (e.g., see d’Aspremont and Jacquemin 1998; Suzumura 1992; Kamien et al. 1992; Leahy and Neary 1997; Amir 2000; Amir et al. 2003, among many others).Footnote 1 Surprisingly, the case of R&D cartel competition has received very little attention in the literature. However, the observed pattern of R&D cartelization in many industries is very complex. Clodt et al. (2010) report that in the software industry of the late 90s, the top ten firms in terms of number of R&D agreements ranged from Microsoft, with 89 partnerships, to Oracle, with 25. Similarly, Gugler and Siebert (2007) report that between 1989 and 1999 there have been 244 R&D joint ventures in the semiconductors industry, with average number of participating firms of 2.99. Analogous evidence is found for other high tech industries. These networks of cooperative relations are typically centered on a few leading firms, which often are competitors at the R&D phase. An example of competition among R&D cooperatives in the early 80s is that between the research joint venture including Boeing, Mitsubishi, Kawasaki, and other firms, and the Airbus consortium. A more recent and often reported example is the competition between three consortiums of firms for the development of the HDTV system in the US.Footnote 2
 An important exception in the literature is the paper by Kamien and Zang (1993), which studies competing R&D cartels. In that paper, R&D cartels exploit cooperative synergies, in the sense that the spillover rate within an R&D cartel is \(1\), while that between R&D cartels is \( \theta \le 1\). This form of cooperation is often called Cartelized R&D Joint Venture (henceforth RJV). For the case of linear demand in the product market, Kamien and Zang show that effective R&D, and hence consumer surplus, is the highest under either the industry-wide RJV or exactly two competing RJV’s, depending on whether \(\theta \) is respectively larger or smaller than a threshold. To my knowledge, no other study has elaborated on this result,Footnote 3 and many important points that have been extensively analyzed for the case of industry-wide R&D cooperation remain open for that of R&D cartel competition. This paper considers a simple model of R&D where firms participate to competing R&D cartels and then compete in a Cournot market for an homogeneous good. It provides an evaluation of alternative cartel structures ranging from industry-wide cooperation to R&D competition in terms of R&D results, consumer surplus, industry profit, and social welfare. It also compares equilibrium and second best levels of R&D, and hence outlines the policy implications of the results. This paper extends Kamien and Zang in three directions. First, it adopts a relatively general demand function, using conditions from the recent theory of Cournot markets that weaken the usual assumption of linear demand in a substantial way (e.g., see Amir 1996; Vives 2001). This also allows to represent the results in terms of the negative of the slope of the reaction function at the equilibrium in the product market, \(\rho \), which is here interpreted as a measure of contestability of that market through R&D. Second, besides consumer surplus, the paper also considers a second best criterion of evaluation, wherein the level of R&D is set to maximize social welfare conditional on the subsequent Cournot equilibrium.Footnote 4 Social welfare accounts for an important source of welfare variation, arising from R&D duplication, which is often mentioned as a key determinant of R&D cooperation, but is ignored by the consumer surplus approach. Third, and relatedly, the paper studies the cases of both cooperative synergies and the lack of thereof, which is here interpreted in terms of R&D coordination between separate R&D labs. Finally, the paper extends the results in Kamien and Zang, providing conditions for ranking different cartel structures in terms of total profits and social welfare. The implications of R&D cartel competition depend both on the standard of evaluation and on whether there are synergies or not. For the case of no cooperative synergies, the equilibrium level of R&D investment and hence consumer surplus is monotone in the number of R&D cartels. It is maximized under industry-wide cooperation if the spillover rate is above a threshold level, which is decreasing in \(\rho \). On the other hand, equilibrium industry profit decreases as the number of R&D decision makers increases. Due to these possible competing effects of varying the number of competing cartels, the welfare rank of alternative cartel structures depends on the spillover rate. For the case of synergies, equilibrium consumer surplus is in general non monotone in the number of RJV’s. Provided this number is larger than two, consumer surplus is decreasing. However, consumer surplus is maximized by the industry-wide RJV only if the natural spillover rate is above a threshold level. This is an extension to the case of general demand of the result in Kamien and Zang mentioned above. A total profit and a social welfare comparison of different RJV structures is not immediate. The paper provides two sufficient conditions for industry profit and welfare to decrease with respect to the number of RJV’s. When the social planner can implement the desired number of R&D labs as well as the level of R&D activity, then the optimal R&D policy is to set a unique, joint R&D lab and then subsidize R&D accordingly. As discussed in Sect. 5, this result is not robust to relaxing the constraint of symmetric R&D profiles, in which case the optimal policy might deny access to R&D to a subset of firms. Relative to second best R&D, inefficiencies in terms of both under and overinvestment are possible, both with and without synergies. However, the cases in which equilibrium R&D is socially excessive are limited to low spillovers and a relatively large number of R&D cartels. This paper considers the effect of R&D cartel competition for a given cartel structure of the industry and hence ignores the issue of R&D cartel formation. Although firms in general participate to R&D agreements on a voluntary basis, the study of exogenous R&D cartels is important for at least two reasons. First, it is necessary to understand the incentives of candidate members to join a cartel and is hence preliminary to any study of endogenous agreements. Second, and more important, it provides a guidance to the antitrust treatment of R&D cooperation, which usually allows courts to directly affect the pattern of cartelization of the industry. While past guidelines have often explicitly suggested to block industry-wide cooperation in favour of smaller, competing projects, more recent decisions have favoured industry-wide arrangements (Grossman and Shapiro 1986),Footnote 5 and it is common opinion that the vast literature on the matter has contributed to this change. Besides Kamien and Zang, the analysis is also close to other studies of industry-wide R&D cooperation vs competition which this paper treats as special cases. Notably, the paper extends some of the results in Suzumura and Leahy and Neary (1997) to the case of R&D cartel competition. The model is described in Sect. 2. Sections 3 and 4 consider the case of no synergies and synergies, respectively. Section 5 considers the scope of application of the results. “Appendix” collects the proofs and derives some intermediate results invoked in the main text.

Title: Risk aversion in the Nash bargaining problem with uncertainty
Social responsibility in a bilateral monopoly
Intro: “What is worse than a monopoly? A chain of monopolies.” (Tirole 1988, p. 175) Paul Pollack, the CEO of the global corporation “Unilever”, implements a “sustainable living plan” (The Economist 2012, p. 68) into its firm mission to generate a sustainable profit in the long-run.Footnote 1 Critics of the shareholder value approach argue for a modern management which should concentrate on a broader company mission with additional goals like “customer satisfaction” (p. 68), instead of the exclusive concentration on (short-term) shareholder value. The trend toward more social actions by firms, which is very often summarized as “Corporate Social Responsibility”, is confirmed by diverse surveys [e.g. KPMG (2011); Ernst and Young (2011); UN Global Compact and Accenture (2010); McKinsey and Company (2007); Economist Intelligence Unit (2007)]. Since the beginning of this millennium the debate on firms’ social responsibility has been discussed more frequently in the scientific community. For example, Jensen (2001, 2002) points out the importance of firm’s stakeholders which should additionally be considered in firm’s decision making process. Therefore, he redefines the firm’s objective which he calls “Enlightened Value Maximization”. The arguments of Porter and Kramer (2011) are in the same line. They indicate the firm’s responsibility to care also about societal needs. As a consequence, they illustrate the importance of “creating a shared value”. An organizational architecture is created by Bromberger (2011), because within a “hybrid-organization” an entrepreneur “can operate as both a for-profit and a nonprofit” (p. 49). For Husted and Allen (2011) the combination of for-profit goals and non-profit goals is even implemented in the firm’s strategy they call “Corporate Social Strategy”, because both shareholders and stakeholders neither solely concentrates on profit nor on social benefits. The organizations’ challenge is to find “the right balance” (p. 20). An upcoming analytical stream of literature started by Goering (2007) deals with mixed duopolies where a profit-maximizing firm (henceforth PMF), which is exclusively concentrated on its profit, competes against a socially concerned firm (SCF). The SCF maximizes in addition to its own profit a share of consumer surplus. Goering (2007) and Kopel and Brand (2012) analyze a mixed duopoly with a PMF and a SCF where both firms can offer strategic incentives to their manager. In line with this articles, Kopel and Brand (2013) explain why SCFs pay low-powered incentives to their executives. A mixed market model without managers is analyzed by Goering (2008),Footnote 2 whereby a SCF competes either against a PMF or a public firm, which maximizes total welfare. This analysis contains also a triopoly with all three different types of firms. The double marginalization in a bilateral monopoly is explored originally by Spengler (1950). Goering (2012) starts to analyze the impact of firms’ social concern on a bilateral monopoly.Footnote 3 His analysis is concentrated on a perfectly coordinated marketing channel,Footnote 4 introduced by Jeuland and Shugan (1983). The analytical framework developed by Goering (2012) is completed in Brand and Grothe (2013). Due to the fact that Goering (2012) and Brand and Grothe (2013) are analyzing a perfectly coordinated marketing channel, the double marginalization problem is solved ex ante by the assumption that the manufacturer is able to absorb the whole retailer’s profit. This assumption is relaxed within our framework. The rest of the model used by Goering (2012) is unchanged. At first, we examine the impact of a given level of social concern on the double marginalization problem. Afterwards, social concern is used strategically by means of firms’ endogenously chosen levels of social concern. As a result, our analysis combines the double marginalization problem with firms’ social responsibility. In detail, we want to answer the following research questions: First, how does firms’ social concern change the classical double marginalization problem? Second, for which firm does it pay off to be socially responsibly? Third, which effect has firms’ social responsibility on quantity, price, consumer surplus and total welfare? Through the analysis of our model we get three main results. First, not only in an oligopoly, even as pointed out by Manasakis et al. (2007), Kopel and Brand (2012) and Kopel and Brand (2013), also in a bilateral monopoly firms’ social responsibility can be chosen strategically. The result confirms the empirical findings made by Hillman and D.Keim (2001), McWilliams and Siegel (2001, 2011), Siegel and Vitaliano (2007) and Fernández-Kranz and Santaló (2010). Second, socially concerned firms soften the double marginalization problem although a perfectly coordinated marketing channel solves this problem more efficiently than firms’ social responsibility. Nevertheless, if perfect coordination is not possible, the implementation of a broader firm mission results in a Pareto improvement. Third, the fact that impact of the retailer’s social concern affects the equilibrium values twice as much as the manufacturer’s social responsibility is in line with Fisman et al. (2005, 2006). Their empirical studies show that firms selling their products to end-consumer are more often socially concerned than firms without any connection to the final market. In summary, our model gives further insights into a bilateral monopoly when firms have the choice to be socially concerned. The rest of this paper is structured as follows. Section 2 introduces the model setup and Sect. 3 summarizes the results. The last section concludes our findings.

Title: Szenberg, Michael and Ramrattan, Lall: Secrets of Economics Editors
Selected books received
Managerial delegation and welfare effects of cost reductions
Intro: A firm’s cost reduction is not always beneficial to this firm, the industry and/or society as a whole. Schmalensee (1976), Gaudet and Salant (1991) and Kimmel (1992) are examples of early papers that revealed that cost reduction can harm an individual firm’s profitability in a Cournot oligopoly setting. Zhao (2001) extended this logic to society, showing that a small cost reduction by an inefficient firm may well reduce social welfare in an \(n\)-firm Cournot oligopoly with linear cost and demand. Smythe and Zhao (2006) generalized this result to the \(n\)-firm Cournot oligopoly case with non-linear cost and demand. These findings have clear implications for policies relating to the support of inefficient firms. For example, the effect on the world’s social welfare of aid to inefficient firms in developing countries may well be negative, as is the impact of providing support to inefficient “national champions” in times of economic crisis. We add to this literature by analyzing \(n\)-firm Cournot strategic delegation games. Strategic delegation games depart from the standard assumption of profit maximization. Since the contributions of Vickers (1985), Fershtman and Judd (1987) and Sklivas (1987), two-stage strategic delegation games have been developed in which the owner of the firm decides in the contract stage of the game about his manager’s incentives, which impact the latter’s behavior in the market stage of the game. The original models assumed sales delegation: that is, the owner decides on the manager’s remuneration as a weighted combination of the profits and sales obtained in the market stage of the game. Later, other types of strategic delegation anchors have been introduced, such as relative performance (Miller and Pazgal (2002)) and market share (Jansen et al. 2007; Ritz 2008). In the current paper, we model strategic sales delegation games. We first generalize the method of Zhao (2001) for the classical profit maximization \(n\) firm Cournot oligopoly case, and express the results in terms of the effects of both small and large cost reductions. We show that, in an \(n\)-firm strategic sales delegation Cournot oligopoly, a cost reduction of an inefficient firm is more likely to be associated with firm exit and welfare loss than in the benchmark case of a classical profit maximization \(n\)-firm Cournot oligopoly. From this, we conclude that if a government decides to offer financial support to an inefficient firm, either at home or abroad, that then a condition as to managerial incentives should be part of the policy package.

Title: Learning by doing and horizontal mergers
International cross-ownership of firms and strategic privatization policy
Intro:
The past few decades have witnessed a global wave of privatization, with the total value of privatization worldwide exceeding US$200 billion in recent years, even in the aftermath of the post-2007 financial crisis.Footnote 1 During the privatization process, the ownership of state-owned enterprises (SOEs) is transferred from the state to private domestic and foreign investors, with share issue privatizations (SIPs) and mergers and acquisitions (M&As) being among the main privatization methods (Brada 1996; Megginson and Netter 2001).Footnote 2 At the same time, with the increasing integration of international equity markets, the international cross-ownership of assets in trading firms has become increasingly common. For instance, foreign investors hold 27.3 % of the shares in the partially privatized Japanese telecommunications giant Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation (NTT). Similarly, Japanese investors also hold large amounts of stock issued by foreign telecommunications companies.Footnote 3 Clearly, how the structure of the international cross-ownership of firms affects strategic privatization policy merits careful consideration. However, despite a substantial literature concerning the effects of international cross-ownership of firms on strategic trade policies and trade patterns dating from seminal work by Lee (1990), Dick (1993), and an extensive literature on mixed oligopoly with foreign competitors that starts with Corneo and Jeanne (1992, 1994), this important issue remains only partly addressed.Footnote 4
 More concretely, consider the possible further privatization of Airbus, the largely state-owned European aerospace and defense corporation. If the European governments owning Airbus contemplate an SIP as a means of privatization, they must think carefully about how they should sell shares in Airbus to a private sector that may have already invested heavily in stocks issued by its most important rival Boeing, a private US firm.Footnote 5 How, then, will the possibility of the international cross-ownership of firms affect the possible privatization of Airbus? A similar question arises in relation to the Japanese government contemplating the further sale of shares in the already partially privatized NTT and JT. It, too, has to consider the fact that the targeted private sector has already invested heavily in stocks issued by the foreign rivals of NTT and JT. Our aim is to examine this important question using a simple model of international mixed oligopoly, where the domestic firm is a partially privatized public firm operating in the same market as privately owned foreign firms.Footnote 6
 Using our simple model, we show that the structure of the international cross-ownership of firms emerges as a critical determinant of privatization policy. In the case of international Cournot competition in a third market, an increase in the domestic ownership of foreign firms can impede privatization, whereas an increase in the foreign ownership of the privatized domestic firm can promote privatization. This arises primarily because the government needs to balance two conflicting incentives, i.e., increasing the profits of the partially privatized public firm and increasing the profits of the foreign firm partly owned by domestic residents. An increase in the intensity of privatization shifts production from the foreign firm to the domestic firm, and thus increases the profits of the latter. However, this increase in profits is at the expense of the domestic residents owning shares in the foreign firm. Hence, when there is an increase in the domestic ownership of the foreign firm, the home government is motivated to protect the interests of domestic residents by rendering the domestic firm less aggressive (through a reduction in the level of privatization), thus increasing the profits of the foreign firm. In contrast, an increase in the foreign ownership of the domestic firm diminishes the domestic welfare incentive to increase the profits of the foreign firm, thus promoting further privatization. Conversely, under Bertrand competition, it would always be optimal for the home government to pursue complete nationalization. This is because, unlike the Cournot case, there is a convergence of interests between the firms under Bertrand competition, such that a less aggressive domestic firm benefits both the domestic and international firms. This is especially the case when domestic residents also own shares in the foreign firm. Consequently, under Bertrand competition, the home government always chooses to nationalize the domestic firm completely. These findings suggest that depending on the type of competition, the effects of the international cross-ownership of firms on the privatization process can be completely different. Furthermore, we also demonstrate that under Cournot competition, domestic ownership of foreign firms renders neither complete privatization nor complete nationalization optimal under moderate conditions. Put otherwise, our results suggest that under Cournot competition, domestic ownership of foreign firms may prevent governments from adopting policies aimed at either a complete privatization or a complete nationalization of their industries. Our analysis thus offers a novel explanation, at least in part, for the common observation that governments worldwide appear to refrain from applying complete privatization in the modern era of globalization. In terms of background, our analysis mostly relates to the extensive literature on mixed oligopolies.Footnote 7 In early work, Matsumura (1998) considers partial privatization and examines optimal state ownership in a domestic context.Footnote 8 Since then, a number of studies have considered competition between partially privatized domestic firms and private foreign firms.Footnote 9 Recently, evidence has emerged of a strong interdependence between privatization policies and strategic trade policies.Footnote 10 For instance, using a mixed oligopoly model for two countries, in each of which there is a public firm and a private firm, Han and Ogawa (2008) show that integration in the product market can limit privatization. Alternatively, Long and Stähler (2009) demonstrate that when a partially privatized domestic firm and a foreign firm compete à la Cournot in a third market, the optimal export subsidy increases with state ownership, whereas in the case of Bertrand rivalry with differentiated goods, the optimal export tax increases with state ownership. Lastly, in an important recent contribution, Lin and Matsumura (2012) consider the setting where a partially privatized domestic firm competes with a number of domestic and foreign private firms. Under this setting, they examine how the foreign ownership of partially privatized domestic firms affects privatization policy and show that a higher ratio of foreign investor stockholding in a partially privatized firm can promote privatization, whereas the increased penetration of foreign firms in the product market can retard privatization. Nonetheless, despite being a widely observed phenomenon in the age of globalization, the domestic ownership of private foreign firms has not been explicitly considered in the literature.Footnote 11 To the best of our knowledge, this is the first analysis concerning the interdependence of the international cross-ownership of firms and privatization policy.Footnote 12
 Our paper also relates to the vast empirical literature on privatization, which generally shows that the magnitude of privatization varies greatly by industry.Footnote 13 Our results also contribute to this stream of the literature by generating some testable predictions concerning the direction of privatization policy. Namely, given the domestic ownership of foreign firms, (i) depending on the characteristics of the market under consideration, the direction of privatization policy can be opposite, and (ii) neither complete privatization nor complete nationalization may hold. The remainder of the paper is structured as follows. Section 2 presents the basic model and the main results. We consider both Cournot and Bertrand competition, and their outcomes are briefly compared. Section 3 examines the robustness of the main results. This section also analyzes the cases where the two firms compete in the home market, as well as the effects of an asymmetric cost structure. We conclude the paper in Sect. 4.

Title: Does two-part tariff licensing agreement enhance both welfare and profit?
Competition and uncertainty in a paper’s news desk

Lechevalier, Sébastien: The great transformation
of
Japanese capitalism
Downstream and upstream oligopolies when retailer’s effort matters
Intro:
This paper investigates the interactions between upstream oligopolists and downstream retailer(s) contingent on the terms of their transactions: either wholesale or retail pricing combined with sharing the revenues. One motivation for this analysis is Apple’s entry into the ebook market on the basis of the agency model (retail pricing by the publishers with Apple keeping a share) while Amazon, which enjoyed a monopoly before Apple’s entry, kept publishers on the “wholesale model”. The peculiarities of this market are addressed in Foros et al. (2013). In spite of a similar motivation and a similar demand framework, objective, set up, and most of the questions and results in this paper are different and presumably complementary to Foros et al. (2013). The major differences are: First, to account for potentially substantial contributions of retailer(s). Recent management literature, e.g., Dawar (2013), stresses that downstream activities are gaining strategic importance. Second, the focus on upstream–downstream oligopolistic interactions in a more general setting beyond the ‘Apple’ case. Third and related to above, the assumption of simultaneous moves because that allows treating all firms symmetrically. A sequential game requires asymmetry with respect to strategic leverages and in particular with respect to commitment power. Commitment power is also needed for more complicated contracts such as nonlinear tariffs. Therefore, the assumptions of symmetry and simultaneous moves allow restricting the analysis to linear tariffs. Fourth, Nash competition at all stages. The combination of the above mentioned items distinguishes this paper from the extensively explored field of vertical relations (with and without product differentiation) as sequential games and/or bargaining models dominate. Fifth, comparing retail monopolies and duopolies, which leads to the surprising conclusion that upstream firms can benefit from facing a retail monopoly. A major reason for considering simultaneous moves is the focus on interactions between upstream and downstream oligopolies beyond the topical case in order to address inter alia the following questions: Which of the two kinds of pricing arrangements, wholesale or agency, is more profitable and to whom, first under a downstream monopoly and then under an oligopoly? Is downstream competition (always) beneficial for an upstream oligopoly? What about the possibility of an asymmetric equilibrium within a symmetric setup, choosing wholesale for one and retail pricing for the other retailer? What happens if upstream firms choose different pricing strategies? The answers to the above questions can be applied to study the relations among non-competitive suppliers and non-competitive and effort providing retailers such as those between supermarket chains and their suppliers (e.g., dairies and breweries), between luxury (and other branded) goods and selected retail chains. In order to address all of the above questions it is necessary that different pricing modes are possible. This is presumably not the case in all vertical relations like the one between the (oligopolistic) electronics industry that uses similar inputs from its oligopolistic suppliers to assemble TVs, mobile phones, computers, etc. However, even in such cases, the results reported under wholesale pricing seem applicable. The model considers upstream and downstream oligopolies (for simplicity duopolies) within a differentiated goods framework such that a consumer can decide among four products differentiated along suppliers and retailers. In the motivating case of Amazon and Apple the differentiation of otherwise identical products (say a John Irving novel) is clear due to differences of the required hardware. One crucial feature of this analysis is that cooperation, which is assumed in most of the related IO literature in at least one of the upstream–downstream relations, is eschewed. Instead non-cooperative behavior of all (four) players—an upstream duopoly and a downstream duopoly—is assumed. Another and crucial extension is that the retailers are not passive but provide a value enhancing task. These extensions turn some conventional wisdoms upside down. One reason is the possibility of morale hazard on behalf of the retailer(s) in particular under retail price arrangements. This was already noted in Romano (1994), which allows also upstream moral hazard but restricts the analysis to a single firm downstream and upstream with the latter dictating the terms of the contract; recently, Gabrielsen and Johansen (2013b) shows that retailers’ moral hazard leads to commitment problems for an upstream monopoly selling to two retailers. Although the above sketched model is set up along familiar IO frameworks, its focus and results are different. Horn and Wolinsky (1988) considers bilateral relations between upstream and downstream, Cournot competition in the downstream market and (bilateral) Nash bargaining between supplier and retailer, which affect the profitability of an upstream merger. Naylor (2002) finds the unusual effect that downstream profits can increase with the number of retailers. Matsushima (2006) shows that this can also arise under Nash interactions between downstream and upstream firms and free entry into the upstream sector. This possibility arises also in this paper but for different reasons. In the related marketing literature, Choi (1991) considers simultaneous moves as well as Stackelberg setups with two manufacturers selling to one retailer (wholesale) that is extended in Lee and Staelin (1997) for retail competition (and for general demand functions).Footnote 1
Rey and Stiglitz (1995) considers upstream and downstream competition in wholesale prices but focuses on how exclusive territories reduce intrabrand competition. Rey and Verge (2010) considers four ‘products’ differentiated along the manufacturer and retailer dimension but assumes that all the bargaining power is with the manufacturers (\(=\) upstream). The upshot is that retail price maintenance (RPM) limits competition and can generate monopoly pricing. Dobson and Waterson (2007) in contrast finds that RPM is not universally undesirable in a four product demand framework, which will be used in this paper too, and bargaining. Gabrielsen and Johansen (2013a) is a recent paper that differentiates products according to manufacturer and retailer. It assumes that one of the two brands (\(=\) upstream producers) is competitively supplied and focuses on seller versus buyer power and RPM versus two part tariffs (confirming the concern against RPM), while this paper focuses on Nash outcomes. Many papers eschew competitive settings and assume either bargaining in such bilateral oligopolies, e.g., Björnerstedt and Stennek (2007), Mills (2007), Richards and Patterson (2005) or focus on integration, e.g., Gaudet and van Long (1996) considers the prospects of downstream oligopolists pairing with upstream oligopolists in the case of a homogenous good, Jansen (2003), Milliou and Petrakis (2007) and Bourreau et al. (2011) on vertically integrated versus disintegrated downstream firms, on how retail power induces concentration, Inderst (2007). The upstream oligopoly’s strife to fix retail prices in order to avoid double marginalization is, however, not without costs if the retailers’ efforts can add value. The reason is that retail pricing allows the upstream firms to appropriate all rents in a non-cooperative setting. This eliminates not only double marginalization but also all efforts of retailers, which can lead to lower upstream profits. Indeed, as long as the retailers’ efforts are not too costly, double marginalization is less harmful and thus wholesale pricing should be the preferred policy of the upstream oligopolists. Hence, allowing for a contribution by retailers changes conventional wisdom between retail and wholesale pricing arrangements. Furthermore, retail competition need not benefit the upstream firms and it can be optimal for them to split their strategy even within an otherwise symmetric framework: use a wholesale pricing arrangement for one retailer and fix retail prices for the other. Of course, downstream firms will always prefer wholesale pricing in such a non-cooperative simultaneous move setting, i.e., in the absence of strategic advantages and corresponding commitment power. Summarizing, a number of concrete and testable (i.e., refutable) predictions are obtained. The presentation of the model (including benchmarks for comparisons), is followed by the analysis of a retail monopoly (Sect. 3) and then of a retail oligopoly (Sect. 4), where each section considers retail and wholesale pricing arrangements. In addition, Sect. 5 considers mixed pricing arrangements, downstream and upstream. All proofs are relegated to an “Appendix”.

Title: Stability, strategic substitutes, strategic complements
Intro:
Studies abound that limit the parameter space of models of imperfect competition by considering stability conditions that must hold in equilibrium. As Seade (1980, p 483) observes: It is natural to disregard unstable equilibria as being unobservable, in particular in the context of a comparative-statics exercise, where any possible initial unstable equilibrium would be lost when perturbed and would not be regained subsequently. Let \((x_{1}^{*},x_{2}^{*})\) be some candidate equilibrium in a two-player game. A well-known necessary and sufficient condition for this equilibrium to be stable, is that the determinant of the concomitant Jacobian matrix is positive and that the trace of the Jacobian is negative (e.g. Dixit 1986). The latter condition is met in case all second-order conditions are satisfied. The former condition, also known as the Routh–Hurwitz stability condition, reads as: 
\(i,j=1,2\), \(i\ne j\), whereby \(\pi _{i}\) refers to subject \(i\)’s objective function. Underlying (1) is a myopic adjustment process: starting from any point \((x_{i},x_{j})\) each player \(i\) adjusts \(x_{i}\) as long as marginal profits of doing so are positive (Dixit 1986). Stability condition (1) guarantees that this adjustment process converges to \((x_{1}^{*},x_{2}^{*})\).Footnote 1
 Although simple in itself, it is quite easy to track down contributions to the literature that did not properly take into account condition (1). Overlooking the distinction between choice variables that are a strategic substitute or a strategic complements is one reason for these errors. Indeed, as this note illustrates, condition (1) can take a different form for strategic substitutes and strategic complements.

Title: Competition and privatization policies revisited: the payoff interdependence approach
Privatization in the presence of patent licensing
Endogenous timing in a mixed duopoly model
Intro: The existing literature on industrial organization studies firms’ behavior by using models based on different hypotheses about the context and the way in which firms make their decisions. Particularly, some models assume price competition (Bertrand’s model) and others assume quantity competition (Cournot’s model). Sometimes it is assumed that firms produce homogeneous goods and sometimes that the goods produced are differentiated. Furthermore, there are contributions on both private oligopoly models and mixed oligopoly models. Finally, some models assume that firms make their decisions simultaneously (Bertrand and Cournot’s models) and other models consider that firms play sequentially (Stackelberg’s models). The order in which firms take decisions is considered very important because as Pal (1998) points out a sequential order of moves may give rise to significantly different results from those obtained in a simultaneous game. Therefore, the order of moves in which firms take decisions should be analyzed endogenously. By considering the observable delay game of Hamilton and Slutsky (1990), this paper analyzes endogenous timing in a mixed duopoly model, in which firms produce differentiated good assuming both Cournot and Bertrand competition. Recently, studies of mixed markets involving both private and public firms have become increasingly popular in the literature. This interest in mixed oligopolies is due to their importance to the economies in many countries of Europe, Canada and Japan, among others. Although the world wave of privatization has been observed since 1980s, competition between public, semi-public (partially owned by public sectors) and private firms exists in many sectors, among others, the airline, rail, telecommunications, natural gas, steel, electricity, as well as services including banking, hospitals and education. Since Merrill and Schneider (1966) seminal paper, the literature on mixed oligopolies has become richer and more diverse. Specifically, Matsumura (1998) shows that semi-public firms can emerge naturally in mixed oligopoly markets. Recent papers on partial privatization are, among others, Matsumura and Kanda (2005), Fujiwara (2007) and Lin and Matsumura (2012). Most of the existing literature on mixed oligopoly assumes either that firms make quantity or price choices, in either a simultaneous or a sequential game, and that the order of movements is exogenously given. However, some papers discuss endogenous timing in mixed oligopoly models. Some of them analyze endogenous timing assuming quantity competition and homogeneous goods for example, Pal (1998), who investigates this problem in a closed economy by using the observable delay game formulated by Hamilton and Slutsky (1990), Matsumura (2003), who considers only foreign firms in the analysis, and Lu (2006), who takes into account both domestic and foreign firms in the analysis. Other papers, analyze endogenous timing in a price competition setting, for example: Ogawa and Kato (2006), Bárcena-Ruiz (2007) and Méndez-Naya (2011)Footnote 1. The above literature on mixed duopoly shows that when firms compete in quantities and produce a homogeneous good, contrary to private duopoly, they make their decisions sequentially (Pal 1998; Matsumura 2003; Lu 2006). Under price competition (Bárcena-Ruiz 2007) shows that, once more contrary to a private duopoly model, the public and the private firms set prices simultaneously because of the dominant strategy for the two firms is to be the Stackelberg leader of the game, that is to say, both of them prefer to set prices as soon as possible. On the other hand, Méndez-Naya (2011) proves that a merger between a public and a private firm could change the timing of the game. The purpose of this paper is to complement existing literature on endogenous timing in mixed duopoly models by setting a general duopoly model in which firms may compete in either prices or quantities, the goods produced by the two firms may be either homogeneous or differentiated and, furthermore, there could be either a mixed duopoly model or a private duopoly one. Specifically, the endogenous timing of the game is analyzed by assuming that there is a private firm and a partly owned one. Matsumura and Ogawa (2010) and Bárcena-Ruiz and Garzón (2010) have already analyzed endogenous timing in a mixed oligopoly model by using the (Hamilton and Slutsky 1990) observable delay game, however, their papers discuss quantity competition assuming homogeneous goods. Therefore, this paper complements the above mentioned papers by adding price competition and product differentiation. Specifically the role played by both the degree of privatization and the existing product differentiation on the endogenous order in which firms make their decisions is discussed. Following Pal (1998) and based on the (Hamilton and Slutsky 1990) observed delay game, it is proved that the endogenous timing of the game, in both a Bertrand and a Cournot setting, depends in a complex way on the existing relationship between both the degree of privatization of the partially privatized firm and the existing product differentiation. Furthermore, it is shown that the results obtained in the Cournot’s model are quite different to those obtained in the Bertrand’s model.

Title: Kotz, David M.: The rise and fall of neoliberal capitalism
Angrist, Joshua D. & Pischke, Jörn-Steffen: Mastering 'metrics: The path from cause to effect
A symmetric Heckscher–Ohlin model of endogenous growth
Optimal fiscal policies in an economy with externalities from public spending
Innovation and labour mobility
Legal enforcement against illegal imitation in developing countries
Miao, Jianjun: Economic dynamics in discrete time
Selected Books Received
Incomplete financial markets with real assets and wealth-dependent credit limits
Factor substitution is an engine of growth in a model with productive public expenditure
Intro:
Factor substitution is a powerful engine of growth. This is the conclusion drawn from the influential work of Grandville (1989) and Klump and Grandville (2000), who find a positive relationship between factor substitution and growth and income per capita in the Solow model. The link between economic growth and factor substitutability has thereafter attracted a great attention of the literature (see, e.g., Klump et al. 2012, for a recent survey). This research has been stimulated by empirical work providing evidence against the unitary elasticity of substitution implicit in the Cobb–Douglas specification and in favor of a more general Constant-Elasticity-of-Substitution (CES) specification (e.g., Chirinko 2008; Klump et al. 2007; León-Ledesma et al. 2010). Thus, subsequent work by Miyagiwa and Papageorgiou (2003) shows that such positive relationship does not necessarily hold in the Diamond model. Irmen and Klump (2009) reconcile these findings by considering a generalized neoclassical growth model with possible asymmetries in savings out of factor incomes. They show that factor substitution has a positive ‘efficiency effect’ on growth via income but an ambiguous ‘distribution effect’ via factor income shares. However, the positive link between factor substitution and growth can be assured, in particular, if the saving rate out of capital income is not lower than the saving rate out of wage income. Xue and Yip (2012) present a comprehensive characterization of the growth-substitutability nexus in the Solow, Ramsey-Cass-Koopmans and Diamond models.Footnote 1
 This literature has relied on growth models in which the long-run growth rate is exogenously given. Therefore, factor substitution can affect the growth rate during the transition, but not the long-run growth rate.Footnote 2 Furthermore, the unique factors of production considered are capital and labor, so the analysis focuses on the effect of capital-labor substitution. A large empirical literature shows that other inputs are fundamental in production and, in particular, the productive role of certain types of public expenditure is well documented (see, e.g., the review in Romp and Haan 2007, and the meta-analysis in Bom and Ligthart 2014). In this paper we consider an endogenous growth model with productive public expenditure à la (Barro 1990). Thus, we examine the effect of the elasticity of substitution between private and public inputs on (endogenous) long-run growth.Footnote 3 An important implication of the introduction of policy variables is that it allows us to analyze the effect of factor substitution on the optimal fiscal policy as well. Furthermore, we also study the effect of the elasticity of substitution on welfare, which should be the ultimate goal of the analysis (e.g., Grandville 2009). We find that for two identical economies differing uniquely in the elasticity of substitution between private and public inputs, if the baseline government size is suboptimally low the first-best optimal government size and, in the presence of congestion, the optimal income tax rate will be higher in the economy with the higher elasticity of substitution. If the baseline government size is suboptimally high this result must be reversed: the first-best optimal government size and, in the presence of congestion, the optimal income tax rate will be lower in the economy with the higher elasticity of substitution. In any case, the high-elasticity economy will feature a higher first-best optimal long-run growth rate and welfare. This is due to the efficiency effect of Klump and Grandville (2000); i.e., a higher elasticity of factor substitution increases the productivity of inputs. This paper is also related to a large body of literature that, since the seminal work of Barro (1990), has analyzed from a theoretical perspective the effect of productive government expenditure in endogenous growth models (see, e.g., Irmen and Kuehnel 2009, for a recent survey). Because of its analytical simplicity, most of this literature has considered that production is Cobb–Douglas. However, a small strand of this literature combined public and private inputs through a more general CES technology. Devarajan et al. (1996) examine the effect of the composition of government expenditure on the long-run growth rate, whereas Ghosh and Gregoriou (2008) study the (second-best) welfare-maximizing solution in this model. Ott and Turnovsky (2006) derive the optimal tax structure in a model with non-excludable and excludable public inputs. Misch et al. (2013) and Gómez (2014) analyze the relationship between the growth-maximizing, (second-best) welfare-maximizing and first-best optimal income tax rates—or, equivalently, government sizes—and long-run growth rates in models with productive public expenditure/capital for given parameter values, including the elasticity of substitution.Footnote 4 Thus, neither of these works examine the effect of changes in the elasticity of substitution so, in particular, they do not need to use normalized CES production functions. This paper studies, instead, the effect of changes in the elasticity of substitution on the first-best government size, welfare and long-run growth. Therefore, following Klump and Grandville (2000), we have to normalize the CES production function. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 describes the model. Section 3 examines the effect of the elasticity of substitution between public and private inputs. Section 4 concludes.

Title: Relative effects of labor taxes on employment and working hours: role of mechanisms shaping working hours
Llavador, Humberto G., Roemer, John E. and Silvestre, Joaquim: Sustainability for a warming planet
Stigum, Bernt P.: Econometrics in a formal science of economics: theory and the measurement of economic relations
Bargaining and collusion in a regulatory relationship
Intro: In this paper we examine the interaction between a regulator and a regulated firm as a bargaining process. Our aim is to investigate the impact of the bargaining powers of the regulator and of the firm on the scope for collusion between the parties. This approach generalizes the standard framework of ‘command and control’, where all the bargaining power is allocated to the regulator, and allows a broader analysis of the optimal institutional response to collusion. Regulatory intervention is usually thought of as the use of the government power to coerce for the purpose of restricting the firms’ decisions when unfettered competition turns out to be inappropriate. This is the case in relevant portions of electricity, gas, sanitation, telecommunications, transportation and water industries. The economic literature typically assumes that the regulator has the power to dictate a regulatory policy to the firm, and therefore regulation is modelled as the outcome of a ‘take-it-or-leave-it’ offer. In practice, however, regulation is generally a process of give-and-take rather than of take-it-or-leave-it. On the one hand, regulators issue rules in the form of administrative acts that fill in the details of the authorizing legislation. Given the general and vague policy aims provided by the legislation (a form of contract incompleteness), regulators are left with some power when they regulate firms. On the other hand, regulated firms generally do not comply in a fully passive manner with regulatory decisions. They may threaten to appeal against the regulator’s decisions in order to obtain some revisions. The desire to avoid a rule being repealed in the courts can determine the form of the rule that is finally adopted. More importantly, this is not the only means to directly affect the regulatory outcome. A regulator usually must fulfill some procedural requirements that restrict the exercise of policies in the form of command and control. The US Administrative Procedure Act (APA) of 1946 provides that rulemaking procedures may be either formal, with hearings resembling a court trial, or informal, with notice of rulemaking and public comments. Concerned parties are allowed to express their viewpoints by presenting evidence on the effects of the regulator’s actions and on questions of fact. Regulatory hearings are typically characterized by repeated revisions of rate proposals. In reaction to complaints, the regulator puts forward a new set of rules and amendments to the existing ones. Therefore, rulemaking is not usually the direct product of the regulator’s fiat, but it arises from a process of intensive scrutiny. This discussion suggests that regulation tends to be the outcome of a bargaining process. Empirical evidence seems to support this view. For instance, the presence of turnover costs can weaken the threat to replace an incumbent firm that is reluctant to accept a regulatory policy. Kahn (1988) observes that in utility sectors the relationship between a regulator and a regulated firm generally constitutes a bilateral monopoly that induces the parties to achieve a compromise. In their analysis of the features of the regulatory process in the US, Viscusi et al. (2005) emphasize the influence of private players (mainly, firms) on regulatory outcomes. Rossi (2011) explores the increasing scope for bargaining in regulatory relationships after the liberalization process.Footnote 1 In their seminal survey on optimal regulation, Armstrong and Sappington (2007, p. 1564) point out that the standard approach in the literature, which ignores negotiations between the regulator and the firm, “generally is adopted for technical convenience rather than for realism”. In our model the regulator is required to monitor the firm’s costs and to reveal its information to a political principal (Congress). As it is well established in the collusion literature (e.g., Tirole 1986, 1992), this raises the possibility of collusion between the firm and the regulator, which can manipulate its audit report to Congress in exchange for a side transfer from the firm. Frequent news reports of corruption and lax regulation suggest that collusion is a widespread phenomenon. Laffont and Tirole (1993, Ch. 11) emphasize that a regulated firm has several means to influence public decision making. For instance, it can bribe the regulatory officials through gratuities or the offer of job positions in the regulated firm after their retirement (‘revolving door’ phenomenon). Personal relationships can provide incentives for the regulatory staff to treat the regulated firm kindly. The firm may cater to the regulator’s concern for tranquility by refraining from criticizing publicly the regulatory management. As Estache and Wren-Lewis (2009) point out, the problems of collusion and corruption are particularly severe in developing countries. It is well known in the collusion literature that an efficient firm has a stake in collusion with the regulator. We show that this standard conclusion holds only if the regulator’s bargaining power is relatively high. The rationale behind our result lies in the trade-off the firm faces when colluding with the regulator. The benefit of collusion arises from the higher price the efficient firm is allowed to charge when the collusive regulator manipulates its information before Congress and reports that the firm is inefficient. However, a higher price shrinks the gains from trade the parties can share in the bargaining process. Since these gains are redistributed according to the parties’ bargaining powers, a powerful regulator reduces the gains the firm can appropriate. Hence, if the regulator’s bargaining power is significant enough, the firm’s benefit of a higher collusive price outweighs the cost of lower gains from trade, and the firm has an incentive to collude. Our result indicates that the scope for collusion crucially depends on the bargaining powers of the parties involved in the regulatory process. The bargaining power of a party can arise either from the authorizing legislation or from the regulatory environment that determines each party’s strength in the regulatory relationship. If the regulator can impose its decisions to a large extent, it enjoys a high bargaining power vis-à-vis the regulated firm and, in line with the classical approach of command and control, our analysis predicts that the efficient firm has a stake in collusion. However, we show that a sufficiently high bargaining power of the firm removes its incentive to collude. Afterwards, we derive the optimal institutional response to collusion. In a standard framework where incentive payments cannot discriminate between the regulator’s (honest or collusive) types, we characterize the conditions under which allowing collusion is preferred to deterring it (via an incentive payment or the shutdown of the inefficient firm). This can be the case when the regulator’s bargaining power is high enough. The reason for this result is that a powerful regulator increases the firm’s stake in collusion, which makes deterring collusion more costly. We find that allowing collusion can be also optimal when consumer demand is relatively inelastic, such as in markets for essential services (e.g., energy, sanitation). A rigid demand facilitates collusion since it reduces the losses in the surplus from trade due to a higher price, and therefore precluding collusion becomes more expensive. Then, we qualify our results in a more ideal environment where incentive payments can be made contingent on the regulator’s type or Congress does not have to delegate the regulatory task to a (possibly) collusive regulator and it can directly regulate the firm. We feel that the predictions of our analysis can shed new light on regulation as a bargaining process and provide a contribution to the practical and theoretical debate on collusion in regulatory relationships.

Title: Cournot–Bertrand comparison in a mixed oligopoly
Intro:
The comparison between price and quantity competition has been discussed extensively in the literature. In oligopolies among private firms, it is well known that price competition is stronger, yielding lower profits than in the case of quantity competition.Footnote 1 In related literature, Singh and Vives (1984) endogenized the structure of competition (in terms of price or quantity), finding that firms often choose whether to adopt a price contract or a quantity contract. In a private duopoly in which both firms maximize profits, and assuming linear demand and product differentiation, Singh and Vives (1984) showed that a quantity contract is the dominant strategy for each firm when goods are substitutes. Cheng (1985), Tanaka (2001a, b), and Tasnádi (2006) extended this analysis to asymmetric oligopolies, more general demand and cost conditions, and vertical product differentiation, confirming the robustness of the results. However, these results depend on the assumption that all firms are private and profit-maximizers. Therefore, they may not apply to the increasingly important and popular mixed oligopolies, in which state-owned public firms compete against private firms. In most countries, there exist state-owned public firms that have substantial influence on their market competitors. Such mixed oligopolies occur in various industries, such as the airline, steel, automobile, railway, natural gas, electricity, postal service, education, hospital, home loan, and banking industries.Footnote 2 In addition, we have repeatedly observed how many private enterprises facing financial problems have been nationalized, such as General Motors, Japan Airline, and Tokyo Electric Power Corporation. Studies on mixed oligopolies involving both state-owned public enterprises and private enterprises have recently attracted more attention and have become increasingly popular. 
Ghosh and Mitra (2010) revisited the comparison between price and quantity competition in a mixed duopoly. They showed that, in contrast to the case of a private duopoly, quantity competition is stronger than price competition, resulting in a smaller profit for the private firm.Footnote 3 Then, Matsumura and Ogawa (2012) examined the endogenous competition structure. In their study of a mixed duopoly, when one of the two firms is public, a price contract is the dominant strategy for both the private and the public firm, regardless of whether goods are substitutes or complements.Footnote 4 However, in their analysis, they assume that one public firm competes against one private firm. In this study, we allow for more than one private firm and investigate whether the two aforementioned results hold in an oligopoly. First, we revisit this price-quantity comparison in mixed oligopolies. We adopt a standard differentiated oligopoly with a linear demand (Dixit 1979) and show that, regardless of the number of private firms, the Bertrand model always yields higher welfare.
