However, the profit ranking depends on the number of private firms. If the number of private firms is less than or equal to four, the Bertrand model yields a larger profit for each private firm. However, if the number of private firms is greater than or equal to five, the profit can be larger under Cournot competition. Here, the Bertrand model always yields smaller profits, regardless of the degree of substitutability, if the number of private firms is sufficiently large. Next, we endogenize the competition structure (i.e., price or quantity) using the model of Singh and Vives (1984). We show that Bertrand competition can fail to be an equilibrium when the number of private firms is greater than or equal to two. These results suggest that, in contrast to the case of private oligopolies, the results of mixed oligopolies depend on the number of the private firms, both in terms of price-quantity comparison and in terms of endogenous competition structure. Finally, we investigate a model with multiple public firms. In the literature on mixed oligopolies, it is standard to assume that only one public firm competes against a number of private firms.Footnote 5 Recently, studies have begun allowing for multiple public firms, such as Matsumura and Shimizu (2010), Bose and Gupta (2013), Matsumura and Matsushima (2012), and Matsumura and Okumura (2013). A typical example of multiple public firms is the financial market in Japan. In China and Russia, many industries have multiple public firms, such as the banking, energy, and transportation industries. We consider the case in which the number of public firms is same as that of private firms. With regard to Bertrand–Cournot competition, we find that Bertrand competition always yields a larger total social surplus and profit in private firms, regardless of the number of private firms. This result suggests that the profit ranking does not depend on the number of private firms, but instead depends on how the weight of private firms in the market increases. However, with regard to the endogenous competition structure, the equilibrium competition structure does depend on the number of private firms. When two public firms compete against two private firms, Bertrand competition can fail to be an equilibrium, which is a common result in models with one public and two private firms. With regard to the Bertrand–Cournot comparison, Scrimitore (2014) established an important contribution. She adopted the partial privatization approach of Matsumura (1998) and considered the optimal degree of privatization. Her findings show that under optimal privatization policies, Cournot competition can yield higher profits in private firms than in the case of Bertrand competition. The optimal degree of privatization is lower under Bertrand competition, and a lower degree of privatization leads to stronger competition. Here, the profit ranking can be reversed under optimal privatization policies. Our study shows that the profit ranking can be reversed even if we do not consider optimal privatization policies. The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents the proposed model, and Sect. 3 compares Bertrand and Cournot competition. Section 4 endogenizes the competition structure (i.e., a price or quantity contract). Then, Sect. 5 considers a case of multiple public firms. The proofs of the propositions can be found in Appendix B.

Title: A model of advance selling with consumer heterogeneity and limited capacity
Consistent location conjectures under spatial price discrimination
Gershkov, Alex and Benny Moldovanu: Dynamic allocation and pricing: a mechanism design approach
Shiller, Robert J.: Irrational exuberance. Revised and expanded third edition
Utilitarian population ethics and births timing
Intro:
In Reasons and Persons, Parfit (1984) emphasized some major shortcomings faced by utilitarian social welfare criteria in the context of different numbers choices. On the one hand, the classical utilitarian social welfare function suffers from the Repugnant Conclusion: for any large population, there exists a much larger population with a much lower welfare per head, but which yields a larger aggregate welfare than the former population, and which is thus regarded as strictly better under classical utilitarianism. On the other hand, average utilitarianism suffers from the Mere Addition Paradox: the addition, to some population, of a given number of persons with a welfare slightly lower than the initial average welfare is regarded as socially undesirable under average utilitarianism, even if the welfare of the initial population is left unaffected. Following Parfit’s pioneer work, utilitarian population ethics has been developed in various directions. The search for alternative social welfare criteria that can escape from the two counterintuitive results mentioned above has received a strong attention. That research program has produced various new social welfare criteria, such as critical-level utilitarianism (Blackorby and Donaldson 1984), number-dampened utilitarianism (Hurka 1983; Ng 1986), and critical-band utilitarianism (Blackorby et al. 2005).Footnote 1 Besides new utilitarian social welfare criteria, new paradoxes and impossibility results have also been produced (Arrhenius and Bykvist 1995; Bykvist 2007; Arrhenius 2013). Moreover, utilitarian population ethics has been applied to some complex ethical dilemmas, such as the treatment of future generations (Broome 1992; Arrhenius and Bykvist 1995), or the trade-off between the addition of new persons and the extension of the life of existing persons (Broome 2004; Arrhenius 2008). Most of the population ethics literature relies on an abstract representation of human societies, which is often reduced to two dimensions: (1) a population size; (2) a level of utility for each person. More recently, economists revisited utilitarian population ethics within economic environments, where other dimensions of life are modeled. Renström and Spataro (2011) applied the critical-level utilitarian criterion to the question of the optimal population growth in a dynamic overlapping generations (OLG) economy with physical capital accumulation, which was first formulated by Samuelson (1975) under average utilitarianism. Jouvet and Ponthiere (2011) revisited the trade-off between adding new persons and extending the life of existing persons in a dynamic OLG economy with a fixed living space. Boucekkine and Fabbri (2013) reconsidered Parfit’s Repugnant Conclusion within a dynamic economic model of endogenous growth. More recently, Bouccekine et al. (2014) examined the extent to which equalizing the consumption of all individuals in all generations can be the optimal solution to a utilitarian social planning problem consisting in choosing the optimal age structure dynamics under the constraint of a given initial age structure. Besides theoretical developments, the population ethics literature also evolves through the new challenges it faces. New phenomena can raise new ethical dilemmas. One of those new phenomena consists of the recent postponement of births. Since the 1970s, demographers have observed a significant postponement of parenthood. That postponement is illustrated on Fig. 1.Footnote 2
 Average age of women at first birth (period) In the case of Sweden, for instance, the average age of women at first birth has increased from age 24 in 1970 to age 29 in 2010. The postponement of births is a fundamental evolution of the last decades, which, as such, raises several questions, about its causes, its consequences, and about its social desirability. Is the postponement of births socially desirable? The goal of this paper is to study the social desirability of births postponement in the long-run. For that purpose, we study, within a dynamic framework, whether the postponement of births is socially desirable or not from the perspective of utilitarian population ethics. As this is well-known, utilitarian ethics answers questions about social desirability of actions or policies by means of the calculus of social welfare under those different actions or policies (without emphasis on individual choices). In the present context, we propose to examine how utilitarian population ethics criteria would rank histories that are equal on all dimensions except one: the timing of births. The problem can be presented as follows. Suppose that a life includes not one, but several fertility periods, during which one can give birth to children. The question that we ask is the following: which fertility profile is optimal from a utilitarian perspective? To illustrate the problem, Fig. 2 shows, for a lifetime equal to four periods and including two fertility periods (periods 2 and 3), two possible alternatives, coined “early births” and “late births” respectively. One can also refer to those two societies as two distinct islands, i.e.  Early Island and Late Island. The fertility rates n and m denote, respectively, the number of children born during the first and the second reproduction periods. As shown on Fig. 2, the fertility timing implies two major differences. A first difference concerns the coexistence time between the parent and the child. At each point in time, four generations coexist when births are early, whereas only two cohorts coexist when births are late. Moreover, whereas children can coexist with their grand-parents on Early Island, this is not the case on Late Island, where grandparents are dead when the grandchildren are born. Another difference lies in how the current cohort size is related to the past cohort size. In Early Island, the size of a newborn cohort is directly related to the size of the cohort that is born at the previous period. However, on Late Island, the size of a newborn cohort is related to the size of the cohort born two periods before, which generates a different population dynamics. Early births versus late births In order to study the social desirability of birth postponement, we will focus here on an economy with a fixed living space.Footnote 3 That living space is a common resource, which is used, at a given point in time, by all individuals who are alive at that time. One can regard that economy with fixed living space as a “spaceship economy”, in line with Boulding’s metaphor of the Earth as a spaceship (Boulding 1966). On that spaceship, individual welfare is assumed to depend positively on the available space per head, space being here equally distributed among the living individuals.Footnote 4 The positive effect of space per head on individual welfare can be interpreted in several ways. One may consider that space consumption matters for its own sake, so that a too large population can lead to welfare-reducing congestion (Marshall 1890).Footnote 5 Another interpretation consists of considering that space is used in production, so that a too large population can also reduce welfare through output reduction (Hardin 1968). The timing of births being an inherently dynamic issue, we will study the social desirability of birth postponement in a dynamic framework where distinct generations overlap with each others. The advantage of that framework is that it includes, in addition to information about population size and utility, information about the age-structure of the population, and on the duration of overlap between generations, which is most relevant for the issue at stake. We develop a T-period dynamic overlapping generations economy where individual temporal welfare depends positively on the available space per head, and where agents have children in one out of two reproduction periods. Then, we compare, by means of various utilitarian population ethics criteria, such as classical utilitarianism (CU), average utilitarianism (AU) and critical-level utilitarianism (CLU), two economies that have exactly the same initial conditions, the same longevity, but differ regarding the fertility timing: in one economy, all births take place early in life (i.e. Early Island), whereas in the other economy, all births take place later on in life (i.e. Late Island). The welfare comparisons are carried out in four stages. In a first stage, the comparison focuses on finite histories, i.e. histories where an equal finite number of life-periods is lived by humans. Then, in a second stage, we compare infinite histories, i.e. histories where an infinite number of life-periods is lived by humans, by focusing on histories with a constant long-run population size. In a third stage, the robustness of those comparisons is examined by introducing an additional determinant of human well-being: the coexistence time with descendants, which varies across the different births timing (see Fig. 2). Finally, we examine the social desirability of a sudden transition from an early births regime to a late births regime, which amounts to compare histories differing in the timing of births and in their starting points. Anticipating on our results, we first show, when comparing finite histories with an equal number of life-periods but different fertility timing, that CU, AU and CLU criteria select the same fertility timing, which is the one leading to the most smoothed population pattern over time. That optimal birth timing depends on the initial age-structure within the reproductive age-group. When the comparison focuses on infinite histories with constant long-run population sizes, the fertility timing recommended by CU, AU and CLU depends on the form of the temporal utility function, as well as on the initial age-structure. Those results are qualitatively robust to the introduction of coexistence concerns across generations, except insofar as those coexistence concerns push towards earlier births, in such a way as to allow for longer periods of coexistence between humans. Hence the socially optimal birth timing depends, at the end of the day, on how congestion and coexistence concerns are weighted against each other. Regarding the social desirability of a transition from an early births regime to a late births regime, we show that such a transition is, for an equal total number of life-periods, socially desirable when individuals have no coexistence concerns, but may be undesirable under strong coexistence concerns. In sum, the major contribution of this paper is to provide, by means of a general dynamic overlapping generations model, a formal analysis of the social desirability, from a utilitarian perspective, of the postponement of births. Our key findings are: (1) the social desirability of birth postponement depends, in general, on the postulated population ethics criterion; (2) the social desirability of birth postponement depends strongly on the initial age structure of the population; (3) the social desirability of births postponement varies also depending on the importance of spacial congestion and coexistence concerns within individual’s preferences; (4) the conclusions that can be drawn are sensitive to the precise framing of the model, in the sense that a study of the desirability of different simultaneous histories is not formally similar to a study of the desirability of a sudden transition from one births regime to another regime. By its findings, the present paper contributes to the recent renewal of the optimal fertility literature. In a canonical paper, Golosov et al. (2007) revisited the optimal fertility by extending Pareto efficiency to situations of varying population sizes. Their extension gave birth to two concepts: A-efficiency (focusing on the well-being of each individual alive in all situations under comparison) and P-efficiency (which treats alive and potential individuals in symmetric ways). More recently, Conde-Ruiz et al. (2010) proposed to revisit optimal fertility, by means of the concept of Millian efficiency (constrained A-efficiency). In comparison with the present study—which is based on utilitarian criteria—, those two recent papers rely on more general normative foundations. However, both Golosov et al. (2007) and Conde-Ruiz et al. (2010) rely on a framework with a unique fertility period, in the sense that individuals have all their children at the same point in their life. The present study, on the contrary, relies on a framework that allows also for the study of the optimal timing for births. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents the framework. Section 3 compares histories with different birth timings, in the case of finite histories with an equal total number of life-periods. Section 4 compares histories with different birth timing in the case of infinite histories with a constant asymptotic population sizes. Section 5 considers an extended model where individuals value coexistence with their descendants. Section 6 examines the social desirability of a transition, at a given point in time, from an early births regime to a late births regime. Section 7 concludes.

Title: Harsh occupations, health status and social security
Optimal implicit collusion in repeated procurement auctions
Assaf, Razin: Understanding global crises: an emerging paradigm
Selected Books Received
Sustaining collusion in markets with entry driven by balanced growth
Leniency programs under demand uncertainty: cartel stability and the duration of price wars
Intro: Leniency programs (LPs) aim to improve cartel deterrence by offering fine reductions to cartel members that voluntarily self-report or cooperate during investigation. The objective of this paper is to examine the effect of LPs on collusion when demand is stochastic and firms cannot perfectly observe their rival’s choices. It is shown that an LP may affect both, the duration of the competitive price wars which are necessary for cartel stability, and the levels of demand uncertainty under which collusion is viable. While it is well known that no collusive agreement can be successful without the participating firms’ willingness to credibly punish deviations, there are instances where extremely hard punishments may be counterproductive. Such is the case analyzed in Green and Porter (1984), (GP hereafter) where in the presence of unexpected demand slumps it is preferable for cartel-participating firms unable to perfectly monitor each other’s actions to adopt strategies that are more lenient than the so-called “grim” (or “trigger”) strategy.Footnote 1 In the GP context, a firm observing low sales cannot distinguish whether they are due to a deliberate price cut by a rival, or simply to sluggish demand. Punishing to infinity destroys, potentially for no reason, an otherwise profitable cartel. At the same time, not punishing at all induces cheating on the cartel agreement with certainty. An intermediate solution is a strategy that calls for interrupting cooperation every time low sales are observed (independently of their origin), but only for a limited number of periods. GP shows that a long enough period of cooperation-interruption is sufficient to induce loyalty to the cartel agreement. This way, cooperation may be disrupted for a number of periods giving its place to price wars, but stays alive in the long run. In this paper we consider a supergame in which firms choose between competing and colluding. The demand is stochastic and a low demand state occurs with positive probability, while each firm cannot perfectly observe the price set by the rival. We show that leaving the LP available after an inspection has already been launched (post-investigation leniency) may have ambiguous effects on collusion. When negative demand shocks are frequent, post-investigation leniency may (a) reduce the duration of temporary competitive price wars, and (b) enlarge the set of negative-demand-shock probabilities for which the collusive agreement is viable. In other words, introducing leniency may in some instances enhance, instead of undermining cartel stability. Cartel stability is more likely to be enhanced when negative-demand-shocks are expected to be frequent in the future, and the probability of conviction after investigation is already high. Our conclusion is that in such cases, fine reductions not only are of little help, but also have undesirable side-effects. On the contrary, when the probability of conviction is low, leniency policies always result in a welfare improvement. The effect of LP on cartels is first examined in Motta and Polo (2003) which stresses the importance of post-investigation leniency. Spagnolo (2004) concludes that costless cartel deterrence can be achieved when the first informant is rewarded sufficiently. Chen and Rey (2013) shows that it is optimal to provide leniency post-investigation when conviction is not very likely without self-reporting. Studying empirically the effectiveness of the early European corporate LP, Brenner (2009) concludes it has not significantly affected cartel stability, eventually because of the weakness of the provided incentives. The paper is organized as follows: The model is described and benchmark is set in Sect. 2. Section 3 contains the solution of the model when post-investigation leniency is introduced. In Sect. 4 the analysis is concluded.

Title: Revenue royalties
Intro:
Patent licensing plays a crucial role in modern economies for the dissemination of innovations and technological improvements across firms (Kamien and Tauman 1986; Katz and Shapiro 1986). Consider a firm owning a cost-reducing innovation. It can increase its own profits by licensing the innovation both to competitors and to non-competitors. In the former case, the patentee is said to be an insider innovator, while in the latter case it is an outsider innovator (Sen and Tauman 2007). We consider the case of an insider innovator. The patentee has several options for licensing the innovation to its competitors. Theoretical investigation on patent licensing has typically considered licensing contracts based on the quantity produced by the licensee. Furthermore, literature commonly assumes constant returns to scale. Therefore, under that assumption, the kind of contract scrutinized by theorists typically consists in per-unit royalties, alone or combined with fixed fees (two-part tariffs), where “per-unit royalties” means that the licensee pays to the patentee a certain royalty per any unit it sells. The typical result is that per-unit royalty is preferred to fixed fee by the patentee (Wang 1998; Wang and Yang 1999; Poddar and Sinha 2004; Filippini 2005). As expected, two-part tariffs perform even better, but they may decrease welfare (Faulí-Oller and Sandonìs 2002; Colombo 2012). In this paper we extend the literature by considering ad valorem royalty contracts and revenue-royalty contracts, where the price, rather than the quantity, is the basis of the licensing contract. In particular, “ad valorem royalty” means that the patentee extracts a quota of the licensee’s profits in change of the license, whereas “revenue-royalty” means that the patentee extracts a quota of the licensee’s revenues.Footnote 1
\(^{, }\)
Footnote 2
 We assume that the cost function may have various degrees of convexity, and we show that several licensing contracts—two-part per-unit royalty contract, ad valorem royalty contract and revenue-royalty contract—may represent the preferred contract for the patentee, depending on the convexity of the cost function. Therefore, the degree of the convexity of the cost function may contribute to explain the real-world existence of different types of licensing contracts. Indeed, both ad valorem royalties and revenue-royalties are widely diffused in practice.Footnote 3 For example, Bousquet et al. (1998), by studying a dataset of French firms, find that 78 % of contracts include royalties and amongst these, only 4 % are per-unit royalties while 96 % are other types of royalties (ad valorem royalties or revenue-royalties). Another study by Lim and Veugelers (2002) on technology licensing contracts in US shows that at least 20 % of licensing agreements include some forms of ad valorem and revenue-royalty in the payment scheme. Sakakibara (2010) finds that a revenue-royalty scheme is better than a fixed fee payment in representing the patent price in the Japan industry. Macho-Stadler et al. (1996), by using a dataset of 241 licensing contracts in Spain, find that revenue-royalties are more common than per-unit royalties. Niu (2013) reports that the medical firm CSIRO in 2005 licensed an innovative medical device to Polynovo employing ad valorem royalties. Another example of ad valorem royalties is provided by Microsoft, when in 2006 it gave Skinkers the intellectual property rights for the peer-to-peer technology (Niu 2013). Very recently, Johnson and Johnson licensed an experimental ebola vaccine to a Danish vaccine maker, Nord Bavarian, in change of ad valorem royalties.Footnote 4
\(^{,}\)
Footnote 5 On the other hand, revenue-royalties contracts are adopted for exclusive patent licensing agreements between the US state-owned National Renewable Energy Laboratory and its licensees.Footnote 6 Similarly, revenue-royalties are used for those inventions whose intellectual property belongs to the University of California at Davis.Footnote 7 Confindustria (Confederation of the Italian firms) explicitly suggests its members to license their innovations by using either a per-unit royalty contract or a revenue-royalty contract.Footnote 8
 Our main results are the following. In the case of non-drastic innovation,Footnote 9 we find that the patentee prefers adopting ad valorem royalties when the returns to scale are scarcely or highly decreasing, while revenue-royalties are the preferred option when the degree of convexity of the cost function is intermediate-low. When the returns to scale are intermediate-highly decreasing, the preferred option is the two-part per-unit royalty contract. The intuition is the following. For low or high levels of convexity of the cost function, the ad valorem royalty licensing contract allows the patentee to have a great commitment power, that is, the patentee is able to commit to be less aggressive. Therefore, the patentee prefers this licensing method in order to keep the overall quantity low and to extract a quota of the profits from the licensee. When the degree of convexity of the cost function is intermediate-low, revenue-royalties turn out to be the preferred option for the patentee. Indeed, when the production costs go up, the patentee renounces to the commitment power guaranteed by the ad valorem method and prefers passing to revenue-royalties in order not to sustain (part of) the costs of production of the licensee. Finally, when the degree of convexity of the cost function is intermediate-high, the patentee prefers to balance the overall production between itself and the licensee by using a fixed fee together with the per-unit royalty. In this way, it is able to limit an excessive increase of the costs of production. In the case of drastic innovation, the ad valorem royalty contract is the preferred licensing mechanism for the patentee. Indeed, under the ad valorem royalty contract the patentee is able to replicate the multiplant monopolist, thus obtaining the highest profits. Few papers introduce convex costs functions in the context of licensing contracts for a cost-reducing innovation. Mukherjee (2014) considers an insider innovator that has to decide how many licenses to sell for a new product, and he finds that, in the presence of a convex cost function, it is better to sell the license to all the potential licensees. The analysis is performed under the hypothesis of per-unit royalties. Sen and Stamatopoulos (2009, 2013) compare fixed fees and per-unit royalties under the hypothesis of decreasing returns to scale, and find that the incidence of positive royalties is inversely related to the economies of scale. However, these papers do not consider alternative kinds of licensing contracts. The remaining of this article proceeds as follows. In Sect. 2 we introduce the model. In Sect. 3 we compare the two-part per unit royalty contract, the ad valorem royalty contract, and the revenue-royalty contract. In Sect. 4 we discuss a pure per-unit royalty contract. In Sect. 5 we consider more complex licensing contracts. Section 5.4 concludes. In “Appendix 1” we provide a numerical simulation of the main results, whereas in “Appendix 2” we discuss a variation of the main model.

Title: Moral hazard in innovation: the relationship between risk aversion and performance pay
Akerlof, George A. and Shiller, Robert J.: Phishing for phools: The economics of manipulation and deception
Free entry and social inefficiency under co-opetition
Intro:
In many industries, firms compete for market share while managing common property resources that affect the market size or consumers’ willingness to pay for products. This simultaneous competition and cooperation is called “co-opetition” (Brandenburger and Nalebuff 1996). For example, mobile phone companies, tourist sites, and food courts share common property resources such as base-station antennas, historic ruins in natural environments, and common dining areas, respectively. The quality of common property resources affects the market size and/or consumers’ willingness to pay for the products or services. Furthermore, the high quality of such resources generates non-excludable benefits for all firms in the industry. Therefore, each firm’s investment in common property resources (e.g., erecting additional base-station antennas, preserving historic ruins and the natural environment, and maintaining a hygienic eating environment) creates public-good benefits that all the firms can enjoy.Footnote 1 Another example is generic advertising for various commodities such as beverages, fruit, and meat and dairy products. Improving product image generates non-excludable benefits for all producers providing the same products. Firms’ investment in product safety is also considered as co-opetive behavior when they share an industry’s collective reputation for product safety.Footnote 2 In the aforementioned examples, firms share the product image as a common property resource and sometimes voluntarily contribute to improving it.Footnote 3
 Is free entry into such co-opetitive industries desirable from a social welfare perspective? To answer this question, we have to identify the following two effects of free entry on social welfare. One is the well-known business stealing effect of entry, which creates production inefficiency in the presence of scale economies (Mankiw and Whinston 1986; Suzumura and Kiyono 1987) and generally leads to socially excessive entry. The other is the effect of entry on the amount of common property resources, which we call the common property effect of entry. On the one hand, an increase in the number of firms may increase the total investment in common property resources. In this case, free entry may result in socially insufficient entry because firms do not consider the positive external effect of their investment in common property resources on other firms. On the other hand, an increase in the number of firms may also exacerbate the under-provision of common property resources, which may lead to a tragedy-of-the-commons situation. For instance, an increase in the number of tourism firms can deteriorate the quality of tourist attractions (such as wild life and historic ruins), which can eventually destroy tourism itself. As Puppim de Oliveira (2003) indicates, locations such as Acapulco in Mexico, the French Riviera and Mallorca and Torremolinos in Spain have faced tourism-related environmental issues. In these cases, the common property effect contributes to socially excessive entry. This leads us to the question of whether the government should regulate or encourage firm entry into the co-opetitive industry. In this study, we formulate a simple model of co-opetition with endogenous entry to present a welfare analysis of free entry equilibrium. In particular, we consider whether the number of firms that can enter a co-opetitive market is excessive or insufficient from the viewpoint of social welfare. We distinguish between two types of investment in common property resources: pre-commitment and non-commitment investments. In the case of non-commitment investment, firms choose their output and investment in the same stage; we call this game a “simultaneous co-opetition game.” In the case of pre-commitment investment, firms determine their investment before they choose their output; we call this a “sequential co-opetition game.” In both games, firms’ entry decisions are made in the first stage. The difference between non-commitment and pre-commitment investments reflects the difference in reversibility and persistency in investment. When investment has long-term impacts and is difficult to reverse (e.g., renovating historic buildings in a tourist area and increasing base-station antennas for mobile phone networks), it has strategic commitment value, which can be described by a sequential co-opetition game. In contrast, when investment has short-term impacts and is easy to reverse (e.g., providing generic advertising in daily newspapers and cleaning shopping malls or food courts), it has no strategic commitment value, which can be described as a simultaneous co-opetition game. We show that whether free entry into a co-opetitive industry is socially excessive or insufficient depends on the relative strength of business stealing and common property effects of entry. The former effect, as indicated by previous studies such as those by Mankiw and Whinston (1986), is based on the fact that an entrant firm does not consider its negative impact on other firms’ profits.Footnote 4 Therefore, when firms face fixed entry (set-up) costs, the business stealing effect leads to the excess entry of firms into the market caused by the socially wasteful replication of entry costs. The latter effect is novel and depends on the effect of entry on the total amount (or quality) of common property resources. An increase in the number of entrants increases the incentive to “free ride” on other firms’ investments in common property resources (public goods). However, the total amount of common property resources may increase because of a rise in the number of entrants. If that is the case, then such entry will generate positive external effects for other firms. Because private firms do not consider the positive externality when deciding whether to enter a market, the common property effect leads to insufficient entry. If market entry results in a reduction in the total amount of common property resources, then such entry will create negative external effects for other firms. In this case, a negative common property effect leads to excess entry. We find that in the simultaneous co-opetition game, an increase in the number of firms increases the total investment in common property resources while reducing individual investment per firm. Thus, the business stealing and common property effects function in opposite directions. In other words, whether free entry is socially excessive or insufficient depends on the relative magnitude of the two effects. In particular, by providing two concrete examples that assume linear and constant elasticity demand, we show that free entry is more likely to result in socially insufficient entry when initial market size as well as investment and production cost are smaller and/or the demand is more elastic. However, the business stealing and common property effects work in the same directions in the sequential co-opetition game, in which investment has a commitment value. The important aspect in this case is that the total investment in common property resources is decreased by an increase in the number of entrants. This is in contrast to the result of the simultaneous co-opetition game, because when investment has a commitment value, an increase in firm’s investments induces rival firms to respond more aggressively by increasing their output in the subsequent stage. Therefore, this pre-commitment effect of investment reduces the incentive to invest in common property resources. Because an increase in the number of rival firms strengthens the pre-commitment effect, the sequential co-opetition game gives rise to a negative common property effect of entry. Therefore, excess entry holds in sequential co-opetition. Interestingly, we show that the excess entry results hold for the sequential co-opetition game even when there are no entry costs caused by the negative common property effect. Our results enrich the established excess entry theorem in theoretical industrial organization literature. The theorem shows that in a Cournot model with homogenous products, free entry is socially excessive when firms incur fixed entry costs.Footnote 5 Our results from the simultaneous co-opetition game suggest that free entry may lead to socially insufficient entry when firms share common property resources that raise industry-wide demand or consumers’ willingness to pay for products. Furthermore, we show that excess entry occurs in the sequential co-opetition game even when there are no entry costs. Existing literature extends the excess entry theorem in various directions. Konishi et al. (1990) extend the traditional Cournot model with free entry to a general equilibrium model and explore Pareto-improving tax-subsidy policies. Incorporating strategic cost-reducing R&D activities into the Cournot model, Okuno-Fujiwara and Suzumura (1993) show that the existence of R&D investment strengthens the tendency of excess entry in a free-entry equilibrium. The critical difference between R&D investment in their study and investment in common property resources in our study is that the former generates private benefits for the investing firm, while the latter generates public benefits for all firms. Recently, Haruna and Goel (2011) and Wang et al. (2015) have also considered the problem of excess entry in the presence of cost-reducing R&D with spillovers. Our sequential co-opetition game with linear demand is iso-morphic to the case of R&D with perfect spillovers in Haruna and Goel (2011) and Wang et al. (2015).Footnote 6 However, our study considers various model specifications, including simultaneous-move model, non-linear demand, and investment cooperation. In particular, we find that the commitment power of investment in common property resources is a key factor determining whether free entry leads to excess or insufficient entry.Footnote 7
 Previous studies have found that free entry can result in socially insufficient entry (Spence 1976; Dixit and Stiglitz 1977; Kühn and Vives 1999; Ghosh and Saha 2007). Ghosh and Morita (2007) consider a vertical relationship in a homogeneous Cournot model and show that free entry in the upstream sector can lead to socially insufficient entry. The driving force behind their insufficient entry result is that entry in the upstream sector has a positive external effect on the downstream sector’s profit. However, the driving force behind our insufficient entry result is that entry may have a positive external effect on other firms’ profits through changes in the quality of common property resources. Incorporating constant elasticity demand into a standard Salop (1979) spatial framework, Gu and Wenzel (2009) show that the excess entry theorem does not hold when the price elasticity of demand is high. Although their study differs from ours in several respects, the conclusions are similar; insufficient entry occurs when price elasticity of demand is high. Therefore, the degree of price elasticity of demand may serve as a guideline for entry regulation policy.Footnote 8
 Using a free-entry oligopoly model, Etro (2006) considers the optimal behavior of a leader firm that can make a strategic precommitment on a “profit enhancing factor” before choosing outputs or prices. In contrast to the case with barriers to entry, when entry is free, the leader can take into account of the effect of its own investment on entry. He shows that the leader firm always undertakes aggressive investment in a market with free entry, and surprisingly, this does not depend on the mode of competition or strategic interaction among firms.Footnote 9 Our definition of co-opetitive investment is similar to the profit-enhancing one in Etro (2006), but there are two important differences. First, the investment in Etro (2006) is undertaken before entry stage, whereas the co-opetitive investment is undertaken after the entry stage. Second, the former can be undertaken only by the leader firm, whereas the co-opetitive investment can be undertaken by all firms, which benefits all firms in the industry. Furthermore, the main objective of Etro (2006) is to consider the optimality of preliminary investment by the leader firm under endogenous entry threats, whereas ours is to consider the welfare evaluation of free entry in a situation where all incumbent firms can (or should) engage in co-opetitive investment. This study is organized as follows. Section 2 presents the basic structure of the model. Section 3 considers a simultaneous co-opetition game, investigates the properties of free-entry equilibrium, and compares it with the second-best. Section 4 investigates the same for a sequential co-opetition game. Section 5 discusses some policy implications and a possible extension of the analysis. Section 6 concludes the study.

Title: Optimal know-how transfers in licensing contracts
Intro:
Licensing is an important channel for technology transfer. The returns from technology licensing allow the owner of an invention, that is protected by patent laws, to recover part of its incurred R&D expenses. How profitable can licensing be will depend on how broad or narrow is the target market. Tacit knowledge or know-how also plays an important role in the successful transfer of many innovations, often complementing the transfer of codified knowledge. Our paper is a contribution to the literature on optimal licensing contracts in the presence of moral hazard associated with costly provision of know-how by the licensor. In a setting where the target market consists of a fraction of heterogeneous consumers who have enough valuation for the new product, we want to address the question of whether a licensor will include know-how, and if so, under which conditions the transfer of know-how fails to be complete. The scarce existing evidence on licensing contracts reveals that licensing by means of a fixed fee is less frequently used than royalties or a combination of them.Footnote 1 However, as emphasized by the large existing literature on technology transfer (see, for instance, Teece 1977), contracting for technology involves transaction costs. These costs include the costs of writing contracts as well as the costs of transferring know-how. With regard to international technology transfers, Arora (1996) showed that bundling know-how with other complementary inputs increases the efficiency of contracts. He argues that a successful transfer of technology, especially to firms in developing countries, requires that tacit knowledge complement codified knowledge. Tacit knowledge is intangible or informal knowledge that cannot be put into words, which is transmitted by personal contact and learned by experience. Hence, arm’s-length transactions of know-how are potentially affected by moral hazard problems. Since transferring know-how is costly, the licensor has incentives to spare on the quality or extent of the know-how transferred. On the licensee’s side, it may fail to honor the contract after learning the know-how. The costly efforts to transfer know-how may be observable to the parties, but not verifiable to a third party, and therefore contracts contingent on these efforts are not enforceable in courts. This way, compensation structures become relevant in these inter-firm relationships. Along these lines, Aulakh et al. (1998) document, among other things, that licensor involvement in foreign markets is higher under a royalty-based agreement to ensure appropriate use of know-how, meet quality standards and so on. In this paper we wish to explore optimal know-how transfer in licensing contracts. 
Kamien (1992) provides an excellent survey of the literature on licensing, where optimal licensing policies are reviewed in a game theory framework. Sen and Tauman (2007) provide a general presentation and offer a good overview of the licensing literature. See also Mukherjee (2009) for a survey on technology licensing. Output based royalties are typically used as a response to asymmetric information; they may also be used to induce licensees to reduce output, or as a reaction to moral hazard.Footnote 2 Relevant theoretical justifications for using royalties that allude to informational asymmetries include Gallini and Wright (1990), Macho-Stadler and Pérez-Castrillo (1991) and Beggs (1992). In Marjit and Mukherjee (2001) the quality of the technology is private information. These authors consider alternative ways of international technology transfer to show that a pure technology licensing agreement is not always preferred. Incumbent innovators have a preference for royalty licensing in order to control for competition intensity, as in Wang (1998), Kamien and Tauman (2002), and Mukherjee and Pennings (2006), to mention a few. More related to our work is the literature on licensing with moral hazard. Macho-Stadler et al. (1996) and Choi (2001), in a setting with one-sided and double-sided moral hazard, respectively, show that the optimal contract between a licensor and a licensee will typically include royalties so as to provide the parties with the right incentives to undertake effort. Our model is thus a contribution to the licensing literature as we characterize the optimal licensing contract in the presence of costly provision of know-how by the licensor. Our analysis can also be related to the existing literature on the endogenous provision of technology quality with costly technology transfer. The recent paper by Mukherjee and Tsai (2015) features a licensing model with an incumbent innovator, who chooses to license its technology at a certain quality level; higher quality entails lower licensee’s marginal cost, but this is at the expense of higher transfer cost. They show that firms profit and social welfare are higher under a two-part tariff contract that includes an output royalty. The royalty included in the licensing contract induces a higher quality level transfer, although the best technology is not necessarily transferred. In contrast to Mukherjee and Tsai (2015), we consider a product innovation that is licensed by an external licensor where the provision of know-how is endogenous and reduces the marginal production costs. In line with the extant literature on know-how, we assume that its level is observable to the licensor and the licensee but not to third parties, so it is not included in the licensing contract.Footnote 3 Additionally, and regarding demand, only a certain consumer segment may purchase the licensed product. When the relevant market is too thin, the licensor’s incentives to transfer know-how are limited by the restriction of selling to all consumers. This conditions the optimal terms of payment and the level of know-how transferred, leading to non-monotonicity between the size of the target market and the level of know-how transferred. We show that, no matter how thin the target market, know-how transfer always takes place. The optimal licensing contract includes a royalty on sales, which is non-increasing with the size of the target market. However, know-how transfer can be full or partial, where full implies that marginal production cost becomes zero. Specifically, parameter configurations with low enough maximum willingness to pay and high enough convexity of know-how cost are sufficient conditions that entail partial instead of full know-how transfer. If those conditions are not satisfied then the thinness of the target market explains when partial instead of full know-how transfer is implemented. Full transfer is chosen more frequently as it becomes less costly. Finally, it is also shown that the effective (inclusive of the royalty) marginal cost exceeds the one when know-how transfers do not occur. These results are particularly relevant for developing countries, since understanding the efficiency of different channels of technology transfer—see Saggi (2002) and Maskus (2004) for surveys—has very important welfare implications. In particular, we add another explanation for the lack of transfer of the best technology available and point at a potential inefficiency in this process as it leads to a higher effective marginal cost once technology payments are included. Other examples that preclude the licensing of the best technology can be found in Rockett (1990), Kabiraj and Marjit (1993) and Feess et al. (2009). The remainder of the paper is organized as follows: Sect. 2 begins by describing the model and assumptions. Different subsections characterize the equilibrium choice of production, know-how transfer and contract terms, before presenting the main results and intuition. Some concluding remarks close the paper.

Title: Combining the endogenous choice of timing and competition version in a mixed duopoly
Mixed oligopolies and collusion
Intro:
This article considers the case of a mixed oligopoly, that is, an industry where private firms co-exist with a public or semi-public firm. The vast and increasing literature on mixed oligopolies dates back to Merrill and Schneider (1966), and now comprehends a large array of questions.Footnote 1 In particular, this study investigates long-run competition and collusion in a mixed oligopoly. On one hand, long-run competition in mixed oligopolies has been studied in the context of partial privatization by Matsumura and Kanda (2005), Fujiwara (2007) and Cato and Matsumura (2012). Matsumura and Kanda (2005) and Fujiwara (2007) consider the case of free-entry of private firms, and they are mainly interested in the effects of the degree of privatization of the public firm on the total welfare when goods are homogeneous and differentiated, respectively, whereas Cato and Matsumura (2012) investigate the long-run effect of foreign penetration in home markets on the optimal privatization policy of the public firm. On the other hand, collusion between private firms in a super-game context has received constant attention by scholars. For example, Chang (1991, 1992) and Hackner (1995) investigate the impact of product differentiation on collusion sustainability, Motta and Polo (2003) and Ishibashi and Shimizu (2010) explore the impact of leniency programs on the collusive behaviour of private firms, Friedman and Thisse (1993), Posada and Straume (2004) and Colombo (2011) consider partial collusion, whereas Lambertini and Schultz (2003) and Albaek and Lambertini (2004) investigate the choice of the strategic variable in a context of colluding private firms. In the present article, we consider a situation where a number of private firms are trying to constitute a cartel when also a non-colluding public or semi-public firm is competing in the same market. Indeed, the private firms have the incentive to collude in order to obtain greater profits even when they operate in industries where public firms act as well. For example, a recent antitrust case handled by the Italian Antitrust Authority (ref. I743-AGCM) involved four independent private firms carrying passengers to and from Sardinia, and competing against a public-owned company that did not participate to the collusive agreement. In the Netherlands, Dijkgraaf and Gradus (2007) document the existence of collusion between private firms in the waste collection market. Notably, in this market, private firms compete not only with each other, but also with public companies. Therefore, collusion between private firms is not a priori prevented by the presence of public firms in the same market. Starting from these observations, we investigate the impact of a public firm on the conditions for the sustainability of collusion between the private firms. While the literature on the conditions for collusion sustainability is rich, the role played by a public firm in such a context has not been investigated yet.Footnote 2
 Therefore, we posit the following question: does the existence of a public or semi-public firm favor the collusion between private firms? To answer this question, we develop a parsimonious model of collusion in a dynamic game. There are two private firms that try to set up a cartel. However, there is also another firm which does not participate to the cartel. As in Matsumura (1998), the government owns a positive proportion of the shares of the non-colluding firm. Therefore, the non-colluding firm takes into consideration both its own profits and the social welfare: by varying the weight attached to each of these two components in the firm’s objective function, we cover all the intermediate cases between the two extreme situations where the non-colluding firm is a purely private firm or a purely public firm. We analyse how variations of the public quota in the non-colluding firm affect the sustainability of collusion between the private firms. We find that increasing the public ownership of the non-colluding firm may increase or decrease collusion sustainability between the private firms. In particular, when the products are strongly substitutable, the existence of a public or semi-public firm that does not participate to the cartel makes the punishment in the case of a deviation from the agreement harsher and it makes the deviation less profitable. This helps sustaining collusion, as it makes the conditions for collusion sustainability milder. The opposite holds when the products are weak substitutes. The rest of this article proceeds as follows. In Sect. 2 we introduce a simple model with two colluding private firms and one non-colluding public or semi-public firm. In Sect. 3 we discuss the conditions for collusion to be sustainable in equilibrium, and we study the impact of public ownership in the non-colluding firm on the conditions for collusion sustainability. Section 4 extends the basic model in several directions. Section 5 concludes.

Title: Gernot Wagner and Martin L. Weitzman: Climate shock: the economic consequences of a hotter planet
Stern, Nicholas: Why are we waiting?: the logic, urgency and promise of tackling climate change
Contract competition between hierarchies, managerial compensation and imperfectly correlated shocks
Customer poaching and coupon trading
Nonprofit organizations, free media and donor’s trust
Intro:
In 2007, UNICEF Deutschland, one of the biggest and most well-known nonprofit organizations (NPOs) in Germany, was accused of nepotism, of having made dubious and expensive arrangements with private fund-raising agencies without written contracts, of paying suspiciously high consultant fees, which went partly to the former employees, and of the costly rebuilding of its headquarters in Cologne. The story was uncovered by a German newspaper, the Frankfurter Rundschau. Between December 2007 and April 2008, UNICEF Deutschland lost the trust of 38,000 of its individual members, worth roughly €22 million in yearly donations. Many corporate donors also revoked their donation agreements.Footnote 1
 This and other recent scandals show that there is a serious problem in the nonprofit sector. Because the donors are not the beneficiaries, they cannot estimate how much of their donation reaches the needy and how much trickles away as fund-raising and administrative costs or even as agency fees and private expenses. Although many of the nonprofit organizations seem to be devoted to achieving their chosen charitable goal to the best of their abilities, some of them, however, seek to maximize the amount of money in their own pocket. Cutlip (1990) describes the situation in the following way: Cruel exploitation of man’s urge to help his less fortunate fellow man is an ancient evil. \(\ldots \) In the early centuries of philanthropy the charity frauds were perpetrated mostly by the itinerant beggars, making false claims in their tearful appeal for alms, or of local fund appeals of questionable merit. \(\ldots \)[W]ith the advent of America’s twentieth-century surefire methods of fund raising and multibillion-dollar philanthropy, dishonest and wasteful fund raising has become a serious social problem (Cutlip 1990, p. 441). The solutions to the problem of asymmetric information proposed and implemented for typical consumer goods might not work for the nonprofit sector.Footnote 2 The reason is that the notion of quality is a very subjective one and there are few legal rules for how the money collected should be spent. This is intentional, as governments aim to increase private involvement, believing that such nonprofit organizations better understand how to help the needy. Governments do not want to restrict nonprofit activities with too much regulation. This allows “bad” nonprofit organizations to abuse the trust they are granted by the donors. Therefore, in the absence of any other mechanism revealing true quality, donors’ decisions about the amount of charitable giving must be based on the expected quality. If the level of trust is low, such that a good organization cannot cover its costs, then a complete market collapse is probable. Nevertheless, the size of the third sector is, at least in some countries, large. For example, in the US it amounted to $241 billion in 2002 (Andreoni 2006), in the Netherlands it makes up 4.95 % of GDP, whereas in Mexico it is only 0.12 % (Salamon and Sokolowski 2004). Among different possible reasons for those cross-country differences, the available information about NPOs is likely to be very important. The relevant information is provided by certifying and watchdog agencies, and by the media. Media organizations can spread information about (subjective) misconduct very quickly, and therefore severely punish an organization that relies on private contributions. In the words of Brunetti and Weder (2003) “[A]ny independent journalist has a strong incentive to investigate and uncover stories on wrongdoing.” Investigative journalism increases the probability of revealing a “bad” NPO and reduces its incentives for entering the market. What are the incentives for the media per se? The main product that they sell is news. Qualitatively good, interesting, scandalous and timely news attracts new readers and encourages loyalty among current readers. This in turn increases circulation and revenue from advertising. Furthermore, a journalist’s career concerns and private motives of the watchdog ethos may play an important role as well. Big organizations might get more attention from national and international media. Small, regional nonprofit organizations may be of interest to the regional media. This paper shows how media contributes to more transparency in the nonprofit sector. It shows that media, and especially more competition among media organizations, reduces the incentives of “bad” organizations to enter the market, thus increasing donors’ trust and the level of public good. However, the media is never able to completely deter the “bad” type from entering the market. The explanation for this is the following: if the probability of the “bad” type entering the market is zero, it does not pay off to investigate the market. Without the probability of being detected, “bad” types of organizations, expect profits and certainly enter the market. This paper contributes to the less examined research field that investigates the incentives and behavior of nonprofit organizations. Moreover, it contributes to the discussion of the performance-enhancing role of the media in the economy by highlighting the importance of media competition and freedom. Section 2 contains a literature review. Section 3 presents some empirical underpinning based on real world data on giving and press freedom. The fourth section of the paper is devoted to the development of a formal model. The last section concludes.

Title: On ambiguity apportionment
Eckwert, Bernhard and Zilcha, Itzhak: The economics of screening and risk sharing in higher education: human capital formation, income inequality, and welfare
Selected Books Received
Two ways to auction off an uncertain good
Intro:
There are many goods whose availability is uncertain to both buyers and sellers in advance such as agricultural products and even bandwidth in radio spectrum sharing. Such goods can be sold either before availability is known to the seller or after availability is known to the seller. In fact, agricultural products and radio spectrum are each sold both ways.Footnote 1 However, it is unclear as to which method is preferable to buyers and/or sellers. To investigate this issue, we examine the expected payoffs to both buyers and sellers as well as the expected social welfare to determine how the timing of such sales affects payoffs. Agricultural products are known for their uncertain production as they can be greatly affected by the weather and other forces of nature. In particular, consider the market for local produce. Such produce is commonly purchased through either a Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) share or at a farmer’s market; see Brown and Miller (2008). A CSA share is usually purchased at the beginning of the growing season and entitles the buyer to a share of the farm’s produce on a weekly basis for the duration of the growing season. The inherent risk involved in farming is then shared between the farmer and buyer. If the farm is subject to early or late freezes, unusually hot weather, or other factors that may affect production the buyer receives less produce than expected, but is not reimbursed for the loss; thus, the produce is sold before its availability is known to either the buyer or the seller; see Wilkinson (2001). The buyer may decide instead to simply purchase local produce at a farmer’s market where the availability of the produce is known at the time of the sale, and the farmer may decide to sell his produce this way if he thinks profits will be higher. Bandwidth in radio spectrum sharing is another good with uncertain availability; see Kasbekar and Sarkar (2011). Here primary users of the spectrum have licenses to use a given frequency. However, such primary users do not use the spectrum all of the time; see Engelman et al. (2002) and McHenry et al. (2006). Secondary (or non-licensed) users would like to access the spectrum when it is not in use.Footnote 2 In such a situation, the primary user could sell spectrum access to a secondary user. However, there is a chance that the primary user will need to use the spectrum himself and will not have any spectrum available to rent out. Thus, he could sell the spectrum to a secondary user either before he knows of its availability or he could sell the spectrum in real time so that availability is known at the time of purchase.Footnote 3
\(^,\)
Footnote 4 Such a secondary spectrum market is crucial for future spectrum access as PCAST (2012) estimates the number of devices connected to mobile networks could increase to 50 billion by 2020 from 5 billion in 2011. Thus, it is important to have a mechanism that mutually motivates both primary and secondary users to share the spectrum as there is a need for more efficient spectrum access; see Engelman et al. (2002), Wang et al. (2010), and Maharjan et al. (2011). Here we consider an auction framework where sellers auction off an uncertain good. Each seller has one unit of a good available with some positive probability and each buyer would like to purchase one unit. Two ways in which the sellers can auction off such an uncertain good are considered. The first is an ex-post auction which takes place after each seller learns whether or not he has a unit available to sell. The second is an ex-ante auction which takes place before the seller learns whether or not a unit is available. Both auctions used are simultaneous ascending bid auctions and it is well known that these auctions generate the lowest competitive market clearing price; see Bulow and Klemperer (1996). One can interpret an ascending bid auction as approximating prices in markets where a formal auction does not take place such as the market for local produce. Lemma 1 gives conditions under which no buyer purchases multiple expected units in the ex-ante auction. In the ex-ante case, the item auctioned off is an expected unit of the good not an actual unit. It is possible that a bidder will want to buy multiple expected units to guarantee that he ends up with an actual unit. In fact, such a buyer could end up with multiple actual units, but that buyer will only use one actual unit.Footnote 5 Such over purchasing creates a loss to society since not all of the product is indeed used. (In the case of cell phone service, if not all of the channels are used, then those which are used could be more crowded resulting in longer wait times to transmit or receive data.) Thus, it is important to know when such over purchasing can be ruled out. Proposition 3 shows that both social welfare and each seller’s expected payoff are higher in the ex-post auction than in the ex-ante auction, assuming that the conditions which rule out over purchasing in the ex-ante auction are met. Sellers expect to be better off with the ex-post auction even though not all sellers will end up with an item available to sell; since, when fewer units are actually available, these units are sold at a high price. While in the ex-ante auction all sellers sell an expected unit; thus, the number of expected units for sale is large which results in a low price. Social welfare is higher in the ex-post auction, because it is more likely that the buyer who values the good the most ends up with an actual unit. In the ex-ante auction, such a buyer always ends up with an expected unit, but may not always end up with an actual unit. A buyer is better off with the ex-post auction, if the buyer has a relatively high valuation of the unit and if the distribution of values makes it less likely that other buyers have high valuations. Such a buyer can expect to win a unit in the ex-post auction at a low price. A buyer is better off with the ex-ante auction, if his valuation is relatively low or if there are many high value buyers. Such a buyer is less likely to win a unit in the ex-post auction, but may still win an expected unit in the ex-ante auction. The current paper is related to the literature on English auctions. We use a standard ascending bid auction as discussed in the classic auction papers of Vickrey (1961), Milgrom and Weber (1982), and Riley and Samuelson (1981). However, the most closely related auction papers are Ausubel (2004) and Kranton and Minethart (2001). We borrow Kranton and Minethart (2001)’s ascending bid auction framework of multiple sellers simultaneously auctioning off units to multiple bidders. We borrow Ausubel (2004)’s ascending bid auction with clinching framework for the ex-ante auction when bidders may bid on multiple expected units. The current paper is also related to the auction literature dealing with stochastic supply; see Jeitschko (1999), Neugebauer and Pezanis-Christou (2007), and Babaioff et al. (2010). In Jeitschko (1999), there is a sequential auction of multiple items with unknown supply and each bidder wants to buy 1 unit. Conditions are given under which the expected price decreases as the price of the bids in the first auction take into account the discounted expected payoff in the second auction. This auction is somewhat similar to our ex-post auction, but differs since our auction takes place simultaneously not sequentially. For additional discussion of imperfect quantity commitment in sequential auctions see Rodriguez (2012) and Zeithammer (2009). Neugebauer and Pezanis-Christou (2007) examines supply uncertainty in a first price bid framework. While Babaioff et al. (2010) examines truthful mechanisms (or auctions) in an uncertain supply framework for online bidding. For an experimental analysis on the efficiency of using auctions to allocate uncertain goods, see Banks et al. (1989). Additionally, there is a large literature in electrical engineering which builds algorithms and/or mechanisms to implement secondary spectrum auctions occurring in real time with various properties such as incentive compatibility, reduction in communication overhead, or choice of transmitting power to name a few. See Chun and La (2013), Gandhi et al. (2007), and Zhang et al. (2013) for a literature review. However, most of this literature ignores the uncertainty regarding the availability of bandwidth. Uncertainty is examined by Kasbekar (2011) and Kasbekar and Sarkar (2011) whose analysis focuses on Bertrand style price competition among primary license holders. Thus, we add to this literature by examining the effect of uncertainty and the timing of secondary spectrum auctions on efficiency. There is also a large literature on the auctioning off of primary spectrum licenses. This work began with Coase (1959) and is eloquently reviewed by McMillan (1994). In Milgrom (2000), simultaneous ascending auctions are developed for the sale of primary radio spectrum licenses where bidding behavior will depend on whether or not the bidder thinks the licenses are substitutes for each other or complements. However, there is a lack of economics literature on the sale of secondary spectrum rights. An exception includes Milgrom (2011) who advocates for keeping some spectrum bands unlicensed as a catalyst for innovation. The paper proceeds as follows. In Sect. 2 the model is presented along with a description of the two auctions. The main results and payoff comparisons are presented in Sect. 3. A brief conclusion and discussion of possible extensions is presented in Sect. 4.

Title: Relationship-specific investment as a barrier to entry
Interlocking cross-ownership in a unionised duopoly: when social welfare benefits from “more collusion”
Intro:
Two important stylised facts regarding especially oligopolistic industries are the widespread presence of unionised labour marketsFootnote 1 and interlocking cross-shareholdings. These facts have been extensively—but so far only separately—investigated. By contrast, in this paper the relationship between cross-ownership and unionisation in a Cournot duopoly is investigated, in particular focusing on the effects of this relationship on social welfare. Most studies consider a very simple ownership structure with only one shareholder having participation in both firms.Footnote 2 In reality there are more complex kinds of cross-shareholdings: for instance, one may find “cross-participations” with each firm possessing a small amount of shares of the other (i.e. two-sided cross-ownership), or “multiple participation” with more complex direct as well as indirect links (e.g. Gilo and Spiegel 2003; Dietzenbacher and Temurshoev 2008). The case of bilateral participations in rival firms occurs fairly frequently. Thus in this paper a unionised Cournot duopoly with mutual (two-sided) cross-participation at ownership level comes under study. Since it is well established that, from a social welfare perspective, greater competition is always preferred and cross-ownership among competing firms reduces competition in the market (e.g. Farrell and Shapiro 1990; Reitman 1994), then common wisdom argues that the higher the share of cross-ownership, the lower the resulting social welfare. Since the relationship between welfare, two-sided cross-ownership and unionisation has not so far, to the best of our knowledge, been fully explored, this paper questions whether the common wisdom that the anticompetitive effect of an interlocking cross-ownership reduces social welfare still holds under the presence of firm-specific monopolistic unions, that is when wages are the outcome of a strategic game in line with the rising literature on unionised oligopolies (e.g. Dowrick 1989; Horn and Wolinsky 1988; Naylor 1999; Correa-Lopez and Naylor 2004; Fanti and Meccheri 2011). Cases of decentralised firm-specific unions are likely to arise in (1) countries with very decentralised bargaining structures such as the US, Japan and the UK, and (2) in markets separated by geographic and cultural spaces which act as obstacles to cooperation between unions.Footnote 3 In particular, as evidenced by Iversen (1998) analysing 15 OECD countries from 1973 to 1995, plant- and firm-level unions predominated (with some elements of industry-level unions) in the United States (1973–1993), Canada (1973–1995), Italy (1973–1975, 1979–1992), France (1973–1980, 1985–1995), Britain (1979–1995) and also in Japan (1973–1995), where, although national associations negotiate central agreements with some capacity for enforceability, industry-level organisations retain the right to bargain separate agreements without adherence to a peace clause. In the above countries not only firm-level unions but also interlocking cross-ownership between major companies commonly occur. Two typical examples of bilateral cross-ownership can be found, for instance as regards France and Japan, in the automobile industry and in the steel industry, respectively,Footnote 4 but there are many other examples regarding countries with significant firm-level unions.Footnote 5
 The paper develops a two-stage game. In stage 1, since both firms are unionised, unions’ choices take place simultaneously across firms: each firm-specific union sets the wage taking the wage of the other firm as given and taking into account how its decision will affect the competitiveness of its firm in the subsequent product market game.Footnote 6 In stage 2, by playing a non-cooperative Cournot oligopolistic game, firms’ owners choose their levels of output and employment, taking wages as determined in the prior stage. We proceed, as usual, by backward induction. As regards the output game, the essential feature of the existence of two-sided cross-ownership is that both firms behave “more collusively” (that is each firm internalises the fact that both firms compete in the product market) and when the mutual cross-ownership share approaches 50 %, they equally share monopolistic profits.Footnote 7
 The collusive behaviour of firms in the product market affects the firm-specific union’s behaviour, in the sense that each union is forced to dampen—with an extent depending on its members’ risk-aversion—its own wage claims. In particular, it is shown that interlocking cross-ownership is a “device” through which firms’ owners may dampen wage claims until to the elimination of the union’s rent. The main result is that, despite the degree of competition is reduced by cross-ownership, both consumer surplus and social welfare may increase with the share of mutual cross-participation, and this occurs even if the unions’ members are fairly “risk-averse” and thus their wage claims would tend to be low by itself.Footnote 8
 This unconventional welfare result occurs because mutual cross-ownerships reduce unions’ wage claims and thus, through reduced wage costs, may indirectly expand output to a greater extent than the output reduction directly induced by “more collusion”.Footnote 9 Moreover, it is shown that this result qualitatively holds also for the cases of product differentiation, Bertrand competition between firms and triopoly. Therefore, this finding, showing that social welfare benefits from the anticompetitive practice of mutual interlocking cross-ownership, offers an interesting anti-trust policy implication.Footnote 10
 The rest of the article is organised as follows. Section 2 presents the basic Cournot duopoly model, along with the equilibrium analysis. In Sect. 3, the union’s wage setting is presented and the basic model is extended with firm-specific unions. In Sect. 4 the welfare analysis is presented and the main result—that consumer surplus and social welfare increase with an increasing two-sided cross-ownership—is shown and discussed; furthermore, also the cases of (i) heterogeneous products, (ii) Bertrand competition and (iii) triopoly are briefly discussed. Section 5 concludes.

Title: Congestion in production correspondences
de La Grandville, Olivier: Economic growth: a unified approach
Taxes, subsidies, regulation in dynamic models
Investment stimuli under government present-biased time preferences
Intro: Tax rate reduction and investment subsidisation are two potential measures for the stimulation of irreversible investment under profit uncertainty. Their relative efficacy has been investigated previously. Pennings (2000) showed how a government can speed up irreversible investment at zero expected cost. This can be done by subsidising the initial investment cost and by charging a positive tax on future profits generated by the project. Pennings (2005) investigated the investment decision of a foreign monopolist, which may either export or set up productive capacity in a host country in order to serve the local market. Under investment irreversibility and demand uncertainty, he showed that domestic benefits are maximised by strongly subsidising the initial investment and by absorbing, through taxation, the benefits exceeding the gains from exporting. Yu et al. (2007) considered the impact on the timing of foreign direct investment associated with an entry cost subsidy and a reduced tax rate in a study where the two measures were considered separately and then compared. It was found that in order to speed up investment, the government should opt for an entry cost subsidy, since this is less costly and more effective than a tax reduction. Summing up, when it comes to speeding up private investment initiative, a subsidy seems to be preferable to a tax reduction. Sarkar (2012) represents the only exception in this regard: by simply allowing the government’s discount (or borrowing) rate to be different from the private firm’s discount rate, he shows that if the difference between the two rates is sufficiently large, a tax reduction may be preferable to an investment subsidy. In this paper we study the efficacy of these two policy measures in a novel frame where we allow for the presence of government present-biased time preferences. Short-sightedness can, as well known, be easily justified in contexts where, for instance, the government preferences are characterized by imperfect intergenerational altruism (see e.g. Phelps and Pollak 1968) or biased by the consideration of political turnover (see e.g. Amador 2003; Aguiar and Amador 2011). By incorporating this assumption into a basic real-option model, we are able to show that the result favouring the adoption of an investment subsidy may be reversed in favour of a tax reduction. In the analysis, government was viewed as an infinite sequence of hyperbolic discounting agents, utility of which depends on future agents’ utility, and this assumption was incorporated into a standard real-option model à la Pennings (2000) where, differently from Sarkar (2012), the government discounts future pay-offs at a time-declining rate. Within this frame, the net benefit accruing to the government was examined and the conditions under which the result favouring the adoption of an investment subsidy may be reversed in favour of a tax reduction were determined. The reasoning behind this approach is straightforward.
