The rest of the paper is organized as follows: in the next section we will lay the foundations of the model, which is itself an extension of GH; in Sect. 3 we will apply our North–South convergence analysis; in Sect. 4 we will delve into the welfare issues; Sect. 5 will assess the relevance of our assumptions for an appropriate parameterization; finally, Sect. 6 concludes. Some lengthy mathematical derivations will be contained in the final Appendices.

Title: Colander, David and Freedman, Craig: Where economics went wrong: Chicago’s abandonment of classical liberalism
Blanqué, Pascal, The Economic and Financial Order
Bundling versus unbundling: asymmetric information on information externalities
Intro: In most countries, but especially in developing and emerging economies, immediate governmental responses to crises had the intention of providing a direct stimulus to economic activities, while less attention was paid to the choice of the optimal tools to pursue efficient public expenditure strategies (Brumby and Verhoeven 2010). As this situation is not expected to change for some time, governments are asked “to do better with less by spending smarter” (OECD 2014, p. 6). With the objective of dealing with some of these challenges, this paper addresses the optimal delegation from the public to the private sector of sequential tasks for the realization of strategic public investment that can enhance long-term growth rates, accumulate public capital, and generate long-term outputs (ECB 2016). One critical aspect of the delegation process in long-term projects is the allocation of connected activities among multiple agents. On one hand, the presence of positive externalities among tasks may motivate the adoption of ex-ante “bundled” contracts with a single private contractor to allow governments to exploit economies of scope and increase the efficiency of projects (Iossa and Martimort 2015; Martimort and Pouyet 2008). On the other hand, in the presence of future uncertainty and low competition for bundled contracts, governments may prefer “unbundled” schemes, where tasks are sequentially allocated to agents through independent awarding procedures (Li et al. 2015; Hoppe and Schmitz 2013; Bentz et al. 2002). Public authorities have traditionally selected unbundled contracts to procure investments. The idea of bundling tasks for the realization of a public project has become common thanks to developed and developing countries’ growing use of public–private partnerships (PPPs). PPPs have been implemented in a wide array of sectors, from standard projects for which the main source of revenue is user fees (e.g., motorways, parking facilities, and public transport), to highly complex projects in which private profits come from government subsidies (e.g., hospitals, schools, and prisons).Footnote 1 In PPPs, the private consortium that is in charge of designing, realizing, and managing the infrastructure can assume the role of financier, and the risks are optimally shared between public and private partners (OECD 2013). The focus in this paper is on a particular aspect of PPPs—that is, the bundling of tasks—while setting aside the analysis of such aspects of PPPs as the transfer of risks, control, and cashflow rights from the public to the private sector. In particular, the paper compares “bundling” with “unbundling” given the presence of an externality between sequential activities whose magnitude is ex-ante uncertain and unobserved by the government, while the private operator is able to infer this information during the first stage of the project. Moreover, as in Auriol and Picard (2009a, b, 2013) the study assumes that the principal has a budget constraint and, hence, faces a shadow cost of public funds. Using the contract theory methodology (Laffont and Tirole 1993), the theoretical analysis relaxes the usual assumption of perfectly observable externalities by using a more realistic environment in which a budget-constrained public authority that seeks to maximize the project’s net social welfare decides whether to select bundled or unbundled contracts without having all of the relevant information ex-ante. The results of the study reveal a trade-off: The advantage of the government’s choosing bundling is related to the first stage of investment, and it increases with the level of ex-ante uncertainty about the real impact of the building investment in its operational activity. On the other hand, if the government chooses unbundling, it can save informational rents, as the contract with the operator is written after the building stage once it has observed the real value of the externality. These results may explain the rationale behind the increased adoption of bundled contracts like the BOT (Build, Operate and Transfer), the BOOT (Build, Operate, Own and Transfer), and the FDBO (Finance, Design, Build, Operate and Transfer) in sectors like public transport, health, sanitation, and energy. In these sectors the link between building investment and operational costs can be significant but also highly uncertain at the ex-ante stage. In such frameworks, public administrations generally understand the need for investment in technologies that can control operational costs (e.g., intelligent transportation systems, medical technologies, energy-efficient instruments, waste water treatments), but these administrations usually cannot perfectly assess up front the long-term impacts and risks of such innovations (OECD 2014). The involvement of private contractors in the design, realization and future management of the project may allow public administrations to exploit their stronger market/sector knowledge and expertise for the provision of efficient investment levels in adequate innovative solutions (Iossa and Russo 2008). The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents a review of the related literature. Section 3 lays out the model, and Sects. 4 and 5 discuss the unbundling and bundling scenarios, respectively. Section 6 uses a welfare analysis to identify the net surplus the scenarios produce, and Sect. 7 concludes.

Title: Foreign penetration and domestic competition
Endogenous strategic variable in a mixed duopoly
Corporate social responsibility and privatization policy in a mixed oligopoly
Intro: The privatization trend has been increasing worldwide since the 1980s. Nevertheless, public and semi-public (partially privatized) firms are still important players in the global economic arena, but are highly concentrated in a few sectors with large portions of the world’s resources.Footnote 1 Particularly, public firms successfully compete with their private counterparts in a wide range of industries, such as healthcare, education, financing (e.g., banking and insurance), transportation (e.g., railways and airlines), telecommunications and energy-related industries (e.g., electricity, power generation and natural gas). Therefore, privatization in these industries attracted extensive policy attention from economics researchers in developed, developing, and transitional economies, such as Eastern Europe, Latin America, and Asia, including China.Footnote 2 The early analyses on mixed oligopolies date back to at least Merrill and Schneider (1966), although only more recently the literature in this field has become richer and more diverse. Specifically, the literature on mixed oligopolies adopted the partial privatization model formulated by Matsumura (1998), who discussed the optimal degree of privatization in mixed oligopolies. Since then, partial privatization models have been analyzed by a rapidly growing literature, and numerous recent works showed various factors affect the optimal degree of privatization.Footnote 3 Nonetheless, most papers assume private enterprises having homogeneous objectives maximize their profits.Footnote 4 On the other hand, driven by capital market and industry associations, corporate social responsibility (CSR) has become a global mainstream business strategy. According to KPMG (2013), nearly 85% of the 250 largest companies worldwide issued CSR reports and above 90% of companies in Japan adopted CSR activities. CASS (2017) releases that the yearly average proportion of CSR reports announced by the listed companies in China is 71.4%. While a large number of firms worldwide issue various CSR statements and activities, several belong to industries characterized as mixed oligopolies, in which CSR firms compete with public ones. That is, the heterogeneity of objectives among private firms emerges as an important research topic in the literature on mixed oligopolies. The recent CSR topic have also received increasing attention from broad research using both empirical and theoretical analyses in business and economics.Footnote 5 The concept and scopes of CSR are wide, ranging from investment in human capital to the social impact of firms’ traditional concerns, such as investments in R&D, product design, prices, and quantities, and the expansion of market shares. Many studies formulated theoretical papers on the CSR-initiatives and analyzed different models of oligopolies, where profit-maximizing private firms compete with other private firms that implement CSR activities.Footnote 6 Particularly, they utilized a model in which the private firm adopts consumer surplus as a proxy of its own CSR concerns. Subsequently, a CSR-related incentive combines both profitability and consumer surplus and, thus, the objective of a CSR firm is a convex combination of consumers’ surplus and its own profit. As CSR is a growing trend in many industries, including those characterized by mixed oligopolies, in which the investigation of privatization policies is significant, it is thus restrictive to assume private firms have homogeneous objectives, wherein they maximize only their own profits. Therefore, it is also important to examine the interactions between the CSR activities of private firms and optimal privatization policies on public firms. As such, we adopt the formal CSR approach and investigate how the heterogeneity of objectives among private firms affects optimal privatization policies in a mixed oligopoly, in which a public firm competes with CSR firms. The main contribution of our paper is providing different results by determining the optimal privatization policy in a mixed oligopoly with CSR firms. We show that, depending on the level of CSR and cost differences among firms, either nationalization or full privatization can be optimal. This result strikingly contrasts to the literature on mixed oligopolies. Since Matsumura (1998) first analyzed partial privatization under moderate conditions in a homogeneous mixed duopoly, several other studies examined optimal privatization policies under different aspects of economic phenomena and proved the optimality of partial privatization is robust.Footnote 7 For identical cost functions, furthermore, we find the optimal degree of privatization is decreasing with the level of CSR in private firms and, thus, nationalization can be optimal if they have homogeneous objectives. However, if there is significant objective heterogeneity among private firms, the optimal degree of privatization is non-monotone with respect to the CSR level but nationalization cannot be optimal. This result suggests the optimal privatization policy depends on the CSR level, which affects the heterogeneity of objectives among private firms. This highlights the role of CSR activities in the magnitude of heterogeneity of objectives for choosing an optimal degree of privatization and its effects on the non-monotonicity of privatization policies in a mixed oligopoly. Recently, Ouattara (2017) and Itano (2017) examined optimal privatization policies with the CSR activities of a private firm, but focused only on a mixed duopoly where both public and private firms have identical cost functions. Chang et al. (2018) also analyzed CSR activities of a public social enterprise in a mixed duopoly by taking the degree of caring about the profit of a private firm into consideration. However, the heterogeneity of objectives among private firms is absent in their models and thus, the results are more restrictive than ours. As related works, Goering (2008), Flores and García (2016), and Leal et al. (2018) showed that technology efficiency is crucial in determining whether welfare increases or decreases as the social concern of a non-profit firm raises. Yet, they did not consider the optimal degree of privatization. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2, we briefly review the CSR in the economics literature. We construct the basic model of mixed oligopolies with CSR firms and analyze the optimal policies in Sect. 3. In Sect. 4, we focus on the identical cost functions and discuss two specific cases: (i) both private firms have the homogenous CSR and (ii) one firm is a profit-maximizer, while the other firm adopts CSR. The final Sect. 5 concludes the paper.

Title: Basu, Kaushik: The republic of beliefs: a new approach to law and economics
Grigoriadis, Theocharis: Religion and Comparative Development: The Genesis of Democracy and Dictatorship
Optimal public policy à la Ramsey in an endogenous growth model
Intro: The choice of an objective function with which to characterize the social optimum has always been the subject of controversy. Ramsey (1928) assumed a social planner who maximizes an infinite, non-discounted sum of current and future utilities. The discounting of later enjoyments in comparison with earlier ones was for him an unacceptable practice. Later, Cass (1965, 1966), Koopmans (1965, 1967), Malinvaud (1965) and Samuelson (1965) generalized Ramsey’s approach to allow for the discounting of future utilities. In an explicit overlapping generations setting where individuals are pure life-cyclers, Diamond (1965) adhered to the maximization of the utility level of a representative individual under the constraint that any other achieves the same welfare level, giving rise to what the subsequent literature coined as the Two-Part Golden Rule, i.e., the combination of the Biological Interest Rate and the Golden Rule of (physical) capital accumulation (Samuelson 1968, 1975a, b). Adding to this framework the dimension of intergenerational altruism à la Barro (1974), so that individuals behave as if they maximized dynastic utility, the question arises of whether considering the welfare level enjoyed by a representative child only (Carmichael 1982) or that of all children (Burbidge 1983). Clearly, each of these views of social welfare leads to a different optimal resource allocation. But all of them share the feature that they assume economies without productivity growth, in which a steady state is a situation where consumption levels per unit of (natural) labour are kept constant. In contrast, in the presence of productivity growth that translates into consumption growth, these consumption levels will grow without limit. Under these circumstances, a social planner will be unable to choose the stream of consumption levels that maximizes a sum of utilities. The reason is simple: the utility index itself will grow without limit, and will be infinite along the balanced growth path. The standard way to sidestep this issue is, of course, to assume that the planner maximizes a discounted sum of utilities. This is the approach adopted by Caballé (1995), Kemnitz and Wigger (2000) and Docquier et al. (2007) to characterize the optimal growth path in an endogenous growth model with overlapping generations and individuals who are either dynastic savers or life-cyclers. There are, however, two uncomfortable features of this approach. First, as mentioned before, altough positing a social discount rate has become customary, the choice of a particular one can be seen as inherently arbitrary. Second, as highlighted in Del Rey and Lopez-Garcia (2012), the precise cardinalization of the utility function (more precisely, its degree of homogeneity) fundamentally affects both the characterization of the social optimum and the policies that support it. Indeed, the optimal balanced growth path will be characterized by a version of the “Modified Golden Rule” where the rate of growth of productivity has to be adjusted for the degree of homogeneity of the utility function (see footnote 7 below). This means that even if we accept that future utilities should be discounted at an entirely arbitrary rate, we are left with the fact that the optimal policy varies when we use different mathematical specifications representing the same  economic problem. One could reasonably claim that this is also an unpleasant feature of the whole approach.Footnote 1 In light of these facts, it is tempting to ask whether it is possible for a social planner to continue to adhere to the Utilitarian criterion of maximizing a sum of individual utilities but, (i) without having to postulate something as elusive and inherently arbitrary as a social discount rate; and (ii) without having to choose a specific functional form to cardinalize individual preferences. In this paper we argue that the answer to this question is affirmative, accounting for both (i) and (ii), when the social planner maximizes a non-discounted sum of individual current and future utilities defined over consumption levels per unit of  efficient rather than natural labour units. Strictly speaking, and to be precise, the social planner would not maximize the plain sum of welfare levels but that of the divergences between these levels and a “bliss utility” à la Ramsey. We show therefore that it is possible for a Utilitarian social planner to treat all generations equally and be respectful of individual preferences. On the one hand, in a growth environment, treating all generations alike involves the choice of some utility index that eventually converges. In order to ensure convergence of the utility index we can divide consumption levels by another variable that grows at the same rate along a balanced growth path. The level of physical capital and the level of human capital are two natural candidates to be this divisor. However, as consumption and physical capital are denominated in the same units, dividing consumption levels by physical capital would yield a pure number, with no dimension and with no intuitive interpretation. Dividing by human capital, on the contrary, just “re-scales” consumption, measuring it in terms of units of output per unit of efficient labour. On the other hand, it is important to stress that this “new” utility function is obtained by means of a monotonic transformation of the one guiding individual’s behaviour, thus being fully respectul of individual ordinal preferences. Notice also that, assuming convergence, the limit of the time sequence of consumption levels expressed in terms of output per unit of efficient labour will be measured in such a dimension, as will be any variable which is constant along a balanced growth path. A less “technical” rationale can be provided for the maximization, on the part of the social planner, of a non-discounted sum of individual utilities with consumption levels expressed in terms of output per unit of efficient labour. Individuals live for a limited time span, but the social planner is assumed to be infinitely-lived. As the latter has to weigh the lifetime utility levels of individuals born at different periods, she can consider the following reasoning. An individual born at time t is endowed with a given amount of human capital, productivity, or efficiency units. On the one hand, her grandparents, who were born at, say, \(t-2\), had of course a lower level of human capital. They used to play with wooden trucks and rag dolls. On the other, her grandchildren, to be born at \(t+2\), will be endowed with a higher level of human capital, and will be able to enjoy fabulous computers and on-line games. When comparing the utilities achieved by these three generations, will the social planner only compare their respective consumption levels per unit of natural labour? Or will she instead take into account their level of “productivity” (i.e., human capital)? Although the de gustibus non disputandum clause of course applies, if the social planner wants to provide an equal treatment to all the generations involved, she may well consider that, if confronted with a wooden truck or a rag doll, a grandchild can be taken to be worse off relative to her grandparent. Just because the grandchild is endowed with a higher level of human capital, the social planner may claim that, in order to be on an equal footing with a previous generation, their respective consumptions per unit of efficient labour have to be the same. And this obviously requires a higher consumption per unit of  natural labour (i.e., the resources required to build a computer being much greater than those of a wooden truck/rag doll). If discounting is deliberately set aside and the social planner adheres to Utilitarian postulates, this reasoning immediately leads to the social objective of maximizing a function involving an infinite non-discounted sum of utilities derived from individual consumption per unit of human capital. This approach to the characterization of the entire optimal growth path implies a generalization of Del Rey and Lopez-Garcia (2013). Their analysis ignores initial conditions and focuses on the long-run  balanced growth path that maximizes the lifetime welfare (derived from consumption per unit of efficient labour) of a representative individual subject to the constraint that everyone else’s welfare is fixed at the same level. They show that along this optimal “Golden Rule” balanced growth path, a tax on education investments and positive pensions to the elderly are called for. As the analytics below will show, this “Golden Rule” balanced growth path is the one towards which an economy converges when commanded by a social planner who, given some initial conditions, maximizes a function involving a non-discounted sum of individual utilities defined over consumption per unit of efficient labour. It is well known, however, that the results characterizing the public policy that supports the optimal balanced growth path are not very instructive when, as in the present case, the focus turns from balanced growth paths to the entire time trajectory leading to them. In other words, results that pertain to long-run equilibria will in general be a poor way to approach optimal policy out of such states. An example is the well known Chamley (1986) and Judd (1985) result of an asymptotical zero capital income tax in the presence of infinitely-lived individuals, which however provides no indication concerning the time sequence of optimal capital income taxes. In this paper, we explicitly adopt a strict Ramsey approach, i.e., entailing non-discounting, in an endogenous growth model. Our purpose is to characterize those optimal policies that, once superimposed on private behaviour and interaction in the market-place, allow the social planner to decentralize the entire optimal growth path. We identify the optimal subsidies to the education acquired by younger individuals, and the lump-sum taxes to be levied on the working population and the retirees along the entire growth path, and enquire about their sign. We find that, in the current setting, education expenditures should not only be taxed along the optimal balanced-growth path but also along the entire optimal growth path (Proposition 1). Concerning pensions, it is shown that they will also be positive along the whole transition path leading to the optimal balanced growth path (Proposition 3). The sign of the lump-sum tax on the working middle-aged is, however, ambiguous. And, importantly, these results hold regardless of the initial conditions for physical and human capital in the situation taken as a starting point. We thus generalize our previous results to the whole growth path. A tax on education investments is certainly an odd result from the point of view of the received literature (Boldrin and Montes 2005; Docquier et al. 2007). In our setting, it results from the assumption of the existence of perfect credit markets where younger individuals can acquire any amount of desired education, and from the particular interaction between human and physical capital that takes place when we adopt the aforementioned normative criterion. A clear-cut sign of the pensions received by retirees is also in sharp contrast with the message emerging from overlapping-generations models with exogenous growth à la Diamond (1965). Indeed, in this latter case, whether optimal intergenerational transfers are to or from retirees is in general indeterminate, and depends on whether the laissez-faire capital-labour ratio is greater or less than its Golden-Rule counterpart (Samuelson 1975b). This paper shows that the optimality of education taxes and positive pensions is not an oddity related to the existence of a balanced growth path. On the contrary, these results apply to the whole optimal growth trajectory. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents the model and analyzes the market equilibrium in the presence of government. Section 3 discusses the optimal growth path chosen by a social planner who maximizes an objective function involving a non-discounted sum of individual utilities defined over consumption per unit of efficient labour. Section 4 characterizes the optimal tax policies that allow to decentralize the optimal growth path. Section 5 concludes.

Title: Heterogeneity and monetary policy
Intro:
While the representative-agent framework has been the workhorse in macroeconomics over the last several decades, economists have long been interested in heterogeneity (e.g., Huggett 1993; Rios-Rull 1995). It has recently become an important modelling approach in macroeconomics (e.g., Krusell and Smith 2006; Molico 2006; Heathcote et al. 2009; Carroll 2013; Ahn et al. 2018) as it was recognized that many important questions cannot be addressed without heterogeneity. In this paper, we build a simple model with heterogeneous population in which monetary policy is shown to have different effects on different groups of population. The only difference between agents in the economy is their productivity. We demonstrate that a central bank that cares about heterogeneous groups of agents according to their fractions in population, would choose a level of inflation that is higher than when population is homogeneous. The resulting allocation is shown to be below the Pareto frontier. This outcome arises because such a central bank would be to a certain extent preoccupied with the redistribution effect of its policy. This classic trade-off between efficiency and equity arises in the model only due to heterogeneity – it disappears once heterogeneity is removed. We next study the problem of optimal delegation of monetary policy pioneered by Rogoff (1985). A benevolent social planner chooses the weights on the utilities of the two types of agents that guides the behavior of the central bank. And the central bank than chooses optimal monetary policy. We consider two alternative social planners. The first has access to lump-sum redistribution applied to an equilibrium allocation and seeks to maximize social welfare. We show that the optimal delegation leads to an inflation rate lower than the one without delegation but higher than the efficiency level. The second social planner uses a criterion of Pareto unimprovability. Namely, a monetary policy is called Pareto improvable when its allocation is Pareto dominated by the allocation of another policy when some lump-sum redistribution to the latter can be applied. This social planner’s goal is to achieve the allocation of a Pareto unimprovable policy. We demonstrate that the optimal delegation in this case leads to a Pareto efficient allocation. In his seminal work, Rogoff (1985) argues that appointing a central banker who dislikes inflation more than society does allows to overcome the problem of inflation bias and improves social welfare. Our model features a similar outcome of optimal delegation: it is socially beneficial to appoint a central bank that is more inflation averse than society on average. The higher level of inflation aversion of such a central bank stems from a higher weight it puts on utility of the high-productivity workers. While in Rogoff’s paper the trade-off faced by the central bank stems from the assumption that the economy exhibits some sort of distortion (in, say, the labor market), the source of the trade-off in this paper is heterogeneity in productivity among workers. 
Friedman (1969) proposed a rule that minimizes the cost of holding currency by setting the nominal interest rate to zero. As the Friedman rule is at odds with the practice of central banks many of whom have adopted inflation targets somewhere between 2 and 3.5%, a literature has emerged to account for this discrepancy. Schmitt-Grohé and Uribe (2010) succeed in this regard by adding such frictions as incomplete tax systems, downward rigidity of prices, and the zero lower bound on nominal interest rates; these features induce the optimal policy to deviate from the Friedman rule. However, they report that it is hard to theoretically justify deviations of inflation from near-zero optimal inflation rates. Our work adds a modest contribution to this research. The paper finds that optimal delegation of monetary policy results in a departure from the Friedman rule. And perhaps more importantly, we also find a tendency of monetary authorities to deliver an inflation rate higher than in the case of homogeneous population. This effect is present in both the case with and without delegation of monetary policy. Thus we believe that heterogeneity may be an important modelling device in accounting for the difference between observed inflation rates and the near-zero optimal levels reported in Schmitt-Grohé and Uribe (2010), who use a homogeneous environment.Footnote 1 Justifying positive inflation rates on theoretical grounds has proven to be a challenge. For example, Coibion et al. (2012) confirm the findings of Schmitt-Grohé and Uribe (2010); in their work the optimal inflation rate is typically less than 2%. Similarly, for a standard U.S. calibration, Carlsson and Westermark (2016) find a Ramsey optimal inflation rate to be 1.16%. Di Bartolomeo et al. (2015) push this analysis further and in an environment with an incomplete tax system and realistic size and composition of public expenditure demonstrate that the optimal inflation rate varies between 2 and 12% depending on the transfers-to-GDP ratio. This work is one of only few in the literature that demonstrate how public finance can justify positive inflation targets. Chen et al. (2011) build an optimal growth model with resources spent on imagining future pleasures and show that in their environment the Friedman rule does not hold; they find that the optimal inflation rate is 2.09% and the welfare gain of switching from the zero-inflation regime to the optimal inflation is almost 7% per year. And finally, Schmitt-Grohé and Uribe (2012) study inflation in a model with a foreign demand for domestic currency. Various calibrations of the model yield Ramsey optimal rates of inflation between 2 and 10%. Our work is not the first to find a higher inflation rate in heterogeneous environments. In Menna and Tirelli (2017), the social planner chooses a higher steady-state inflation rate than that obtained under the representative agent assumption. If theirs is an outcome of a simulation of a calibrated model, our paper exhibits this effect as a general theoretical result. The remaining of the paper is organized as follows. Sections 2 and 3 present the model. Section 4 characterizes the Pareto frontier. Section 5 presents the main theoretical results. Section 6 summarizes and concludes. Proofs are in the “Appendix”.

Title: Indirect taxes in a cross-border shopping model: a monopolistic competition approach
Optimal saving and health prevention
Intro: When there is a likelihood that a disease occurs in the future, an individual Decision Maker (henceforth DM) can choose to implement preventive treatments which cause pain or side effects on health in the short run, but are important ways of reducing the probability of developing the disease in the long run. For example, after testing positive for a gene mutation associated with a high risk of breast cancer, the actress Angelina Jolie decided to take a radical surgery: prophylactic double mastectomy. Some non-surgical procedures, like coronary angioplasty, although painful in the short run, reduce the probability of future heart attacks in patients with chronic cardiovascular diseases. Less drastic measures, such as the flu vaccination, produce the unintended effect of fever right after the injection, but significantly lowers the probability of contracting a flu virus in the future. This kind of preventive treatment is widely used and corresponds to behavior usually called “primary prevention” in medical and health care literature. The activities involved reduce current health level in exchange for a lower probability of falling into a future less healthy state and suffering from an illness. In such cases, the burden of primary prevention is mainly on a DM’s health. Despite this, to our knowledge, the literature on prevention always models the cost of preventive treatment only as a decline in DM’s wealth, and ignores the potential burden on DM’s health. The first aim of this work is thus to extend the analysis by studying a model where a DM’s utility is bivariate in terms of both wealth and health, and the activity of prevention in health (henceforth health prevention) generates both a cost in the wealth dimension and a cost in the health dimension. As first noted by Menegatti (2009) in a financial framework, prevention often takes place in a multiperiod context where a DM makes a preventive action in the present in order to reduce the probability of a negative event in the future. The same reasoning holds for the kind of health prevention discussed here. In a multiperiod model of health prevention, it seems natural to consider the role of saving as another important intertemporal choice for the DM to maximize her welfare over time. A joint study of health prevention and saving, however, has as yet never been conducted. One main reason for this fact is that, as emphasized by the literature on choice bracketing (e.g. Read et al. 1999), a DM tends to bracket choices of the same type together. The consequence of this is that the analysis in decision theory often distinguishes choices involving financial variables from choices involving health variables. Nonetheless, there are many questions on whether and how the bracketing process occurs. One strand of literature thus started analyzing risk management in multiple dimensions. For example, Liu and Menegatti (2017) recently investigate the substitutability or complementarity between optimal choices of health investment and financial investment when these two decisions are made simultaneously. Their analysis suggests that a similar approach can be applied to the current study of joint decisions on health prevention and saving. Moreover, a recent work by Peter (2017) shows that, in a univariate framework where utility only depends on wealth, the conclusions on optimal choice of financial prevention may change significantly in the presence of saving. It would thus be interesting to identify the conditions under which his findings carry over to a more general framework where utility is bivariate in terms of both wealth and health. Following the research line described above, this work examines the interaction between contemporaneous decisions of health prevention and saving. These two instruments of risk management are chosen in a two-period framework under a bivariate utility of wealth and health. We then introduce a mean-zero background risk in wealth (e.g. Eeckhoudt et al. 1996, 2012; Gollier and Pratt 1996) in the second period and analyze its effects: whether there is a motive of precautionary payment for each of the two choices, as shown by most of the literature on the single-choice problems of saving or prevention. To some extent, this risk can be used to reflect an exogenous risk regarding a DM’s future earnings. For instance, there could be a possible cut in social insurance programs on health care, a strategy often adopted by governments in an ageing economy.Footnote 1 We show that optimal choices of saving and health prevention can be either substitutes or complements, and that a key element distinguishing between these two cases is whether a DM is correlation averse or correlation prone. A further analysis shows that, when the interest rate changes, the reactions of optimal saving and health prevention depend on: (1) the relative importance of the substitution effect over income effect on saving; (2) the sign of correlation attitude (aversion or loving); (3) the alternative fact that the DM has positive saving or is borrowing. Lastly, several combinations of preferences concerning correlation aversion/loving, prudence/imprudence in wealth and cross-prudence/imprudence in health are also provided, in order to determine unambiguous effects of a background risk in wealth on the two optimal choices. This work is related to a wide literature on prevention, either in isolation or jointly with other decisions. Menegatti and Rebessi (2011), Steinorth (2011), Hofmann and Peter (2016) and Peter (2017) examine the interaction between simultaneous decisions about saving and financial prevention in a context where utility is univariate and only depends on wealth. The choice of health prevention alone is studied by Lee (2005) and Courbage and Rey (2006), while the interaction between health prevention and cure is analysed by Hennessy (2008), Menegatti (2014) and Brianti et al. (2018). None of these papers considers the case that the cost of prevention occurs in the health dimension, or introduces saving. In a broader sense, health-related decision problems also include models of health investment with a health cost by Eeckhoudt et al. (2007),Footnote 2 health investment with a financial cost by Denuit et al. (2011), and preventive treatment in the form of self-insurance in health by Courbage and Rey (2016),Footnote 3 all of which are one-choice models. Wang et al. (2015) study a general form of precautionary payment for stochastic improvements on future risk in a context where utility depends both on wealth and health. They also focus on a single instrument of risk management, either saving or prevention with a financial cost. As mentioned above, two instruments of risk management together in a context of bivariate utility are recently analyzed by Liu and Menegatti (2017). Two important features, however, distinguish that article from the present work. First, Liu and Menegatti (2017) study saving together with health investment, which is defined as a reduction in present health generating an increase in future health. Health investment thus does not affect the probability distribution of future health status and, consequently, is different from health prevention.Footnote 4 Moreover, unlike the present work, Liu and Menegatti (2017) do not analyze the effects of the presence of a background risk. As it studies the effect of a background wealth risk, our analysis is also related to Eeckhoudt et al. (2012), who examine the same issue in a model of prevention with a financial cost and do not take into account the intertemporal role of saving. Baiardi et al. (2014) study instead the effects on saving of different kinds of risk (including a background risk in health). Their work, however, introduces a single instrument of risk management and does not consider the role of prevention. Lastly, some linkages can be found between the analysis in the present paper and that of changes in risk in recent studies on one-period models of effort (Chuang et al. 2013; Crainich et al. 2016; Wong 2017). The paper proceeds as follows. Section 2 presents the model and analyzes optimal levels of health prevention and saving. Section 3 analyzes the effect a change in the level of the interest rate. Section 4 studies the impact of the introduction of a background wealth risk. Section 5 concludes.

Title: Torben Iversen and David Soskice: Democracy and prosperity: reinventing capitalism through a turbulent century
Komlos, John: Foundations of real world economics: what every economics student needs to know
Inter-group competition through joint marketing efforts and intra-group Cournot competition
On the social (sub)optimality of divisionalization under product differentiation
Intro:
The early literature on multidivisional firms investigates monopoly models where the subject matter is the use of divisionalization as a strategic entry barrier (Schwartz and Thompson 1986; Veendorp 1991). A subsequent stream of literature translates the idea into oligopoly games to show that divisionalization may be an instrument to acquire a dominant position, or, replicate Stackelberg leadershipFootnote 1 (Corchón 1991) but, since all firms share this incentive, the outcome is definitely procompetitive and may even drive the industry towards perfect competition if divisionalization is costless (Polasky 1992).Footnote 2
Baye et al. (1996a, b) add up a fixed cost per-division to show that the resulting equilibrium, with the same finite number of divisions per-firm, can be socially efficient if the industry is a duopoly.Footnote 3 This literature relies on product homogeneity and linear variable costs. To the best of our knowledge, the only exception contemplating product differentiation in the representative consumer approach used in the bulk of the aforementioned literature is Ziss (1998), where each firm’s product is an imperfect substitute of the rivals’ products, in such a way that intra-firm (resp., inter-firm) competition takes place in differentiated (resp., homogeneous) products. Leaving aside the issue of social efficiency, Ziss (1998) treats the number of divisions as a continuous variable and illustrates the effect of product differentiation on the number of divisions at equilibrium. Ziss (1998) assumes products to be differentiated across firms but not across divisions and demonstrates the existence of a pure-strategy equilibrium with symmetric multidivisional firms, even in the limit case in which divisionalization is costless, for any degree of product differentiation. This finding has a twofold implication: (i) the result outlined in Polasky (1992) emerges only when the product is homogeneous also across firms and not only across the divisions belonging to the same firm; and (ii) the perfectly competitive outcome remains out of reach even when divisionalization costs are nil, provided products are not perfect substitutes. Moreover, Ziss (1998) also shows that the peak of the optimal per-firm number of divisions is sensitive to both industry structure and product differentiation. This approach, as well as the bulk of the aforementioned literature, focusses itself on the existence and characterization of optimal divisionalization, under the (somewhat implicit) assumption that firm will divisionalise themselves. By doing so, it overlooks the possibility for a firm facing a rival which goes multidivisional to respond by not divisionalising itself. This is the route we take here, to produce the following results. Accounting for the integer problem, the decision on divisionalization gives rise to a discrete-strategy game in which firms maintain the option not to do it, and indeed don’t divisionalise themselves if the cost of divisionalization is too high and product substitutability is low enough. It is worth stressing that an analogous result has emerged in the aforementioned debate. In particular, González-Maestre (2000, Props. 1(i) and 3(i), pp. 327–328) shows that single-division firms will appear at equilibrium in a homogeneous good duopoly where divisionalization and strategic delegation à la Vickers (1985) coexist. This is due to the fact that if the number of firms is small, then every firm obtains a relatively high fraction of industry profits; consequently, the possibility of becoming multidivisional is not appealing, as the incentive to increase market share is more than offset by the damage created by the increase in the intensity of market competition. Moreover, González-Maestre (2001, Prop. 1(ii), p. 1303) uses a spatial model à la Salop (1979) to find, amongst other things, that if the number of firms is sufficiently small as compared to the elasticity of the transportation cost function borne by consumers, then firms will remain single-division entities. Additionally, Corchón, (1991, Example 1, p. 2) using a hyperbolic demand function for a homogeneous good, proves that the number of divisions is undetermined in duopoly (which admits the case of single-division firms). There exists an intermediate range of values of fixed costs and product substitutability in which multiple equilibria arise, including, with a positive probability, asymmetric equilibria. The alignment of private and social preferences towards industry-wide divisionalization occurs only for sufficiently low levels of fixed costs and product differentiation. To keep the model manageable, we confine our attention to the duopoly case, although we also extend the analysis to the scenario in which, should firms speculate about becoming multidivisional, they could examine the possibility of activating a finite generic number of divisions. The interesting feature emerging from this slight generalisation consists in the fact that the choice between a single division or more than two does not give rise to a prisoners’ dilemma. The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. The model is laid out in Sect. 2. The solution of the game is outlined in Sect. 3. Section 4 deals with the welfare analysis. the extension to a generic number of divisions is assessed in Sect. 5. Section 6 contains some concluding remarks.

Title: Cooperative R&D with durable goods
Financial conditions and supply decisions when firms are risk averse
Vague, Richard: A brief history of doom
Intro:
For Vague, the fundamental driver of all major financial crises is the dynamics of private debt. An excessive expansion of lending and debts inevitably leads to excessive production and the consequent crisis when the prices of the overproduced gods start falling and so affecting the borrowers’ ability to service their debts. More specifically, Vague points out that in most crises, the dynamics of loans channelled to the real estate sector has been of great significance. Vague’s views about the general fundamental features of financial crises, as explicitly acknowledged by him, have a Minskyan flavor (see, e.g. Minsky 1986[2008]). Market economies are characterized by instability, with booms inevitably followed by crashes in which the behavior of the financial sector is crucial. Booms are boosted by a significant expansion of lending and the recessive phases are longer and deeper because of the agents’ attempt to ameliorate their financial positions by deleveraging.
 Vague holds that most mainstream economists have failed to see the decisive role that the dynamics of private debts, and their excessive expansion during booms, plays in the explanation of crises. He offers a number of reasons for the economists’ ‘blindness’. He argues that, in more recent times, this might have happened because, for a long span of time (1950–1980) private debt was very low and because of the very large influence of central banks, which tend to concentrate on the government finance and reserve accounts.Footnote 3 At a more general level, this might have happened because most economists tend to overlook, or ignore altogether, that private debt creates new money and thus affects demand. The possible reasons of the economists’ ‘blindness’ put forward by Vague are certainly acceptable but, it is argued here, there is an underlying more general explanation which, comprehensibly, is not taken into consideration in the book, given its nature and intents. This more general explanation has to do with the way in which economic theory in general, and macroeconomic theory in particular, evolved in the course of the twentieth century. During large part of the twentieth century, macroeconomics, which is the branch of economics naturally tasked with explaining fluctuations and crises, has almost ignored the role of banks and finance and their interactions with the real economy (see, e.g. Gertler 1988; Goodhart 2005–2006; Ingrao and Sardoni 2019). As a consequence, concerns about the debt structure of the private sector vanished as well, either by aggregating the positions of heterogeneous agents, or by assuming that the macroeconomic behavior of the economy could be effectively represented by models with a single representative agent. The essential reason why macroeconomics evolved in such a way is that, at the least since the 1950s, macroeconomics has been characterized by the attempt to set the analysis within the theoretical framework of a neo-Walrasian general equilibrium model (Ingrao and Sardoni 2019). Although it is undoubtedly correct to set macroeconomic analysis in a theoretical framework in which all the relevant interrelations among sectors and agents are taken into account, to identify such a framework with the neo-Walrasian (Arrow–Debreu) general equilibrium model clashes with the fact that in such a model money and, a fortiori, banks and finance cannot play any significant role. Something that has been clearly acknowledged by general-equilibrium theoreticians (see, e.g. Hahn 1965). Therefore, it is not surprising that the dynamics of the financial sector does not play an important role in mainstream explanations of crises. To be sure, things have changed in recent years. Especially after the 2008 crisis, mainstream macroeconomists have produced an impressive amount of models which contain a financial sector which interacts with the rest of the economy and tends to amplify and prolong the effects of the shocks that hit the economy. These contributions certainly are important and praiseworthy, but they still seem to be unable to provide a fully satisfactory account of the economic dynamics leading to crises. An important exponent of the current mainstream macroeconomics has recently stated: ‘none of the extensions of the New Keynesian model proposed in recent years seem to capture an important aspect of most financial crises—namely, a gradual build-up of financial imbalances leading to an eventual “crash” characterized by defaults, sudden-stops of credit flows, asset price declines, and a large contraction in aggregate demand, output, and employment. Most of the extensions found in the literature share with their predecessors a focus on equilibria that take the form of stationary fluctuations driven by exogenous shocks’ (Galí 2018, p. 107). The building-up of imbalances is exactly the factor that, in Vague’s view, explains the eventual eruption of financial crises. Vague argues that the building-up of financial imbalances—namely excessive lending and the accumulation of debts—is largely due to the competitive environment in which financial institutions operate.Footnote 4 The excessive expansion of lending by banks and other financial institutions is essentially due to their necessity to behave in such a way to not be expelled from markets which, at that time, appear as extremely profitable and not facing any serious risk of contraction. Mainstream macroeconomics, with its focus on equilibria and disturbances to them in the form of external shocks, is largely unable to look at the dynamics of such competitive processes, which are a fundamental feature of the world in which we live. This requires looking at competition as something deeply different from the abstract and static notion of competition underlying the neo-Walrasian equilibrium, even though some imperfections and frictions are superimposed on it to make models better reflect and rationalize some aspects of the actual economy.Footnote 5

Title: Optimal taxation in a common resource oligopoly game
Intro: In this paper, we consider a dynamic oligopoly model in which the competing firms share the access to a natural renewable resource, used as an input for the production of a homogeneous good, as in the seminal paper of Benchekroun (2003). In the real world, such productive resources are often owned by public authorities: as a primary example for this, Agrawal et al. (2008) point out that Central governments own about 86% of the world’s forests and wooded areas. Nevertheless, many government-owned forests are managed as common property for multiple uses by local communities and community-based organizations, whereas many other forests classified under public ownership are effectively governed by logging companies.Footnote 1 In all these cases, a public authority regulates the access to the resource and its exploitation in various ways, by implementing public policies, which can also involve the output market. Of particular economic interest are tax/subsidy policies: since Hotelling (1931), it is well known that taxation can constitute a good policy in the commons. As a relevant real world example, consider forest taxation: a commonly observed class of forest taxes, especially in Scandinavia and central Europe, consists of harvest taxes, which are sometimes levied on the timber volume harvested.Footnote 2 Can a similar tax policy be designed in order to implement the first-best exploitation levels over time, if more firms share the access to the same resource and sell their products in the same market? To address this issue, we adopt a differential game approach and we focus on the piecewise linear Feedback Nash Equilibrium (FNE) of the oligopoly model. As for the dynamic evolution of the resource stock, which constitutes the state variable of the game, we adopt the specification proposed by Benchekroun (2003), which, at the same time, maintains the main properties of the logistic equation, while allowing for closed-form solutions. In this setting, we show that, by means of a simple linear Markov tax, more specifically a tax rate levied on the output, and specified as an affine function of the resource stock available at each time instant, the public authority can achieve the first-best outcome, i.e. the competing firms choose the production levels that maximize a social welfare functional, defined -as usual- as the discounted sum of consumer surplus and firms’ profits. It is worth noting that, in our framework, more specifically under the assumption that the produced output is proportional to the amount of exploited resource, the considered tax can be equivalently levied on the resource that is harvested at each time instant. Our contribution is related mainly to two streams of the literature. First of all, it builds on the differential oligopoly game studied by Benchekroun (2008), which generalizes the already mentioned duopoly model by Benchekroun (2003). Other investigations on the duopoly model are carried out by Fujiwara (2008), Colombo and Labrecciosa (2015), Lambertini and Mantovani (2016).Footnote 3 Several investigations and extensions of the oligopoly model can be found in Fujiwara (2011), Benchekroun et al. (2014), Lambertini and Mantovani (2014), Benchekroun and Gaudet (2015).Footnote 4 The mentioned papers contribute to the literature dealing with the exploitation of natural resources in a differential game framework [see, e.g., the survey paper by Van Long (2011)]. The other related strand of the literature is concerned with first-best tax/subsidy policies in a differential game framework. Benchekroun and Van Long (1998) address the problem of the emission of pollutants in an oligopoly game and show how to determine a linear Markov tax which leads the oligopolists to adopt the welfare-maximizing production plan.Footnote 5 Relatedly, Menezes and Pereira (2017) consider a duopoly model with differentiated products in which firms can undertake R&D activities in order to reduce the environmentally damaging emissions generated by the production activity, and determine the optimal mix of emissions tax and R&D subsidy. Thus, optimal regulation in a differential game framework has been studied in models with dynamic interactions between two sources of externalities: on the one hand, the pollutant emissions, on the other hand, the firms’ market power.Footnote 6 Other contributions [see Clemhout and Wan (1985), Akao (2008)] deal with the optimal taxation in the commons, assuming that agents maximize the utility of consumption: hence, the only externalities are due to the tragedy of the commons, and the tax policy is aimed to achieve the cooperative solution. Therefore, to the best of our knowledge, the design of a first-best tax/subsidy policy in a dynamic game in which firms’ market power interplays with the externalities arising from sharing the access to a renewable productive resource has not been considered so far.Footnote 7 This paper aims to fill this gap within the literature. Our main results can be summarized as follows. Firstly, we show that, depending on the initial resource stock availability, the socially optimal extraction plan consists either in the endless repetition of the perfect competition output or, when the initial resource endowment is below a certain threshold, in output levels increasing over time and converging to the perfect competition one. By comparing this solution with the FNE of the (unregulated) oligopoly game considered in Benchekroun (2008), we find that the competing firms adopt a less conservationist approach for low values of the resource stock, due to the tragedy of the commons, while the opposite holds true for higher resource stock levels. As far as the first-best tax policy is concerned, we show that in a monopoly it takes the simple form of a state-independent tax, i.e. a constant per-unit tax, which actually turns out to be a subsidy. A similar, very simple, tax rule achieves the first-best solution in oligopoly only in steady-state, whereas an affine Markov tax can be designed to make the entire equilibrium path of the game coincident with the welfare-maximizing solution -in the most interesting subgames in which the initial state is low enough such that the tragedy of the commons is relevant-, in any industry comprising at least three firms. Interestingly, in a certain range of the resource stock, despite the output levels in the unregulated oligopoly are higher than it would be socially optimal, the production is subsidized, and this leads the firms to reduce the exploitation (up to the socially optimal level), in view of more conspicuous future subsidies: in brief, the positive dynamic externality associated with lowering the output, created by the considered policy, is able -together with the firms’ market power- to counterbalance the negative externality related to the common access to the resource, entailing lower output when the resource stock is relatively scarce. At the same time, for higher values of the resource stock, the mentioned subsidy leads the oligopolists to expand production above the Cournot static level, up to the socially desirable quantities. Thus, our results suggest that harvest taxes levied on the harvested amount of resource can be an effective policy in regulating the commons, provided that the tax rate is properly linked to the available resource stock. However, as mentioned above, these results do not hold in a duopoly: in the present setting, the first-best solution is not achievable in that case. Such a surprising result probably deserves further investigations. The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2, we set-up the model; in Sect. 3, we characterize the first-best solution and compare it with the (unregulated) oligopoly model; in Sect. 4, we determine and discuss the optimal linear Markov tax; Sect. 5 concludes.

Title: Deferred taxation under default risk
Precautionary retirement and precautionary saving
Intro: Increasing life expectancies and decreasing fertility rates are threatening the financial sustainability of the pension system in most developed countries (OECD 2015). Encouraging continued work is often thought to be the main way of alleviating the current financial distress of pension systems. In fact, after a period of intense reform, many OECD countries have increased the official pension age above the age of 65 years and today it can be said that “67 has indeed become the new 65” (OECD 2015). The effects of these reforms however, are called into question by an important fact observed in the U.S.. Unlike the past, when a single spike in retirements at the full retirement age was observed (Gruber and Wise 1999), a second spike in retirements now occurs at age 62, which, under normal conditions, is the first age for early retirement (Gustman and Steinmeier 2005). The behavior of U.S. workers is puzzling because postponing retirement beyond age 62 is a good deal for most people, given that future Social Security benefits are increased at a better than the actuarially fair rate (Gustman and Steinmeier 2015; Shoven and Slavov 2012a, b). This fact has a potentially big impact on retirement age reform and requires investigation. The present analysis addresses this issue, starting from the preliminary observation that retirement is a form of insurance against labor income variability which allows workers who are eligible for retirement to replace an uncertain labor income with a certain stream of pension payments. This means that, similarly to what happens for precautionary saving, retirement can be used to reduce the disutility caused to a risk-averse agent by an uncertain level of labor income. Hence a precautionary motive for retirement may arise and be responsible for the observed retirement peak at age 62, because a risk averse worker may be pushed to plan an earlier exit from the labor market in the face of higher uncertainty in labor income.Footnote 1 We study the precautionary motive for retirement in a simple model where an agent chooses the level of saving and the timing of retirement in the presence of labor income risk. We assume that a pure redistributive pension system is in place where payments are certain and largely independent of individual contributions.Footnote 2 This type of system which primarily aims at granting its members a safe minimum benefit of a size known in advance, is a Beveridgean system which partially resembles the U.S. Social Security system.Footnote 3 Following a long tradition in decision theory which starts from Pratt (1964), we focus on the case of small risks. Our analysis characterizes and interprets the conditions for the precautionary motive for retirement and for saving to operate in two different settings. In the first setting, agent utility depends only on income, and a sufficiently low level of the index of absolute prudence is necessary for precautionary retirement. On the contrary, for the precautionary motive for saving to operate a sufficiently high index of absolute prudence is required, implying that for intermediate levels of the index, precautionary saving and precautionary retirement can coexist. In the second setting, agent utility also depends on leisure. Under the assumption of Edgeworth–Pareto complementarity between income and leisure, three conditions are sufficient for the precautionary motive for retirement and saving to jointly operate: prudence, a sufficiently low index of absolute prudence and cross-prudence in leisure. Our results enrich the description of the relationship between retirement and labor supplyFootnote 4 and suggest that a higher level of labor income risk, deriving from the effects of demographic change, may play a role in the increase in retirement at age 62. Papadopoulos et al. (2017) in fact point out that this risk has faced baby-boomers who are now approaching retirement age with diminished labor market prospects and decreased employment stability. This explanation is novel to the literature and contributes to the debate over the causes of the observed spike at age 62 where two alternative explanations are found. One explanation points at the deterioration in the macroeconomic scenario after the Great Recession, which caused workers suffering a negative earning shock to be pushed into early retirement due to reduced labor market opportunities (Card et al. 2014; Coile and Levine 2011a, b). A second explanation considers a microeconomic aspect related to worker preferences i.e. the heterogeneity in time preferences (Gustman and Steinmeier 2005). The presence in the population of individuals with high time preferences causes the spike in the retirement age at the first age for early retirement. The present analysis is mostly related to this last strand of the literature which focuses on the role of agent preferences, and in this context, introduces a new element, i.e preferences toward risk. A further contribution of the analysis is the characterization and interpretation of the conditions for precautionary retirement to crowd out precautionary saving. Analyzing the crowding out between retirement and saving is especially relevant in the light of the results obtained by Engen and Gruber (2001), and more recently by Chen et al. (2015). These authors find that unemployment benefits, which, like retirement, are a form of insurance against labor income risk, reduce the scope for precautionary saving. Our results show that in the case of precautionary retirement, this is not necessarily the case. In the setting where utility depends solely on income specific features of worker preferences, including prudence and temperance, are in fact crucial for the crowding out to occur, while in the setting where utility depends on income and leisure, no crowding out occurs. The paper proceeds as follows. Section 2 presents the basic model where agent utility depends solely on income. Section 3 defines the conditions for the precautionary motive for retirement and for savings to operate, in the presence of labor income risk. Section 4 characterizes the mutual relationship between precautionary retirement and saving. Section 5 introduces agent preferences over leisure, and studies the sufficient conditions for the precautionary motives for saving and for retirement to operate jointly. Section 6 discusses the results, and Sect. 7 concludes.

Title: Strategic corporate social responsibility, imperfect competition, and market concentration
Revenue in first-price auctions with a buy-out price and risk-averse bidders
Intro: The online auction marketplace of eBay has been well-studied in academic literature [see, for example, Hasker and Sickles (2010) for an overview of the subject]. The original auction mechanism of eBay involves a timed auction with a proxy bidding system and, as argued in Lucking-Reiley (2000), is well-modeled using a second-price payment rule. One option eBay gives sellers using this original auction mechanism [which we will call the California auction going forward, following Steiglitz (2007)] is to set a buy-out price, which eBay calls a “Buy-It-Now” price. Before any bids are placed on the item (or a secret reserve is met in the case the seller sets a secret reserve), any bidder can choose to pay the buy-out price and win the item immediately and with certainty. Giving sellers such an option seems, at first blush, a curious decision by eBay, as buy-out prices put a ceiling on the possible revenue the seller (and thus eBay) can earn from the auction. This initial intuition is validated by the fact proven by Mathews (2006) and Gupta and Gallien (2006) that, in their respective models of the California auction, risk-neutral and time-insensitive sellers facing risk-neutral and time-insensitive bidders whose values are independent and identically distributed will in equilibrium choose a buy-out price higher than any bidder is ever willing to bid.Footnote 1 But this theoretical model is too idealized to likely capture real world behaviors, and by changing the conditions above authors found theoretical reasons why sellers might post buy-out prices that buyers would use with a positive probability.Footnote 2 The two variations that authors have considered that result in buy-out prices that buyers would consider in equilibrium are time sensitivity and risk aversion. Mathews (2004, 2006), and Gupta and Gallien (2006) each considered models with a time sensitivity component to both sellers and bidders. With respect to time sensitivity, since a bidder using the buy-out price ends the California auction immediately, an auction in which the buy-out price is utilized will end more quickly than one where it is not utilized. As one might expect, these papers showed that time-sensitive sellers are willing to offer lower buy-out prices that time-insensitive buyers in equilibrium will exercise with a positive probability. Conversely, time-sensitive bidders are willing to exercise higher buy-out prices that will increase a time-insensitive seller’s expected revenue. The models utilized in Mathews (2004, 2006), and Gupta and Gallien (2006) are continuous-time models, a complicating but necessary component as modeling time-sensitivity requires utility to depend on time. The second variation that results in buy-out prices that will actually be exercised in equilibrium is risk aversion. This situation was considered in Budish and Takeyama (2001), Maslov (2018), Mathews and Katzman (2006), and Reynolds and Wooders (2009). Mathews and Katzman (2006) examined risk aversion in sellers and showed that a risk-averse seller will set a buy-out price low enough that risk-neutral bidders in equilibrium will exercise it with positive probability. Both Budish and Takeyama (2001) and Reynolds and Wooders (2009) consider risk-averse bidders with risk-neutral sellers. Budish and Takeyama (2001) consider a setting where there are only two bidders whose values can only equal two possible constants. In this case, they prove that a seller can increase his expected revenue in a second-price auction by including a suitable buy-out price. Furthermore, and more surprisingly, they prove that with a suitable buy-out price, a second-price auction with a buy-out price will result in more expected revenue than a first-price auction. This result lies in stark contrast with one of the classic results proven by Riley and Samuelson (1981) that when bidders are risk-averse (and have values drawn from a continuous distribution) the second-price auction generates less expected revenue than a first-price auction. Maskin and Riley (1985) confirmed this classic result in the same discrete setting considered by Budish and Takeyama (2001). To summarize, a first-price auction generates more expected revenue than a second-price auction when bidders are risk-averse. However, Budish and Takeyama (2001) showed that adding a buy-out price on the second-price auction can reverse this relationship. We note here that Budish and Takeyama (2001) did not investigate whether a well-chosen buy-out price could increase the expected revenue of a first-price auction. A natural question to ask with these results is whether they hold for bidder values drawn from continuous distribution. Reynolds and Wooders (2009) verified that the first result of Budish and Takeyama (2001) holds in a continuous case by showing that when bidders exhibit constant absolute risk aversion (CARA), then a range of suitably chosen buy-out prices will result in increased expected revenue for the seller. This result gives a satisfying reason why a seller would include tempting buy-out prices in a California auction. Furthermore, Maslov (2018) also indicates buy-out prices will increase expected seller revenue when bidders exhibit constant relative risk aversion (CRRA) in an environment where items are sold both in second-price auctions without a buy-out price and posted prices.Footnote 3 We will say more about generalizing the second result of Budish and Takeyama (2001) below. Thus far we have concentrated on the known theory surrounding buy-out prices in a California auction. However, buy-out prices appear elsewhere on eBay. Indeed, this main focus of this current study is not buy-out prices attached to the California auction, but to another selling format in the eBay marketplace. eBay also allows sellers to list items for a fixed price. That is, these are items with a “Buy-It-Now” price but no California auction attached to it. However, sellers can also attach a “Best Offer” option to the fixed-price listing, creating a “Buy-It-Now or Best Offer” mechanism. In these auctions, bidders make offers that a seller has up to 48 h to address by either accepting the offer, rejecting the offer, or making a counteroffer. A bidder can make up to five offers and a seller can make up to four counteroffers.Footnote 4 The fifth offer the bidder makes is a take-it-or-leave-it final offer. If an offer is accepted, the bidder pays her offer and receives the item. Where the California auction with the “Buy-It-Now” option is essentially a second-price mechanism with a buy-out price, the “Buy-It-Now or Best Offer” auction is a first-price mechanism with a buy-out price. The “Buy-It-Now or Best Offer” mechanism is also popular with sellers. In Table 1 below, we give the number of eBay listings in certain categories that eBay labels as “Auctions” (which is our California auction) and “Best Offer” which is our “Buy-It-Now or Best Offer” auction. Note that in the categories included that the number of “Best Offer” listing far exceeds the number of “Auction” listings, often by more than a factor of four. In this study, we are interested in comparing expected revenues between a second-price auction with a buy-out price (like the California auction with a Buy-It-Now price) with a first-price auction with a buy-out price (like a “Buy-It-Now or Best Offer” mechanism) when bidders are risk-averse. A first-price auction with a buy-out price admittedly simplifies many of the aspects of the “Buy-It-Now or Best Offer” auction, but we will argue in the next section as well as in the discussion section that the study of the former gives us insight into the latter. To that end, we will first consider the case where bidders draw their values with a continuous distribution. In this case, we derive equilibrium strategies for risk-averse bidders who exhibit either CARA or CRRA for a first-price auction with a buy-out price. We will show that for any fixed buy-out price, the first-price auction with the buy-out price earns more expected revenue than the second-price auction with a buy-out price (Theorem 2). This result yields an initial explanation to why sellers generally seem to prefer the “Buy-It-Now or Best Offer” mechanism to the California auction, as seen in Table 1. As mentioned previously, both Budish and Takeyama (2001) and Reynolds and Wooders (2009) show that a well-chosen buy-out price can increase seller revenue in a second-price auction when buyers are risk-averse. Here we will prove that this property does not generally hold in the first-price setting when bidder values are drawn from a continuous distribution. Specifically, we show that under some modest conditions on the continuous distribution of values (that is, that distribution is log-concave and twice differentiable), to maximize expected revenue a risk-neutral seller will set a buy-out price above what any bidder exhibiting either CARA or CRRA would ever utilize in equilibrium (Theorems 3, 4). That is, a seller cannot increase their revenue in a first-price auction by including a buy-out price even when bidders show some form of risk-aversion. Note that since expected revenue is maximized in the first-price auction when the buy-out price is set higher than any equilibrium bidder would bid, we see that if bidders exhibit CARA and have a continuous distribution of values that is log-concave and twice differentiable then a second-price auction with a buy-out price always generates less expected revenue than a first-price auction (Corollary 1). This shows that the second result of Budish and Takeyama (2001) mentioned above does not generally hold when bidders have a continuous distribution of values. The above result presents a discrepancy between the continuous model and the discrete model of Budish and Takeyama (2001), which motivates the question on how a buy-out option in a first-price auction affects seller revenue in the discrete model. We model this auction in the two-bidder-two-value setting of Maskin and Riley (1985) utilized in Budish and Takeyama (2001) and show that in this case a well-chosen buy-out price can increase seller revenue in the first-price auction when buyers are risk-averse (Theorem 6). In fact, the optimal buy-out price is the same for both first and second-price auctions and the two auctions generate the same amount of expected revenue with this optimal buy-out (Corollary 2). Considering these results across the continuous and discrete settings, we see that the first-price auction with an optimally chosen buy-out price will generate as much or more expected revenue than a second-price auction with an optimally chosen buy-out price. Thus these theoretical results support the thesis that a first-price mechanism is superior to a second-price mechanism in an online marketplaces where sellers are risk-neutral and buyers are risk-averse and explain to the prevalence of “Buy-It-Now or Best Offer” listings on eBay over the more traditional California auction. The paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2 we detail the specifics of the first-price with buy-out auction model for bidders whose values are continuously distributed and state Theorem 1 which gives the equilibrium strategies for bidders under CRRA and CARA risk profiles. In Sect. 3 we give our results on expected revenue in this continuous model that are stated above. In Sect. 4, we analyze a two-bidder-two-value discrete model for the first-price with buy-out auction comparable to the model considered in Budish and Takeyama (2001) by deriving equilibrium strategies for this case and give the results on expected revenue stated above for this discrete model. In Sect. 5 we discuss these results and how they relate to eBay. Finally, in the “Appendix” we give formal proofs of the lemmas and theorems found in the paper.

Title: Does add-on presence always lead to lower baseline prices? Theory and evidence
Intro: Add-ons, i.e. optional goods and services that consumers can add (at a price) to a baseline product, are ubiquitous. In the hotel industry, the price for a room typically does not include additional services such as telephone calls or minibar items. Similarly, airline tickets, especially in the case of low-cost carriers, do not include on-board meals. Appliance stores offer additional warranties to consumers after they buy. A long list of other examples could be provided. Often, prices for such add-ons are difficult (or costly) to observe before the baseline product is bought. This gives firms market power when selling add-ons even if the baseline product is offered in competitive markets. Consequently, add-on prices tend to be high and firms compete on the baseline product price, which then tends to be low.
